original_data.query: Can I park my car facing the wrong way on the street?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility, under current Town bylaws and regulations pertaining to vehicular traffic and parking, of positioning a motor vehicle on a public roadway or municipal right-of-way with the vehicle's orientation contravening the designated direction of travel for that lane or segment of roadway. Specifically, does any provision within the Traffic and Parking Bylaw, or related bylaws concerning public safety, impede or prohibit parking against the flow of traffic?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Direction on Highways

Based on the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's parking regulations, you are not permitted to park your vehicle on any highway with the front of the vehicle facing opposite to the direction in which vehicular traffic is proceeding on that side of the street.

This regulation is outlined in By-law 2008-114, as amended by By-law 2017-027.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Based on the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's parking regulations:

You cannot park your vehicle on any street with the front of the vehicle facing against the normal direction of traffic on that side of the street.

original_data.query: pwede ba tumae yung aso ko sa yard ng kapit bahay ko?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility, under current and recently enacted Town bylaws pertaining to animal control, property rights, waste management, and public health, of allowing a domestic animal, specifically a canine, to defecate on a neighboring private property. This inquiry seeks clarification on any applicable regulations, including prohibitions, obligations for waste removal, and potential violations of zoning ordinances related to animal nuisance or sanitation standards.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Regulasyon Tungkol sa Dumi ng Aso at Pagpasok sa Ari-arian ng Iba

Hindi po pinapayagan na hayaan ang inyong aso na tumae sa bakuran ng inyong kapitbahay.

Ayon sa By-law 2019-047 ng Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville:

  • Hindi po pinapayagan na hayaan ang inyong alagang hayop (kasama ang aso) na pumasok sa pribadong ari-arian ng iba nang walang pahintulot (Section 3.11). Ito po ay itinuturing na trespassing.
  • Kinakailangan din po na agad na alisin at itapon nang maayos ang dumi ng aso mula sa anumang pribado o pampublikong ari-arian sa Town, maliban sa inyong sariling ari-arian (Section 3.8).

Ang paglabag po sa mga probisyon na ito ay isang pagkakasala at maaaring may kaukulang multa.

original_data.query: is it alright if i continue riding my bike through a level train crossing even tho there are signs that tell cyclics to dismount?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding compliance with municipal traffic bylaws pertaining to bicycle operation at railway crossings. Specifically, what are the current regulations, including any recent amendments, governing the permissibility of riding a bicycle through a level railway crossing where signage mandates dismounting? Does any applicable bylaw, including those related to pedestrian safety or obstruction of public thoroughfares, prohibit or otherwise regulate this activity? What are the obligations of cyclists in relation to posted signage at railway crossings within the Town?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Based on the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's traffic regulations, By-law 2008-147 regulates traffic on highways under the Town's jurisdiction.

This by-law defines an "authorized sign" as any sign or marking placed on a highway under the authority of the by-law for the purpose of regulating, warning, or guiding traffic (Section 1(a)). The Director of Public Works is authorized to erect and maintain such signs (Section 2(d)).

Section 17 of By-law 2008-147 states that every person who contravenes any provision of this By-law is guilty of an offence and is liable to a fine.

While By-law 2008-147 does not specifically mention dismounting at train crossings, signs that instruct cyclists to dismount at such locations would be considered authorized signs intended to warn or guide traffic for safety purposes. Therefore, failing to obey these authorized signs would likely be considered a contravention of the by-law.

The by-laws provided do not contain specific regulations explicitly mandating cyclists to dismount at train crossings, but they do require adherence to authorized signs erected for traffic control and safety.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Whitchurch-Stouffville's traffic regulations, outlined in By-law 2008-147, govern traffic on Town highways.

Signs are placed to regulate, warn, or guide traffic, and the Town's Director of Public Works is authorized to put up and maintain these signs.

You must follow these signs. If a sign instructs cyclists to dismount at train crossings, it's there for safety. Ignoring it could result in a fine.

While there's no specific rule about dismounting at all train crossings, you are required to obey authorized signs.

original_data.query: How many dogs am I allowed to have at my house in Stouffville?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissible number of canines, *Canis lupus familiaris*, allowed per residential dwelling unit within the municipal boundaries of the Town of Stouffville, Ontario, Canada, as regulated by current Animal Control Bylaws, Zoning Bylaws pertaining to residential property use, and any applicable Public Health regulations concerning animal ownership, waste management, and potential nuisance. Request clarification on any limitations, restrictions, or permit requirements governing canine ownership, effective as of the current date.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Based on the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's Animal Services By-Law, the following limits apply to the number of animals you can keep at your property:

  • You are permitted to keep no more than three (3) dogs per property or, in the case of a multi-residential apartment building, per unit, within any residential, commercial, industrial, or institutional zoned property.
  • This limit does not apply to licensed kennels, accredited veterinary facilities, pet shops, or animal pounds/shelters.
  • Additionally, the total number of animals (including dogs) per single dwelling unit within any residential, commercial, industrial, or institutional zoned property shall not exceed six (6).

These regulations are outlined in By-law 2019-047.
original_data.laymans_answer:
You can have a maximum of three dogs at your house. This applies to houses and apartments. The total number of animals, including dogs, cannot exceed six.

These rules do not apply to licensed kennels, veterinary facilities, pet shops, or animal shelters. More information is available in By-law 2019-047.

original_data.query: what are the things in stouffville that need to be taken care of when needed to be taken care of
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding extant Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville bylaws pertaining to required maintenance, remediation, or abatement of conditions affecting public health, safety, or property standards. This includes, but is not limited to, obligations arising under property standards bylaws, waste management regulations, animal control bylaws, zoning ordinances concerning permitted uses and site maintenance, and public health regulations. Prioritize bylaws currently in force or recently amended within the past five years.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Property Maintenance Requirements in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Property owners in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville are responsible for maintaining their properties according to the standards set out in the Town's by-laws. These standards cover various aspects of property upkeep to ensure health, safety, and general appearance.

Yard and Property Grounds Maintenance

  • Yards must be kept clean and cleared up, free of weeds (removed by pulling, cutting, turning soil, or herbicide for poison ivy/giant hogweed as per By-law 2018-051), and grass must be maintained below 20 cm in height in turf grass areas (By-law 2016-068). Note that some vegetation rules do not apply to parts of agricultural properties where crops are produced (By-law 2018-051).
  • Shrubs, vines, hedges, bushes, and other vegetation (excluding weeds and turf grass) must be kept trimmed and not be overgrown or unsightly (By-law 2016-068).
  • Vegetation must not become unreasonably overgrown in a way that affects safety, visibility, or passage of the public, conceals hydrants/water valves, or obstructs vehicular traffic views (By-law 2016-068).
  • Heavy undergrowth should be eliminated to be consistent with the surrounding environment (By-law 2016-068).
  • Yards must be cultivated or protected by ground cover to prevent soil erosion (By-law 2016-068, By-law 2018-049).
  • Dead, diseased, decayed, or damaged trees or plants must be removed or pruned to prevent unsafe conditions or property damage (By-law 2016-068).
  • Properties must be free of all nuisances and unsanitary conditions, unlikely to cause damage or injury, not offensive to sight, and maintained to a standard commensurate with the neighbourhood (By-law 2018-049).
  • Suitable ground cover must be provided to maintain appearance and prevent erosion (By-law 2018-049).
  • Ground cover, hedges, trees, landscaping, and site facilities required by development conditions must be maintained (By-law 2018-049).

Waste, Refuse, and Debris

  • Properties must be free and clear of all refuse and waste, infestation, and accumulations of wood, debris, or other objects creating unsafe or unsightly conditions (By-law 2016-068).
  • Unlicensed or derelict vehicles, trailers, machinery, or parts are generally prohibited, except in licensed salvage/wrecking businesses or under specific conditions for inoperative agricultural machinery on farms (By-law 2016-068).
  • Household waste must be stored in rigid, watertight containers with secure lids when outdoors and not stored in the front yard of residential properties with a garage, side yard, or designated storage (By-law 2016-068).
  • Waste stored in exterior bins (6.5 cubic metres or less) must have covers, be large enough for waste between collections, and not be overloaded (By-law 2016-068).
  • No person shall deposit garbage, refuse, or waste in the yard of any property unless permitted by zoning (By-law 2016-068, By-law 2006-162).
  • Dumping or disposing of garbage, refuse, or domestic or industrial waste of any kind is prohibited within the Town (By-law 1975-033). Owners/lessees/occupants must cease using land for such purposes (By-law 1975-033).
  • Owners of private property must remove all refuse or debris to leave the property clean, unless permitted by zoning (By-law 2006-162).
  • Sufficient rooms, containers, and garbage receptacles must be provided to contain waste, which must be removed or made available for removal according to the Town's Waste Collection By-Law (By-law 2018-049).
  • Garbage chutes, disposal rooms, containers, and receptacles must be kept clean and odour-free, with efforts to control vermin (By-law 2018-049).

Composting

  • Composting is permitted only in the rear of a dwelling unit, in a container, pile, or digester, with no more than two per property (total capacity not exceeding 1.5 cubic metres) (By-law 2016-068).
  • Compost containers/digesters must be covered tightly (except when being used), no feces are allowed, no offensive odour should emanate, organic materials must be covered with yard waste/soil/humus, and the location must be at least 60 cm from any lot line (By-law 2016-068).

Water and Drainage

  • Standing water (other than natural bodies or maintained pools/ponds/hot tubs/wading pools) is not permitted for more than 3 days (By-law 2016-068).
  • Owners must take steps to remove standing water when required by an officer, which may include draining, grading, screening, or treatment (By-law 2016-068).
  • Properties must be graded and maintained to prevent water ponding, unsafe conditions, or harm to the environment (By-law 2016-068).
  • Catchbasins and swales must be installed and maintained where necessary to facilitate drainage and not impede storm water flow (By-law 2016-068).
  • Storm water runoff from downspouts and impervious surfaces must be contained within the property limits or drained to a swale, watercourse, or storm sewer (By-law 2016-068).
  • Adequate drainage must be installed for recurring excessive ponding (By-law 2016-068).
  • Property grading/alteration must not change existing drainage patterns or create additional runoff onto adjacent properties (By-law 2016-068).
  • Roof drainage, storm water, swimming pool, hot tub, or sump pump discharge must prevent ponding/basement entry, not discharge onto walkways/neighbouring lands, and be dechlorinated if treated before discharging to a storm sewer (By-law 2016-068).
  • Private drains must be kept operational and in good repair and not obstructed (By-law 2016-068).
  • Watercourses on property must not be obstructed (By-law 2016-068).
  • Basements or cellars must be maintained in a watertight condition and free from dampness/mould (By-law 2018-049).
  • Below grade floors must be adequately drained (By-law 2018-049).

Sewage

  • Sewage or organic waste must be discharged into a municipal system where available, or disposed of in a manner acceptable to local health authorities otherwise (By-law 2016-068).
  • Discharge of sewage onto the surface of the ground is prohibited (By-law 2016-068).
  • If a blocked or damaged sewer lateral is on private property, the owner is responsible for the costs incurred by the Town for repair or service (By-law 2002-219).
  • Every dwelling/building must have an adequate supply of potable water and a plumbing system maintained in good working order, free from leaks, and protected from freezing (By-law 2018-049).
  • Sanitary conveniences and toilet facilities must be properly located, enclosed, cleaned, and maintained (By-law 2018-049).

Pits, Excavations, Wells, etc.

  • Any well, cistern, cesspool, privy vault, pit, or excavation in active use must be secured by a fence with warning signs (By-law 2016-068).
  • Those not in active use must be permanently sealed or secured by a fence, cover, or other means (By-law 2016-068).

Graffiti

  • Placing graffiti on a building is prohibited (By-law 2016-068).
  • The owner or occupant must keep every building on the property free of graffiti (By-law 2016-068).

Snow and Ice

  • Snow and ice must be removed from the roof(s) and eave(s) of buildings if it could pose a health and safety hazard to persons or property below (By-law 2016-068).

Building Structure and Exterior

  • Every part of a building, including accessory buildings, must be maintained in a structurally sound condition (By-law 2018-049).
  • Damaged or deteriorated materials must be repaired or replaced (By-law 2018-049).
  • Exterior walls, roofs, and other parts must be free from loose/unsecured objects (By-law 2018-049).
  • Exterior exposed surfaces not resistant to deterioration must be treated with a protective coating (By-law 2018-049).
  • Exterior walls, columns, and beams must be maintained in good repair, weathertight, free from defects, protected from deterioration, and have a pleasant appearance (By-law 2018-049).
  • Patching and repairs to exterior walls must blend with existing material or be painted/clad uniformly (By-law 2018-049).
  • Canopies, marquees, signs, awnings, stairways, fire escapes, etc., must be maintained in good repair, properly anchored, and protected from elements (By-law 2018-049). Signs must also conform to the Town's Sign By-law and be removed if unused/discarded (By-law 2018-049).
  • Chimneys, smoke stacks, vent stacks, and other roof structures must be maintained in good repair, free from loose parts, hazards, and unsightly conditions (By-law 2018-049).
  • Roofs, including fascia, soffits, eaves troughs, and downpipes, must be maintained in a watertight condition and shed/drain water effectively (By-law 2018-049).
  • Partially constructed buildings intended to have a roof shall not be left without one (By-law 2018-049).
  • Foundations, basement/cellar/crawl space floors must be maintained in good repair to support loads and be watertight (By-law 2018-049).
  • Buildings must be supported by foundations extending below the frost line or to solid rock, made of concrete or suitable material (By-law 2018-049).

Building Interior

  • Exposed interior surfaces must be maintained in a clean, odour-free, sanitary condition, and in good repair, free of defects (By-law 2018-049).
  • Worn or torn floor/stair coverings must be repaired or replaced (By-law 2018-049).
  • Interior common areas must be kept free of objectionable markings (By-law 2018-049).
  • Handrails or banisters must be maintained on open sides of stairways, balconies, landings, or stairwells (By-law 2018-049).
  • Heating systems must be maintained in good working condition and capable of heating the building safely to the required standard (By-law 2018-049).
  • Fuel burning appliances must have ample air supply, be located safely, and be provided with guards where necessary (By-law 2018-049).
  • Electrical wiring, pipes for fuel, equipment, and appliances must be installed and maintained in good working order, free from hazards, and comply with regulations (By-law 2018-049).
  • Adequate lighting fixtures must be installed and maintained in all areas for safety and use (By-law 2018-049).
  • Sufficient ventilation must be provided to all areas to prevent accumulation of heat, dust, vapours, odours, and gases (By-law 2018-049).
  • Fire and accident protection measures must be maintained, including means of egress, fire/gas separations, fire protection equipment, smoke control, exit/emergency lighting, stairs, railings, guards, and removal of hazards (By-law 2018-049).
  • Dwellings must be kept free of rodents, vermin, and insects (By-law 2018-049).
  • Openings in exterior walls/roof must be filled to protect habitable space from water/weather and drafts (By-law 2018-049).
  • Floors, walls, and ceiling areas of habitable space must be watertight and free from dampness/mould (By-law 2018-049).
  • Carbon monoxide detectors and smoke alarms must be working in all dwelling units (By-law 2018-049).

Accessory Buildings

  • Foundations, walls, roofs, and parts of accessory buildings must be maintained with suitable materials and kept from unsightly appearance (By-law 2018-049).
  • Accessory buildings must be kept in good repair and free from hazards (By-law 2018-049).
  • The exterior must be weather resistant (By-law 2018-049).
  • Partially constructed accessory buildings intended to have a roof shall not be left without one (By-law 2018-049).

Vacant Buildings

  • Vacant buildings must be protected in accordance with the Town's Boarding Up of Vacant Buildings By-law (By-law 2018-049).
  • If vacant for more than 90 days, utilities must be disconnected or secured (unless necessary for safety/security) (By-law 2018-049).
  • The exterior must be maintained (By-law 2018-049).
  • Dilapidated derelict buildings must be demolished or removed, and the property left graded, level, and safe (By-law 2018-049).

Heritage Property

  • In addition to general standards, owners/occupants of heritage property must maintain, preserve, and protect heritage attributes to maintain character, visual, and structural integrity (By-law 2018-049).
  • Elements supporting heritage attributes must also be maintained (By-law 2018-049).
  • A heritage permit may be required before performing work under this section (By-law 2018-049).
  • Repair and replacement of heritage attributes must follow specific procedures using the same or replicating materials (By-law 2018-049).
  • Vacant heritage properties have specific requirements for boarding, securing openings, maintaining utilities for environmental control, and preventing moisture penetration (By-law 2018-049).

Property owners are obligated to comply with these standards and any orders issued by Town officers. Failure to comply may result in the Town performing the work at the owner's expense and potential fines (By-law 2016-068, By-law 2018-049, By-law 2006-162).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Property Maintenance Requirements in Whitchurch-Stouffville

As a property owner in Whitchurch-Stouffville, you must maintain your property to meet the Town's standards for health, safety, and appearance.

Yard and Property Grounds Maintenance

  • Keep yards clean and free of weeds. Cut grass to below 20 cm in turf areas. Note that some vegetation rules do not apply to agricultural properties producing crops.
  • Trim shrubs, vines, hedges, and bushes, so they are not overgrown or unsightly.
  • Ensure vegetation doesn't affect public safety, visibility, or obstruct hydrants/water valves or traffic views.
  • Eliminate heavy undergrowth.
  • Cultivate yards or use ground cover to prevent soil erosion.
  • Remove or prune dead, diseased, decayed, or damaged trees or plants to prevent unsafe conditions.
  • Keep properties free of nuisances and unsanitary conditions, maintaining a standard appropriate for the neighbourhood.
  • Maintain suitable ground cover to prevent erosion.
  • Maintain landscaping and site facilities as required by development conditions.

Waste, Refuse, and Debris

  • Keep properties free of refuse, waste, infestation, and accumulations of wood or debris that create unsafe or unsightly conditions.
  • Unlicensed or derelict vehicles, trailers, or machinery are generally prohibited, except for licensed salvage businesses or under specific conditions for farm equipment on farms.
  • Store household waste in rigid, watertight containers with secure lids when outdoors, and not in the front yard of residential properties with a garage, side yard, or designated storage.
  • Waste stored in exterior bins (6.5 cubic metres or less) must be covered, large enough for waste between collections, and not overloaded.
  • Do not deposit garbage in any yard unless permitted by zoning.
  • Dumping or disposing of garbage or waste is prohibited within the Town.
  • Remove all refuse or debris from private property to leave it clean, unless permitted by zoning.
  • Provide enough rooms, containers, and garbage receptacles for waste, and ensure it's removed according to the Town's Waste Collection By-Law.
  • Keep garbage chutes, disposal rooms, containers, and receptacles clean and odour-free, controlling vermin.

Composting

  • Compost only in the rear of a dwelling unit, in a container, pile, or digester (maximum two per property, not exceeding 1.5 cubic metres total).
  • Compost containers must be covered tightly (except when in use), contain no feces, emit no offensive odours, have organic materials covered with yard waste/soil, and be located at least 60 cm from any lot line.

Water and Drainage

  • Standing water (excluding natural bodies or maintained pools/ponds) is not allowed for more than 3 days.
  • Remove standing water as required by an officer, potentially through draining, grading, or treatment.
  • Grade and maintain properties to prevent water ponding or harm to the environment.
  • Install and maintain catchbasins and swales to facilitate drainage and not impede storm water flow.
  • Contain storm water runoff within property limits or drain it to a swale, watercourse, or storm sewer.
  • Install adequate drainage for recurring excessive ponding.
  • Do not alter property grading to change existing drainage patterns or create runoff onto adjacent properties.
  • Ensure roof drainage and other discharges prevent ponding, basement entry, and do not discharge onto walkways/neighbouring lands; dechlorinate treated water before discharging to a storm sewer.
  • Keep private drains operational and unobstructed.
  • Do not obstruct watercourses on your property.
  • Maintain basements in a watertight condition, free from dampness/mould.
  • Ensure below-grade floors are adequately drained.

Sewage

  • Discharge sewage into a municipal system where available, or dispose of it in a manner acceptable to local health authorities.
  • Do not discharge sewage onto the surface of the ground.
  • If a blocked or damaged sewer lateral is on private property, the owner is responsible for repair costs incurred by the Town.
  • Every building must have an adequate supply of potable water and a plumbing system in good working order, free from leaks, and protected from freezing.
  • Ensure sanitary conveniences and toilet facilities are properly located, enclosed, cleaned, and maintained.

Pits, Excavations, Wells, etc.

  • Secure any well, cistern, cesspool, pit, or excavation in active use with a fence and warning signs.
  • Permanently seal those not in active use, or secure them with a fence or cover.

Graffiti

  • Do not put graffiti on any building.
  • Keep buildings free of graffiti.

Snow and Ice

  • Remove snow and ice from roofs if it could be a hazard to people or property.

Building Structure and Exterior

  • Maintain every part of a building in structurally sound condition.
  • Repair or replace damaged or deteriorated materials.
  • Keep exterior walls and roofs free from loose/unsecured objects.
  • Treat exterior surfaces not resistant to deterioration with a protective coating.
  • Maintain exterior walls in good repair, weathertight, free from defects, and with a pleasant appearance.
  • Ensure patching and repairs to exterior walls blend in.
  • Maintain canopies, signs, stairways, and fire escapes in good repair and properly anchored. Remove unused signs.
  • Maintain chimneys and roof structures in good repair and free from hazards.
  • Keep roofs watertight and able to drain water effectively.
  • Buildings intended to have a roof cannot be left partially constructed without one.
  • Maintain foundations in good repair to support loads and be watertight.
  • Buildings must be supported by foundations extending below the frost line.

Building Interior

  • Keep interior surfaces clean, odour-free, sanitary, and in good repair.
  • Repair or replace worn or torn floor or stair coverings.
  • Keep interior common areas free of markings.
  • Maintain handrails on stairways, balconies, and landings.
  • Maintain heating systems in good working condition to safely heat the building.
  • Ensure fuel-burning appliances have ample air supply and are safely located.
  • Maintain electrical wiring, fuel pipes, equipment, and appliances in good working order and free from hazards.
  • Install and maintain adequate lighting fixtures.
  • Provide sufficient ventilation to prevent accumulation of heat, dust, vapours, odours, and gases.
  • Maintain fire and accident protection measures, including exits, fire separations, and safety equipment.
  • Keep dwellings free of rodents, vermin, and insects.
  • Fill openings in exterior walls/roof to protect from weather.
  • Ensure floors, walls, and ceilings are watertight and free from dampness/mould.
  • Ensure carbon monoxide detectors and smoke alarms are working.

Accessory Buildings

  • Maintain accessory buildings with suitable materials and keep them from looking unsightly.
  • Keep accessory buildings in good repair and free from hazards.
  • Ensure the exterior is weather resistant.
  • Partially constructed accessory buildings intended to have a roof shall not be left without one.

Vacant Buildings

  • Protect vacant buildings according to the Town's by-law.
  • If vacant for more than 90 days, disconnect or secure utilities (unless needed for safety/security).
  • Maintain the exterior.
  • Demolish or remove dilapidated buildings, and grade the property to be level and safe.

Heritage Property

  • Maintain heritage properties to protect their heritage attributes and structural integrity.
  • Maintain elements supporting heritage attributes.
  • A heritage permit may be required before performing work.
  • Repair and replace heritage attributes using the same or similar materials.
  • Vacant heritage properties have specific requirements for boarding, securing openings, maintaining utilities, and preventing moisture penetration.

You must follow these standards and any orders from Town officers. If you don't, the Town may do the work at your expense and you may face fines.

original_data.query: did you know that fireworks are allowed in stouffville on any weekday
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire whether the discharge, ignition, or setting off of fireworks, as defined under applicable municipal bylaws, is permitted within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville on weekdays, specifically Monday through Friday. This inquiry pertains to compliance with regulations governing noise control, public safety, property rights, animal welfare, and fire prevention, considering any temporal restrictions or exemptions currently in effect or recently enacted, and any permit requirements or prohibitions outlined in relevant bylaws.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Fireworks Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

According to the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's current by-laws, setting off fireworks on any weekday is not generally permitted.

Based on By-law 2025-024, which came into effect on April 16, 2025:

  • The sale of all types of fireworks within the Town is prohibited year-round (Section 2.1).
  • The discharge (setting off) of 'Family Fireworks' is prohibited at all times (Section 3.1).
  • The discharge of 'Display Fireworks' and 'Pyrotechnic Special Effects Fireworks' is only permitted if a permit is obtained from the Town's Fire Chief or an Assistant to the Fire Marshal (Sections 4.1 and 5.1). These permits are subject to specific requirements and conditions outlined in the bylaw.

Therefore, setting off fireworks on any weekday is not allowed unless you have obtained a specific permit for Display Fireworks or Pyrotechnic Special Effects Fireworks, and Family Fireworks are prohibited entirely.

Setting off fireworks on any weekday is generally not permitted in Whitchurch-Stouffville.

  • Sale of Fireworks: No person is permitted to sell or offer for sale any fireworks of any kind or description whatsoever in the Town on any day during the year (Section 2.1).

By-law 2025-024 repealed the previous fireworks by-law, By-law 2019-077-FR.

original_data.query: Are there specific times when parking is restricted on most streets?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the existence of municipal bylaws establishing restrictions on vehicular parking, specifically concerning temporal limitations applicable to public roadways within the Town's jurisdiction. original_data.filtered_answer:
General Parking Restrictions on Town Highways

Yes, there are specific times when parking is restricted on most streets (highways) under the jurisdiction of the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville.

According to Section 17(a) of By-law 2008-114, parking is prohibited on any highway:

  • At any time during the hours of 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.
  • From and including December 1st of each year, to and including March 31st of the following year.

Please note that there are specific exceptions to this winter parking restriction listed in the by-law, including a portion of Church Street south of Main Street and other designated locations.

  • From December 1st to March 31st each year.

There are some exceptions to the winter parking restriction, such as part of Church Street south of Main Street and other locations.

original_data.query: Is it permissible for my dog to defecate on my neighbor's lawn?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the current permissibility, under applicable Town bylaws pertaining to animal control, waste management, public health, and property rights, of allowing a domestic canine animal under one's ownership or control to deposit fecal matter on privately owned property not under the same ownership or control, specifically a neighboring residential lawn, within the Town limits. original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Excrement on Private Property

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, while your dog may defecate on your neighbor's lawn, you are required to immediately remove and properly dispose of the excrement. According to By-law 2019-047, Section 3.8, "Every Owner of a Dog shall immediately remove and properly dispose of excrement left by such Dog on any private or public property in the Town, other than on the Owner's property by placing such excrement in a garbage receptacle." Similarly, By-law 2001-082-LI, Section 14, states that "Any person who owns, harbours, or possess a dog shall forthwith clean up and dispose of any excrement left by the said dog on any property whether public or private in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville." Therefore, it is your responsibility as the dog owner to ensure that any excrement left by your dog on your neighbor's property is promptly cleaned up and properly disposed of.

original_data.query: how much is the fee to register my dog
original_data.transformed_query: "Inquire as to the current fee schedule and associated costs mandated by the Town's Animal Control Bylaw and related municipal codes for the registration of a domestic canine animal. Specifically, what is the prescribed registration fee, as of the current date, for a dog, considering all applicable categories, exemptions, and potential penalties for non-compliance with mandatory animal registration requirements, including but not limited to licensing and permit obligations under relevant property and public health regulations?"
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Registration Fees in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The fees for registering your dog in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville are set out in the Town's Fees and Charges By-law, as referenced in By-law 2019-047. Based on the amendments to the Fees and Charges By-law 2016-164-FI, specifically By-law 2017-010 and By-law 2017-075, the following fees apply:

  • Standard Dog Licence (Renewal or new resident by mail, at Outlets or Municipal Offices):
    • For licences purchased in January & February (base price): $38.00
    • For licences purchased from March to December (includes additional late fees): $48.00 ($38.00 base price + $10.00 additional late fee)
  • Dog Licence (Renewal or new resident by seller at Door):
    • For licences purchased from May to September: $54.00
  • New resident or new dog (October to December): No Charge for the current year, but you must make a pre-payment of the current year's base price for the following year.
  • New resident with a current tag from another municipality: Free Exchange.
  • Replacement Licence Tag: $10.00
  • Dog Licence for a Menacing Dog: $100.00
  • Dog Licence for a Dangerous Dog: $200.00

Please note that By-law 2019-047 also states that no licence fee shall be charged for a Service Dog.

Dog licences are required annually for dogs over the age of 16 weeks and expire on December 31st of the year they are issued, with renewals due on or before February 28th of each year, as per By-law 2019-047.

original_data.query: Can my dog walk on my neighbor's property?

original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Access to Neighbouring Property

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, your dog is generally not permitted to walk on your neighbour's private property without their explicit permission.

Specifically, Bylaw 2019-047, the Animal Services By-Law, states the following:

  • Section 3.3: "No Owner of a Domestic Animal shall allow a Domestic Animal to Run at Large within the limits of the Town, unless prior consent is given by the owner of the property in which the Domestic Animal is found to be Running at Large."
  • Section 3.11: "No person who owns, harbours, or possesses a Domestic Animal shall allow it, whether Leashed or unleashed, to trespass on private property."

Similarly, Bylaw 2001-082-LI also states in Section 13: "No person who owns, harbours, or possesses a dog shall allow it, whether leashed or unleashed, to trespass on private property."

Therefore, to allow your dog on your neighbour's property, you must have their prior consent.

original_data.query: Am I allowed to wash my car in my front yard?
original_data.transformed_query: Formal inquiry regarding permissible activities on residential property: Specifically, what are the current regulations, as of [CURRENT DATE], governing the washing of motor vehicles on private property, including front yards, within the Town? This inquiry pertains to potential violations of bylaws related to water usage restrictions, waste discharge, property maintenance standards, public nuisance ordinances, and any applicable environmental protection regulations. Are there any prohibitions or conditions precedent to such activity?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Car Washing Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Regarding washing your car in your front yard, there are several Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville by-laws that apply to water use, property maintenance, drainage, and parking. While there isn't a by-law that explicitly prohibits washing a car in your front yard, the activity is subject to various regulations:

  • Water Use Restrictions:

    According to By-law 2004-087 (Water Restrictions), the use of municipal water from a hose, pipe, sprinkler, or permanent water irrigation system for the purpose of washing vehicles is restricted. These restrictions are in place between May 15th and September 30th of each year. During this period:

    • Even-numbered addresses may use water outdoors only on even-numbered days of the month.
    • Odd-numbered addresses may use water outdoors only on odd-numbered days of the month.
    • Outdoor water use is only permitted between the hours of 6:00 am to 10:00 am and 6:00 pm to 10:00 pm.

    During a Stage 1 Outdoor Water Use Advisory or Stage 2 Outdoor Water Use Ban, all persons are requested or prohibited, respectively, from using municipal water for washing vehicles, with some exemptions for specific users like commercial car washes.

  • Water Discharge and Drainage:

    By-law 2018-056 (Water and Sewer) regulates discharges into the municipal sewage system, including storm sewers and land drainage works. This by-law prohibits the discharge of substances into a storm sewer or land drainage works if the discharge is not storm water or uncontaminated water. Car wash water, which typically contains soaps, detergents, and dirt, would generally not be considered storm water or uncontaminated water. Discharging such water into storm sewers or land drainage works is prohibited if it may cause interference, obstruction, damage, a hazard, or adverse effects to persons, property, vegetation, or the natural environment.

    Furthermore, By-law 2016-068 (Regulation - Yard & Property Maintenance) requires property owners to ensure their property is graded and maintained to prevent water from ponding or creating unsafe conditions. It also states that storm water runoff should be contained within the limits of the property and not discharged onto walkways, boulevards, stairs, or neighboring lands. This principle would extend to water used for car washing, meaning the water should not run off your property onto public areas or adjacent properties.

  • Parking Regulations:

    If your car is parked in your front yard while being washed, By-law 2017-027 (Parking Regulation) and By-law 2023-111 (Zoning Order) are relevant. By-law 2017-027 prohibits parking a motor vehicle in an "unauthorized area," which is defined as a Front Yard, Exterior Side Yard, or Side Yard, except as otherwise permitted under the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-Law. By-law 2023-111 clarifies that in residential zones, motor vehicle parking in a front yard is only permitted on a driveway or a parking pad that meets specific dimension requirements.

In summary, while you may wash your car on your property, you must adhere to the specific days and times for outdoor water use as outlined in By-law 2004-087. Additionally, you must ensure that the water used for washing your car does not flow off your property onto public lands or neighboring properties, and that it does not enter the storm sewer system, as per By-law 2016-068 and By-law 2018-056. Your vehicle must also be parked in an authorized area, such as a driveway or designated parking pad, while being washed, in accordance with By-law 2017-027 and By-law 2023-111.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Car Washing Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

You can wash your car in your front yard, but there are rules you need to follow:

  • Water Use Restrictions:

    From May 15th to September 30th, you can only use municipal water to wash your car on certain days and times:

    • If your address is even-numbered, you can only use water outdoors on even-numbered days of the month.
    • If your address is odd-numbered, you can only use water outdoors on odd-numbered days of the month.
    • Outdoor water use is only allowed between 6:00 am to 10:00 am and 6:00 pm to 10:00 pm.

    During water use advisories or bans, you may be asked or prohibited from washing your car with municipal water.

  • Water Discharge and Drainage:

    You cannot discharge car wash water (which contains soap, detergents, and dirt) into storm sewers or land drainage areas if it causes any damage or harm to property, people, or the environment.

    You must also make sure that the water used to wash your car stays on your property and does not flow onto walkways, neighboring properties, or other public areas.

  • Parking Regulations:

    When washing your car, it must be parked on your driveway or a designated parking pad. Parking in an "unauthorized area" (anywhere in the front yard that is not a driveway or parking pad) is not permitted.

In short, you can wash your car on your property if you follow the rules about when you can use water, make sure the water stays on your property, and park your car in the right spot.

original_data.query: What are the bylaws regarding noise levels from construction activities?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissible sound levels and noise emission standards applicable to construction activities within the Town's jurisdiction, pursuant to all relevant bylaws, including but not limited to noise control bylaws, zoning ordinances, and public health regulations. Specifically, determine any restrictions, prohibitions, or permitted hours of operation concerning construction-related noise, considering temporal limitations and the most recently enacted amendments governing noise pollution and disturbance.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Noise Regulations for Construction Activities in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville regulates noise, including that from construction activities, primarily under By-law 2019-092-RE, as amended by subsequent by-laws such as By-law 2022-080-RE, By-law 2024-042-RE, and By-law 2024-077-RE. By-law 2018-052-RE also provides relevant exemptions for public works.

General Noise Prohibition

No person shall make, cause, or permit the emission of noise that is audible at a Point of Reception and is likely to disturb any person in the Town. This includes the operation of any Construction Equipment in the Stouffville Secondary Plan Area residential area without effective muffling devices in constant operation and good working order, as outlined in By-law 2019-092-RE.

Restricted Times for Construction Noise

The following restricted time periods apply to construction noise:

  • Operation of any Construction Equipment (general):
    • 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Monday to Friday
    • 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Saturday
    • All day Sundays and Holidays
  • Construction or the operation of any Construction Equipment conducted by any individual other than the homeowner:
    • 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Monday to Friday
    • 7:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. Saturday
    • All day Sundays and Holidays

These specific restrictions are detailed in By-law 2019-092-RE, with the non-homeowner construction times further clarified by By-law 2022-080-RE.

Definitions

As per By-law 2019-092-RE and By-law 2024-042-RE:

  • "Construction" includes erection, alteration, repairing, dismantling, demolition, structural maintenance, painting, moving, land clearing, earth moving, grading, excavating, the laying of pipe and conduit whether above or below ground level, street and highway building, concreting, equipment installation and alteration and the structural installation of construction components and materials in any form or for any purpose, and includes any work in connection therewith.
  • "Construction Equipment" means any equipment or device designed and intended for use in construction, or material handling, including but not limited to, air compressors, pile drives, pneumatic or by hydraulic tools, bulldozers, tractors, excavators, trenchers, cranes, derricks, loaders, scrapers, generators, pavers, off highway haulers or trucks, ditchers, compactors and rollers, pumps, concrete mixers, graders, or other material handling equipment.

Exemptions

The noise by-law provides general exemptions, including but not limited to:

  • Measures undertaken in an emergency for immediate health, safety, or welfare of persons and animals, or for the preservation or restoration of property.
  • The operation of emergency vehicles.
  • Activities of snow plowing and/or removal.
  • Measures undertaken where the Town, its servants, employees, contractors, or agents are carrying out Town operations or operating, maintaining, or installing municipally-owned infrastructure, facilities, or the like.
  • Non-emergency construction, reconstruction, or repair of any regional, provincial, or federal public works, including public highways, provided the Town is given advanced written notice of the hours to be worked if outside the permitted construction hours. This exemption is outlined in By-law 2019-092-RE, reflecting an amendment from By-law 2018-052-RE.

Additionally, a Temporary Noise Permit may be granted for exemptions from the by-law's provisions. Applications for exemptions not exceeding 90 days can be made to the Manager of By-Law or designate, while applications for exemptions over 90 days must be made to Council. The application process and conditions for granting exemptions are detailed in By-law 2019-092-RE.

Penalties and Enforcement

Any person who contravenes the provisions of the noise by-law is liable to pay an administrative penalty and any administrative fees in accordance with the Administrative Monetary Penalty System By-law (By-law 2024-042-RE). The Provincial Offences Act does not apply to contraventions of designated provisions of this by-law. Furthermore, By-law 2024-077-RE states that an owner, whether present or absent from the property where the noise is being emitted, shall be presumed to have permitted or caused the noise, which presumption may be rebutted by evidence to the contrary.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Noise Regulations for Construction Activities in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Whitchurch-Stouffville has rules about noise from construction.

General Noise Prohibition

You can't make noise that is likely to bother people. This includes using construction equipment without proper muffling devices, especially in residential areas within the Stouffville Secondary Plan Area.

Restricted Times for Construction Noise

Construction noise is restricted during certain hours:

  • General Construction Equipment:
    • 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Monday to Saturday
    • All day Sundays and Holidays
  • Construction by someone other than the homeowner:
    • 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Monday to Friday
    • 7:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. Saturday
    • All day Sundays and Holidays

Definitions

  • "Construction" includes building, repairing, demolition, land clearing, and similar activities.
  • "Construction Equipment" means equipment used for construction, such as compressors, bulldozers, cranes, and mixers.

Exemptions

Some activities are exempt from the noise by-law:

  • Emergency measures for health, safety, or property preservation.
  • Operation of emergency vehicles.
  • Snow plowing and removal.
  • Town operations or maintenance.
  • Public works by other levels of government, if the Town receives notice for work outside of permitted hours.

You can apply for a Temporary Noise Permit to get an exemption from the noise rules. Applications for exemptions not exceeding 90 days can be made to the Manager of By-Law or designate, while applications for exemptions over 90 days must be made to Council.

Penalties and Enforcement

You may have to pay a penalty if you break the noise by-law. If noise comes from your property, it will be assumed that you permitted it, unless you can prove otherwise. By-law 2024-077 states that an owner, whether present or absent from the property where the noise is being emitted, shall be presumed to have permitted or caused the noise, which presumption may be rebutted by evidence to the contrary.

original_data.query: can my dog poop on someone else's lawn?

Dog Excrement on Private Property

Additionally, if you are in a park, By-law 2020-087, Section 8.2 requires every owner or person having control of any dog to pick up and remove forthwith excrement left by the dog and dispose of it in a bag into a waste receptacle or remove it from the park or public place.

original_data.filtered_answer:
The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville by-laws do not explicitly define or prohibit biking on "unofficial trails." However, the use of bicycles within the Town's parks and trails is regulated by By-law 2020-087, which governs the use of Parks, Trails, Park Buildings, and Open Spaces. Please consider the following:

  • Under By-law 2020-087, Section 4.1(a) states that "No person shall: play, organize, encourage, or otherwise take part in any game or activity which involves thrown, hurled, or propelled objects in areas of a park not designated for that type of game or activity and/or that may cause an element of danger to any person not involved in the same game or activity." While this clause specifically mentions objects, it also refers to activities in areas not designated for that type of activity. Biking in areas not designated as trails could potentially fall under this.

  • By-law 2020-087, Section 6.1, prohibits damage to property. Specifically, it states that "no person shall: (a) plant, prune, remove or damage any plant, shrub, flower, flowerbed, tree, bush, sod, grass, or any other vegetation without written permission from the Manager of Facilities and Parks or designate." Biking off designated trails could cause damage to vegetation or the natural environment, which would be a contravention of this by-law.

  • For context, By-law 2020-087, Section 4.1(t) specifically prohibits riding a bicycle "on, over, or across any bridge in any park." This indicates that specific regulations exist for bicycle use within parks and trails.

Therefore, while there is no direct prohibition on "unofficial trails," engaging in activities like biking in areas not designated for such use, or causing damage to park property or vegetation, may be in contravention of the general regulations outlined in By-law 2020-087.

original_data.query: what happens if i dont remove it
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and potential penalties for failure to comply with a notice or order issued by the Town pursuant to applicable bylaws, including but not limited to those pertaining to property standards, waste management, animal control, public health, or zoning regulations. Specifically, what are the ramifications, including fines, enforcement actions, or other remedies available to the Town, should a property owner or resident fail to abate a nuisance, remove prohibited items, or otherwise rectify a violation as directed within the prescribed timeframe under current and recently amended bylaws?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Consequences of Non-Compliance with a Town Order for Removal or Remedial Action

If you do not comply with a Town order to remove an item or rectify a condition on your property, the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville may take action to ensure compliance. The specific consequences can vary depending on the nature of the item or condition, but generally include the following:

  • Town Remedial Action: The Town may undertake the removal or required work at your expense. For example, By-law 2008-060 states that if a boat deemed a public nuisance is not removed, the Town may remove and dispose of it. Similarly, By-law 1973-043 authorizes the Town to demolish unsafe, fire-damaged buildings if the owner fails to do so. Under By-law 2016-068 (Property Maintenance) and By-law 2018-049 (Property Standards), if an owner fails to comply with an order to correct a contravention, the Town may cause the work to be performed. For waste management, By-law 2018-035 indicates that if waste is not set out correctly and is not collected, and you fail to remove it, the Town may collect it and charge a fee.
  • Cost Recovery: Any expenses incurred by the Town in performing the removal or remedial work will be recoverable from the property owner. These costs can be added to the property's tax roll and collected in the same manner as municipal taxes. This is explicitly stated in By-law 2008-060, By-law 1973-043, By-law 2016-068, By-law 2018-035, By-law 2006-162, and By-law 2018-049.
  • Fines and Penalties: Failure to comply with any provision of a by-law or an order issued under its authority is an offence. Upon conviction, you may be liable to a fine as provided for in the Provincial Offences Act.
    • For a first conviction, fines can range from a minimum of $100 to $350 and up to $50,000 or $100,000, depending on the specific by-law and offence (e.g., By-law 2018-035, By-law 2018-049).
    • For a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence, fines can increase, potentially up to $100,000 (e.g., By-law 2016-068, By-law 2018-035, By-law 2018-049).
    • If an order is not complied with, the contravention may be deemed a continuing offence for each day or part of a day that the order is not complied with, incurring daily fines (e.g., By-law 2016-068, By-law 2018-035, By-law 2018-049).
    • It is also an offence to provide false information, give a false statement, or hinder/obstruct a Town Officer, employee, or agent in the lawful exercise of their duties under a by-law (e.g., By-law 2020-108, By-law 2016-068, By-law 2018-049).
  • Order Registration on Title: An order issued by the Town may be registered on the title to the land to which it applies. This means that any person acquiring an interest in the land after the order's registration will be bound by it (By-law 2018-049).

It is important to comply with all Town by-laws and orders to avoid these consequences.
original_data.laymans_answer:

original_data.query: what is happen if i get bitten by a dog?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the applicable bylaws and regulations pertaining to incidents of animal bites, specifically canine-inflicted injuries, within the Town's jurisdiction. This includes, but is not limited to, regulations under Animal Control Bylaws, Public Health Bylaws, and potentially Property Standards Bylaws. Seek clarification on reporting obligations, owner liability, quarantine procedures, dangerous dog designations, and potential remedies for bite victims, considering the most current and recently amended versions of said bylaws.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Bite Incidents in Whitchurch-Stouffville

If you are bitten by a dog in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the By-law 2019-047 (Animal Services By-Law) outlines the procedures and consequences. A "Bite" is defined as the piercing or puncturing of the skin as a result of contact with a Dog's tooth or teeth.

Declaration of a Dangerous or Menacing Dog

  • A dog that has bitten or injured a person, Domestic Animal, or livestock (in the absence of any Mitigating Factor) may be declared a Dangerous Dog by the Municipal Law Enforcement Manager or Supervisor.
  • A dog that chases or approaches a person or Domestic Animal in a menacing fashion (e.g., growling, snarling, baring teeth, inhibited biting without physical injury) may be declared a Menacing Dog.
  • This declaration is made upon receipt of a signed declaration (Schedule A of By-law 2019-047) from a witness who saw the incident.

Muzzle Order and Owner Responsibilities

  • If a dog is declared Menacing or Dangerous, an Order to Muzzle (Schedule B of By-law 2019-047) will be issued to the owner within two days.
  • Owners of a Dangerous Dog must comply with specific requirements, including:
    • Keeping the dog securely confined indoors, in an enclosed pen, or within a securely fenced yard (minimum 1.8 metres/6 ft high) with a locking device to prevent escape and contact with others.
    • When off the owner's property, ensuring the dog is securely on a leash (maximum 1.83 metres/6 ft) and humanely muzzled to prevent biting or attacking.
    • Ensuring the dog is under the control of a person 16 years of age or older when off property.
    • Having the dog microchipped within 30 days and registering the number with Municipal Law Enforcement.
    • Notifying Municipal Law Enforcement within 48 hours if the dog's ownership is transferred, its residency changes, or if the dog is destroyed.
  • Owners of a Menacing Dog must follow the same requirements as for a Dangerous Dog, or less restrictive requirements if specified in the Order to Muzzle.

Impoundment and Costs

  • If an owner fails to comply with an Order to Muzzle, the dog may be impounded by an Animal Services Officer.
  • If an impounded animal is injured and veterinary services are required, the owner is liable for these costs, in addition to other impoundment fees, before the animal can be redeemed.
  • If a seized and impounded animal is suspected of being rabid, it will be held in isolation for at least ten (10) days if ordered by the Regional Health Authority, as per By-law 2019-047.

Appeals and Penalties

  • Owners may appeal a Muzzle Order to the Appeals Committee within 30 days of being served the order. The Appeals Committee's decision is final and binding.
  • Contravention of any provision of By-law 2019-047, including non-compliance with an Order to Muzzle, is an offence. Penalties can include fines ranging from a minimum of $300 for a first conviction to up to $100,000 for subsequent or continuing offences, as outlined in Section 11 of By-law 2019-047 and further amended by By-law 2020-108.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Dog Bite Incidents in Whitchurch-Stouffville

If a dog bites you (piercing your skin), Whitchurch-Stouffville has specific procedures.

Dangerous or Menacing Dog Declaration

  • A dog that bites or injures someone may be declared a Dangerous Dog.
  • A dog that threatens someone by chasing or acting aggressively may be declared a Menacing Dog.
  • This declaration requires a signed statement from a witness.

Muzzle Order and Owner Responsibilities

  • If a dog is declared Menacing or Dangerous, the owner will receive an Order to Muzzle.
  • Owners of a Dangerous Dog must:
    • Keep the dog securely confined.
    • When off their property, keep the dog on a leash (maximum 6 ft) and humanely muzzled.
    • Ensure the dog is controlled by someone 16 or older when off property.
    • Have the dog microchipped and registered with Municipal Law Enforcement.
    • Notify Municipal Law Enforcement within 48 hours if the dog's ownership changes, it moves, or it dies.
  • Owners of a Menacing Dog must follow the same rules as for a Dangerous Dog, or potentially less strict rules.

Impoundment and Costs

  • If an owner doesn't follow the Order to Muzzle, the dog may be impounded.
  • The owner is responsible for veterinary costs if an impounded dog is injured.
  • If an impounded dog is suspected of rabies, it will be isolated for at least 10 days.

Appeals and Penalties

  • Owners can appeal a Muzzle Order within 30 days.
  • Not following these rules can result in fines, starting at $300 for a first offense, up to $100,000 for repeat offenses.

original_data.query: what is the regulations for walking dogs to do his business?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding current municipal bylaws pertaining to the control and management of domestic animals, specifically canines, with respect to defecation and urination within the Town. Seek clarification on owner/handler responsibilities for waste removal, permissible locations for canine elimination, potential public health or nuisance violations, and applicable regulations under animal control, waste management, and property standards bylaws, including enforcement provisions and penalties for non-compliance, prioritizing recently enacted or amended regulations.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Excrement Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, dog owners are required to manage their dog's waste responsibly on both public and private property. The regulations are primarily outlined in the By-law 2019-047 (Animal Services By-Law) and the By-law 2020-087 (Parks By-Law).

  • General Requirement (Stoop and Scoop): According to Section 3.8 of By-law 2019-047, every owner of a dog must immediately remove and properly dispose of any excrement left by their dog on any private or public property in the Town, other than on the owner's own property. This involves placing the excrement in a garbage receptacle.
  • On Owner's Property: Section 3.9 of By-law 2019-047 further states that owners must remove and properly dispose of any such excrement on their own property in a timely manner, ensuring it does not disturb the enjoyment, comfort, or convenience of any person in the vicinity.
  • In Parks and Public Places: Specifically for parks and public places, Section 8.2 of By-law 2020-087 mandates that every owner or person having control of any dog shall pick up and remove forthwith excrement left by the dog and dispose of it in a bag into a waste receptacle or remove it from the park or public place.
  • Exceptions for Persons with Disabilities:
    • By-law 2019-047 (Section 3.8) provides a defence in prosecution if the owner can prove they have a physical or visual disability that makes them incapable of cleaning up the excrement.
    • Similarly, By-law 2001-082-LI (Section 15) states that its "stoop and scoop" requirement does not apply to any person whose sight is impaired and whose dog is a Seeing Eye dog trained to guide or lead a blind person.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Dog Excrement Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

When walking your dog in Whitchurch-Stouffville, you must immediately clean up after your dog on both public and private property (any property that is not your own).

  • General Requirement: You must immediately remove and properly dispose of any excrement left by your dog on public or private property (excluding your own property) by placing it in a garbage receptacle.
  • On Your Property: You must also remove and properly dispose of any excrement left by your dog on your own property in a timely manner, ensuring it doesn't disturb your neighbours.
  • In Parks and Public Places: You must pick up your dog's excrement immediately and dispose of it in a bag into a waste receptacle, or remove it from the park or public place.
  • Exceptions for Persons with Disabilities:
    • If you have a physical or visual disability that makes you unable to clean up after your dog, you may have a defence if prosecuted.
    • This "stoop and scoop" requirement does not apply to individuals with impaired sight whose dog is a Seeing Eye dog.

original_data.query: What are the regulations for building a swimming pool in my backyard?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding current municipal regulations pertaining to the construction and installation of swimming pools on private residential property within the Town. Specifically, what are the applicable zoning bylaw requirements, including but not limited to setback distances, fencing obligations, permit acquisition prerequisites, and compliance standards concerning water discharge, noise control, and public health, as governed by relevant Town bylaws currently in force?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Swimming Pool Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Building a swimming pool in your backyard in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville involves several regulations concerning permits, enclosures, location, and drainage. Here's a summary based on the Town's by-laws:

Permits and Enclosure Requirements

Before excavating or constructing a swimming pool, or erecting its enclosure, you must obtain a permit. Plans for the enclosure must be submitted to the Chief Building Official, and a permit fee must be paid in accordance with the Town's Fees & Charges By-law. An encroachment permit is also required for any access across or work on Town property related to the pool or enclosure construction. If water is added to the pool during construction, a temporary enclosure must be erected and maintained until the permanent enclosure is approved.

All swimming pools must be completely surrounded by an enclosure to restrict access, especially for small children. Key requirements for enclosures include:

  • The enclosure must extend from the ground to a height of not less than 1.5 metres, measured on the outside.
  • No part of the enclosure shall consist of barbed wire, razor wire, or any device designed to conduct an electric current, or possess other dangerous characteristics.
  • There should be no permanent objects adjacent to the enclosure that could facilitate climbing.
  • No gap within or below the enclosure shall exceed 100 mm.
  • No part of an enclosure shall be located within 1.2 metres of the edge of the water in the swimming pool.
  • Enclosures should not have rails or other horizontal or diagonal bracing on the outside that would facilitate climbing.
  • If a building wall forms part of the enclosure, any door or gate leading into the enclosure through that wall must have a bolt latch, chain latch, or other suitable device located at least 1.5 metres above the floor or ground level.
  • Gates forming part of an enclosure must be of equivalent construction and height to the fence, supported on substantial hinges, and be self-closing, lockable, and self-latching. The opening device for the latch must be at the top of the gate and designed so it cannot be readily opened from the outside by small children. Gates must be kept locked at all times if a responsible person is not present and supervising the pool.
  • Specific construction standards are outlined for chain link and wood fences, and alternative designs must be approved by the Chief Building Official to ensure equivalent safety.
  • Hot tubs and spas are exempt from these enclosure requirements if a substantial, locked cover is affixed to prevent access when not in use.

These enclosure regulations are detailed in By-law 2013-168, Section 8.

Zoning and Location Requirements

A swimming pool or hot tub is generally permitted as an accessory use to a residential use. However, it is subject to specific location restrictions:

  • A swimming pool or hot tub is not permitted in the actual front yard in any zone.
  • It is permitted in the actual or required rear yard, exterior side yard, or interior side yard of any lot.
  • The edge of the water of the swimming pool must not be located any closer than 1.2 metres to any lot line or street line.
  • Swimming pool pumps, filters, and heaters are permitted to project into required yards without restriction, but must be no closer than 0.6 metres from the rear lot line, interior lot line, and exterior side lot line, where the required setback is more than 0.6 metres.
  • Swimming pools and hot tubs are excluded from the calculation of lot coverage.

These zoning provisions are outlined in By-law 2020-058, Section 1(j) (new Section 3.42) and Section 1(e) (new Section 3.22, encroachment provision 11). Additionally, By-law 1996-078, Section 11.(33) also states that swimming pools are not considered a building for lot coverage calculation.

Please note that for specific Recreational Residential (RRC) zones, a swimming pool may not be permitted in the Exclusive Use Area for any Dwelling Unit. This is an exception found in By-law 1998-231, Section 18.3(qq) A.1.xiii and By-law 2003-167, Section 18.3(vv) A.1.x.

Drainage and Maintenance

The installation of any swimming pool or its enclosure must not alter the existing drainage pattern of the lot unless approved by the Chief Building Official. The owner is responsible for ensuring that the new drainage pattern does not negatively affect neighbouring lands.

Regarding swimming pool water discharge:

  • You cannot discharge swimming pool water onto any property without the consent of that property's owner.
  • Swimming pool water and backwash water may be discharged directly by a hose onto the street in front of the owner's property containing the swimming pool.
  • If discharging swimming pool water (other than backwash water) onto a street, you must first remove all organic materials from the water and allow the water to remain for a minimum of 3 days without the addition of any chemicals or algaecides.
  • All roof drainage or storm water, swimming pool, hot tub, or sump pump discharge from the property must be drained to prevent recurrent ponding or water entering a basement or cellar.
  • Such discharge must not be directed onto walkways, boulevards, stairs, or neighbouring lands.
  • If the water is chlorinated or chemically treated, it must be dechlorinated before being discharged to a storm sewer.

Furthermore, every owner of property containing a swimming pool must maintain it in good repair and working condition, and the purification system must be maintained so that the water is properly filtered and purified to prevent health hazards. These drainage and maintenance requirements are outlined in By-law 2006-162, Sections 6, 7.1, 7.2, and 9.5.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Swimming Pool Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

If you're planning to build a swimming pool in your backyard, here's what you need to know:

Permits and Enclosure Requirements

You'll need a permit before starting any work. Submit your enclosure plans to the Chief Building Official and pay the required fee. An encroachment permit is also needed for any work on Town property related to the pool.

Your pool must be fully enclosed to restrict access. Here are the enclosure requirements:

  • Enclosures must be at least 1.5 metres high.
  • Barbed wire, electric fences, and other dangerous materials are prohibited.
  • Keep the area around the enclosure clear of climbable objects.
  • Gaps in or under the enclosure cannot exceed 100 mm.
  • The enclosure must be at least 1.2 metres from the pool's edge.
  • Enclosures shouldn't have climbable rails on the outside.
  • Doors or gates in a building wall that forms part of the enclosure must have a latch at least 1.5 metres above the ground.
  • Gates must match the fence's height and construction, have self-closing and self-latching mechanisms, be lockable, and the latch opening should be placed at the top, making it difficult for small children to open. Keep gates locked when the pool isn't supervised.
  • Specific construction standards apply to chain link and wood fences. Alternative designs must be approved by the Chief Building Official.
  • Hot tubs and spas are exempt if they have a locked cover when not in use.

Zoning and Location Requirements

Swimming pools are generally allowed as an accessory to residential use, but there are location restrictions:

  • Pools are not allowed in the front yard.
  • They are allowed in rear, exterior side, or interior side yards.
  • The pool's edge must be at least 1.2 metres from any lot line or street line.
  • Pool pumps, filters, and heaters can project into required yards but must be at least 0.6 metres from the rear, interior, and exterior side lot lines (where the required setback is more than 0.6 metres).
  • Pools don't count towards lot coverage calculations.

In Recreational Residential (RRC) zones, a swimming pool may not be permitted in the Exclusive Use Area for any Dwelling Unit. This is an exception found in By-law 1998-231 and By-law 2003-167.

Drainage and Maintenance

Pool installation cannot change the existing drainage pattern unless approved. Ensure the new drainage doesn't harm neighbouring properties.

Regarding water discharge:

  • You need permission to discharge pool water onto another person's property.
  • You can discharge pool water onto the street in front of your property.
  • Before discharging pool water (other than backwash water) onto a street, remove all organic materials and let the water sit for at least 3 days without chemicals.
  • All drainage must prevent ponding or water from entering basements and must not be directed onto walkways, stairs, or neighbouring lands.
  • Dechlorinate chemically treated water before discharging it to a storm sewer.

Keep your pool in good repair, and maintain the purification system to prevent health hazards.

original_data.query: can my dog poop in front of businesses?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding compliance with municipal bylaws pertaining to animal control, waste management, and public health, specifically concerning the defecation of domestic animals, particularly canines, on commercial properties or in areas adjacent to business establishments within the Town. Request clarification on any prohibitions, obligations for removal of excrement, or permissible areas for animal waste disposal under current and recently enacted regulations governing public spaces and private property rights.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Excrement Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, dog owners are required to immediately remove and properly dispose of any excrement left by their dog on any private or public property, including in front of businesses. This is mandated under the Town's Animal Services By-law.

Specifically, By-law 2019-047, Section 3.8, states:

  • "Every Owner of a Dog shall immediately remove and properly dispose of excrement left by such Dog on any private or public property in the Town, other than on the Owner's property by placing such excrement in a garbage receptacle."

Additionally, if you are in a park or public place, By-law 2020-087, Section 8.2, reinforces this requirement:

  • "Every owner or person having control of any dog shall pick up and remove forthwith excrement left by the dog and dispose of it in a bag into a waste receptacle or remove it from the park or public place."

Therefore, while your dog may excrete in front of a business, you are legally obligated to clean it up immediately and dispose of it properly.

Yes, but as a dog owner in Whitchurch-Stouffville, you must immediately clean up and properly dispose of any excrement left by your dog on any private or public property. This includes in front of businesses.

You must place the excrement in a garbage receptacle.

original_data.query: how high can my fence be?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding permissible fence height regulations within the Town's jurisdiction, specifically concerning zoning ordinances, property line restrictions, and building code compliance. Request clarification on maximum allowable fence height limitations for residential properties, considering current and recently amended bylaws pertaining to property rights, public safety, and neighbourhood aesthetics. Determine any applicable exceptions or variances based on lot size, location, or specific zoning designations.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Fence Height Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The maximum height for your fence depends on its location on your property and the zoning of your land (residential or non-residential).

  • In Residential Areas:
    • In the front yard, a fence cannot be higher than 1 metre above grade.
    • In any interior side yard, exterior side yard, or rear yard, a fence cannot be higher than 2.2 metres above grade.

    These regulations are outlined in Section 4.1 of By-law 2013-168 and Section 3.21.2 of By-law 2011-115.

  • In Non-Residential Areas (Commercial, Industrial, or Institutional Lots):
    • In the rear yard or an interior side yard, a fence cannot be higher than 3 metres above grade.
    • In the front yard, a fence cannot be higher than 1 metre above grade, unless it is for screening accessory outdoor storage, in which case specific provisions apply (see below).

    These regulations are outlined in Section 5.1 of By-law 2013-168.

  • Specific Standards and Exceptions:
    • Sight Triangles: On corner lots, no fence, building, hedge, shrub, bush, tree, or other plant within the sight triangle can be higher than 1 metre above the grade of either of the abutting streets. This is detailed in Section 3.1 of By-law 2013-168.
    • Fences on Retaining Walls: A fence acting as a guard on top of a retaining wall cannot be more than 1.8 metres above the retaining wall. This is stated in Section 11.1 of By-law 2013-168.
    • Tennis Court Fencing: Tennis court fencing of chain link construction located in a rear yard may be constructed up to a height of 3.6 metres above grade. This is stated in Section 11.2 of By-law 2013-168.
    • Swimming Pool Enclosures: An enclosure (fence, wall, or other structure) around a swimming pool, including its gates, must extend from the ground to a height of not less than 1.5 metres, measured on the outside of the enclosure. This is detailed in Section 8.7 of By-law 2013-168.
    • Accessory Outdoor Storage Screening: If accessory outdoor storage is permitted in a non-residential front yard, the screening (fences, walls, berms, landscaping, and plantings) must be a minimum of 2 metres and a maximum of 3 metres in height, and constructed of permanent opaque materials or vegetation. This is outlined in Section 7.1 of By-law 2013-168.
  • General Provisions:
    • Fences generally cannot be made of sheet metal or corrugated metal panel members, or materials not usually intended for permanent fencing (e.g., tires or corrugated plastic), unless specifically permitted.
    • Barbed wire or razor wire is prohibited, except in Employment Heavy zones where it must be at least 1.8 metres above grade.
    • Electrified fences are prohibited, except for agricultural uses in rural areas for animal containment.
    • Fences must not obstruct the vision of drivers or the visibility of traffic signs, and must be structurally sound and safe.

    These general provisions are found in Section 2 of By-law 2013-168.

  • Privacy Screens:
    • Privacy screens must be located only in a side or rear yard.
    • They must be no longer than 5 metres in any dimension.
    • They can be no more than 2.5 metres in height if constructed at grade, and no more than 1.8 metres in height if constructed on a deck.

    These rules are in Section 6.1 of By-law 2013-168.

For any specific property or unique situation, it is always recommended to consult with the Town's Chief Building Official or Municipal Law Enforcement Officers, as minor or major deviations from the by-law may be permitted under certain conditions (Section 13 of By-law 2013-168).
