    • Side or rear yard: Maximum 2.2 metres high.
  • Non-Residential Areas (Commercial, Industrial, or Institutional):

    • Front yard: Maximum 1 metre high, unless screening outdoor storage (specific rules apply).
  • Specific Situations:
    • Corner Lots (Sight Triangles): Anything within the sight triangle cannot be higher than 1 metre.
    • Fences on Retaining Walls: Maximum 1.8 metres above the retaining wall.
    • Tennis Court Fencing: Chain link fences in a rear yard can be up to 3.6 metres high.
    • Swimming Pool Fences: Must be at least 1.5 metres high.
    • Outdoor Storage Screening (Non-Residential Front Yard): Minimum 2 metres, maximum 3 metres high.

For specific situations or properties, contact the Town's Chief Building Official or Municipal Law Enforcement. They may allow some exceptions to these rules.

original_data.query: Can I put up one of those big inflatable tube guys outside my store for our anniversary sale?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility of deploying an inflatable advertising device, specifically a dynamically moving inflatable tube figure, on commercial property within the Town, for the purpose of promoting an anniversary sale. This inquiry pertains to compliance with all applicable bylaws, including but not limited to zoning ordinances, sign regulations, temporary use permits, visual blight restrictions, and any provisions concerning public safety or nuisance, as currently enacted and recently amended.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Inflatable Signs for Commercial Use

Yes, you may be able to put up an inflatable sign for your anniversary sale, provided your store is located in a commercial, employment, or institutional zone, and you obtain the necessary permit from the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. However, there are specific regulations and restrictions you must adhere to.

Permitted Zones and Permit Requirements

  • Inflatable signs are permitted on properties located in commercial, employment, or institutional zones.
  • A valid sign permit from the Town is required before erecting an inflatable sign.
  • A permit for an inflatable sign is issued for a period not exceeding 30 days.
  • A maximum of two (2) permits may be issued for the same owner, tenant, or occupant at the same location in any calendar year. These permits may be issued for consecutive periods of time.
  • If your premises are occupied by more than one owner or tenant, only one permit will be issued for the same period of time.

Application Requirements for a Sign Permit

To apply for a permit for an inflatable sign, you will need to provide the Clerk or their designate with the following, as outlined in By-law 2016-165 Section 11:

  • One completed copy of the permit application form.
  • A diagram showing the street lines and boundaries of your property, and the proposed location of the inflatable sign in relation to other signs and structures on the property. This diagram may need to be certified by a registered Ontario Land Surveyor if required by the Clerk.
  • A letter of consent from the property owner or property manager/agent authorizing you to erect the sign in compliance with municipal by-laws.

Location and Placement Restrictions

It is crucial to note the following restrictions regarding the placement of inflatable signs, as detailed in By-law 2016-165 Section 8 and By-law 2016-012 Schedule "A":

  • Inflatable signs are NOT permitted in Downtown Stouffville.
  • Power cords and/or supporting devices for inflatable signs shall not be placed on or over parking areas or pedestrian areas.
  • Inflatable signs shall not be placed on a parking space, aisle, or pedestrian areas.
  • The sign must comply with all relevant location and height restrictions provided in the by-law.

Maintenance and Removal

Upon the expiry of a permit for an inflatable sign, the sign must be immediately removed from the premises. All signs must be maintained in a proper state of repair so they do not become unsafe or unsightly, as per By-law 2016-012 Section 11.1.

For specific details regarding your property's zoning and to apply for a permit, please contact the Town's Development Services department.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Inflatable Signs for Commercial Use

You may be able to put up an inflatable sign for your anniversary sale if your store is in a commercial, employment, or institutional zone, and you get a permit from the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. Here are the rules:

Permitted Zones and Permit Requirements

  • Inflatable signs are allowed in commercial, employment, or institutional zones.
  • You must have a sign permit from the Town.
  • Permits last for a maximum of 30 days.
  • You can get up to two (2) permits per year for the same location, and they can be for back-to-back periods.
  • If multiple businesses share a location, only one permit will be issued at a time.

Application Requirements for a Sign Permit

To apply for a permit, you need to provide:

  • A completed permit application form.
  • A diagram showing your property lines, boundaries, and where the sign will be located in relation to other signs and structures.
  • A letter from the property owner or manager allowing you to put up the sign.

Location and Placement Restrictions

Keep these restrictions in mind:

  • Inflatable signs are NOT allowed in Downtown Stouffville.
  • Power cords and supports cannot be on or over parking or pedestrian areas.
  • Inflatable signs cannot be placed in parking spaces, aisles, or pedestrian areas.
  • The sign must follow all location and height rules.

Maintenance and Removal

When the permit expires, you must remove the sign right away. Keep the sign in good repair so it doesn't become unsafe or look bad.

Contact the Town's Development Services department to check your property's zoning and apply for a permit.

Inflatable Signs for Commercial Properties

Permit Requirements and Conditions

  • The permit will be issued for a period not exceeding 30 days.

Downtown Stouffville Restriction

Please note that inflatable signs are not permitted in the Downtown Stouffville Special Sign District, as indicated in Schedule "A" of both By-law 2016-165 and By-law 2016-012.

Application Process for a Sign Permit

To apply for a permit for an inflatable sign, you will need to provide the following to the Clerk or designate, as per By-law 2016-165:

  • One completed copy of the prescribed permit application form.

  • A letter of consent from the owner of the property or the property manager/agent, authorizing you or your tenant to erect the inflatable sign(s) in compliance with municipal by-laws.

Fees and Penalties

Municipal fees for administration and enforcement activities related to this by-law are determined by the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's current Fees and Charges By-law. Application fees are due upon submission of your application.

Failure to comply with the provisions of the by-law, including erecting a sign without a permit or not maintaining it properly, may result in the sign being removed at your expense without notice. Penalties for contravention can range from a fine of not less than $100 and not more than $50,000 for a first conviction, and higher for subsequent or continuing offences, as per By-law 2016-165.

Important Considerations

To ensure compliance, please confirm your property's zoning and whether it falls within the Downtown Stouffville Special Sign District. You can contact the Town's Planning Department or review the Town's Zoning By-law for this information.

original_data.query: How close to a fire hydrant can I legally park?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissible proximity for vehicle parking relative to a fire hydrant, pursuant to the Town's Traffic and Parking Bylaw, specifically concerning obstructions to emergency services access. Request clarification on any applicable provisions, including minimum clearance requirements, prohibitions, and associated penalties for non-compliance, considering all amendments and enactments within the last five years. Determine if any exemptions or variances exist under current municipal code.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Near a Fire Hydrant

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, you are prohibited from parking a vehicle within three (3) metres of a point on the curb or edge of the roadway nearest to any fire hydrant. This regulation is outlined in Section 6(a)(ii) of By-law 2008-114-PR.

Penalty for Violation

If you park within three metres of a fire hydrant, the set penalty for a first offence is $100. This penalty is specified in Schedule "A" of By-law 2024-039-RE, which establishes the Administrative Monetary Penalty System for violations of designated by-laws.

original_data.query: Can I put up one of those big inflatable tube guys outside my store for our anniversary sale?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility of deploying an inflatable advertising device, specifically a dynamically moving, air-filled tube figure, on commercial property for a temporary promotional event (anniversary sale). This inquiry pertains to compliance with applicable zoning bylaws, sign regulations, and temporary use permits, including restrictions on visual obstructions, public safety, noise levels, and potential nuisances, as currently enforced and recently amended within the Town.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Inflatable Signs for Commercial Use

Yes, you may be able to put up an inflatable sign for your anniversary sale, but there are specific regulations and permit requirements you must follow. Here are the general rules for inflatable signs in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, as outlined in By-law 2016-165 and By-law 2016-012:
  • Permit Required: A valid sign permit must be obtained from the Town before erecting an inflatable sign.
  • Permitted Zones: Inflatable signs are generally permitted on properties in commercial, employment, or institutional zones.
  • Permit Duration: A permit for an inflatable sign is issued for a period not exceeding 30 days.
  • Frequency: Not more than two (2) permits may be issued for the same owner, tenant, or occupant at the same location in any calendar year. These permits may be issued for consecutive periods of time.
  • Placement Restrictions:
    • Power cords and/or supporting devices for inflatable signs shall not be placed on or over parking areas or pedestrian areas.
    • Inflatable signs shall not be placed on a parking space, aisle, or pedestrian areas.
    • Inflatable signs are not considered roof signs.
  • Removal: Upon the expiry of a permit, the inflatable sign must be immediately removed.

original_data.filtered_answer:
Inflatable Signs for Commercial Use

Yes, inflatable signs, such as large inflatable tube figures, are generally permitted for commercial use in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, provided certain conditions are met and a valid permit is obtained. These regulations are outlined in By-law 2016-165 and By-law 2016-012.

Permitted Zones and Permit Requirements

  • Inflatable signs are permitted on properties located in commercial, employment, or institutional zones.
  • A valid sign permit must be obtained from the Town before erecting the sign.
  • A permit for an inflatable sign is issued for a period not exceeding 30 days.
  • A maximum of two permits may be issued for the same owner, tenant, or occupant at the same location within any calendar year. These permits may be issued for consecutive periods.
  • If the premises are occupied by more than one owner or tenant, only one permit will be issued for the same period of time.

Placement Restrictions

When placing an inflatable sign, you must adhere to the following restrictions:

  • Power cords and/or supporting devices for inflatable signs shall not be placed on or over parking areas or pedestrian areas.
  • Inflatable signs shall not be placed on a parking space, aisle, or pedestrian areas.
  • Upon the expiry of a permit for an inflatable sign, the sign must be immediately removed.
  • Inflatable signs are not permitted in Downtown Stouffville, as specified in Schedule "A" of By-law 2016-165 and By-law 2016-012. If your store is located in this special sign district, you would not be able to use an inflatable sign.

Application for a Sign Permit

To apply for a permit for an inflatable sign, you will need to provide the following to the Clerk or designate:

  • One completed copy of the permit application form as prescribed by the Clerk or designate.
  • A diagram showing the street lines and boundaries of your property, the proposed location of the inflatable sign, and its relation to other signs and structures on the property. The Clerk or designate may require this diagram and information to be certified by a registered Ontario Land Surveyor.
  • A letter of consent from the owner of the property or the property manager/agent, authorizing you or your tenant to erect the inflatable sign(s) in compliance with municipal by-laws.

Fees and Enforcement

Municipal fees for administration and enforcement activities related to this by-law are set out in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's current Fees and Charges By-law. Application fees are due upon submission of an application. If an inflatable sign is erected or displayed in contravention of the by-law, it may be removed by the Town without notice, at the expense of the sign owner. Penalties for contraventions can include fines.

For specific details regarding your location and to apply for a permit, please contact the Town directly.

original_data.query: are town parks off leash for dogs?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the current regulations pertaining to the presence and control of canines within municipal parklands. original_data.filtered_answer:
Dogs in Town Parks

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, dogs are generally required to be on a leash when in town parks. According to By-law 2020-087, the Parks By-Law, Section 8.1(a) states that no person, as owner or person having control of any dog, shall "Allow it to run at large" while in any park.

The term "Run at Large" or "Running at Large" is defined in By-law 2019-047, the Animal Services By-Law, Section 1.34, as "any Domestic Animal found in any place other than the Premises of the Owner and not controlled by a Leash in the hand of the Owner." This means that for a dog not to be considered "running at large," it must be controlled by a leash held by its owner.

Based on the provided by-laws, there is no information indicating designated off-leash areas within Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville parks. Therefore, dogs must be kept on a leash in all town parks.

original_data.query: On Hoover Park, are we allowed to park car outside school to drop kids?

original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Regulations on Hoover Park Drive for Dropping Off Children

Parking and stopping regulations on Hoover Park Drive in Whitchurch-Stouffville are governed by various by-laws, primarily By-law 2008-114 and its amendments. The ability to park your car to drop off children depends on the specific location on Hoover Park Drive and the time of day.

General Parking and Stopping Rules (from By-law 2008-114)

  • Three-Hour Parking Limit: Unless otherwise specified in Schedule III (which does not include Hoover Park Drive), no person shall park any vehicle on any highway for a period longer than three (3) hours.
  • Interference with Traffic: Parking is prohibited if it interferes with the movement of traffic, obstructs a crosswalk, or obstructs a sidewalk.
  • Boulevards: Parking on a boulevard is generally prohibited, except where the vehicle is parking on a designated access to private property.
  • Double Parking: Stopping on the roadway side of any stopped or parked vehicle is prohibited.
  • Winter Parking Restrictions: From December 1st to March 31st of the following year, parking is prohibited on any highway under the Town's jurisdiction between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Hoover Park Drive is not listed as an exception to this rule.

Specific Parking and Stopping Restrictions on Hoover Park Drive

The following specific restrictions apply to various sections of Hoover Park Drive:

  • No Parking Anytime:
    • On the south side, from the Sandiford Drive intersection to 50 meters east of it, parking is prohibited at any time. (By-law 2018-066)
    • On both sides, from Lucida Court to Edgehill Avenue/Juglans Crescent, parking is prohibited at any time. (By-law 2024-016)
    • On the north side, from the railway tracks easterly 200 metres, parking is prohibited at any time. (By-law 2008-114)
    • On the south side, from the railway tracks westerly 200 metres, parking is prohibited at any time. (By-law 2008-114)
  • Time-Specific No Parking:
    • On the north and south sides, from Yakefarm Blvd. to 135 meters west, parking is prohibited Monday to Friday between 8:00 a.m. - 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. These times often coincide with school drop-off and pick-up periods. (By-law 2015-089)
  • No Stopping Anytime:
    • On both sides, east of Highway 48 for a distance of 480 metres, stopping is prohibited at any time. (By-law 2008-114)

To determine if you are allowed to park your car to drop off children, you must consider the exact location on Hoover Park Drive and the time of day, as specific restrictions apply to different sections of the road. Always observe posted signs, as they indicate the applicable regulations for that specific area.

original_data.query: what happens if my car breaks down in main street

original_data.filtered_answer:
Vehicle Breakdown on Main Street

If your vehicle breaks down on Main Street and is considered to be parked or standing in contravention of a municipal by-law, certain actions may be taken. According to By-law 2023-134, which references the Highway Traffic Act, a police officer, police cadet, municipal law enforcement officer, or an appointed officer may:

  • Cause the vehicle to be moved or taken to and placed or stored in a suitable place.
  • Issue a Parking Infraction Notice.

All costs and charges for the removal, care, and storage of the vehicle, if any, are a lien upon the vehicle. These costs may be enforced in the manner provided by the Repair and Storage Liens Act, as also outlined in By-law 2023-134.

Parking regulations, including "no parking" zones on Main Street, are established and amended by various by-laws, such as By-law 2016-096 and By-law 2020-055, which modify the general parking by-law By-law 2008-114-PR.

Vehicle Breakdown on Main Street

If your vehicle breaks down on Main Street and blocks traffic, the Town may have it moved and issue a parking ticket.

You will be responsible for all towing and storage costs.

Parking rules on Main Street are subject to change.

original_data.query: what happens if my car breaks down in main street

original_data.filtered_answer:
Vehicle Breakdown on Main Street

If your car breaks down on Main Street, please be aware of the following regulations from the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville by-laws:

  • While By-law 2008-114 generally prohibits repairing a vehicle on a highway, an exception is made for repairs necessitated by an emergency (Section 6(a)(viii)).
  • However, you are prohibited from parking any vehicle on a highway in such a position as to interfere with the movement of traffic (Section 6(a)(xiii) of By-law 2008-114). A broken-down vehicle may likely fall under this prohibition.
  • Additionally, no person shall park or leave any vehicle upon any portion of an untravelled highway for a period exceeding seventy-two (72) hours (Section 19(a) of By-law 2008-114).

Vehicle Removal and Associated Costs

If your vehicle is found to be parked, stopped, or left standing in contravention of the by-law (e.g., obstructing traffic, or left for an extended period), a Police Officer or Municipal Law Enforcement Officer may take action:

  • They may cause your vehicle to be moved and stored in a suitable place (Section 21(d) of By-law 2008-114).
  • All costs and charges for the removal, care, and storage of the vehicle, if any, are a lien upon the vehicle. This lien may be enforced in the manner provided by the Repair and Storage Liens Act (Section 21(d) of By-law 2008-114).
  • If a vehicle is discovered apparently abandoned on or near a highway, it may also be taken into custody and stored, with all associated costs being a lien upon the vehicle (Section 21(e) of By-law 2008-114).

Please note that By-law 2023-134 also outlines similar provisions for temporary parking restrictions during specific events, allowing for vehicles parked in contravention to be ticketed or moved, with costs recoverable via a lien.

original_data.query: What are the rules about putting garbage out for collection?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding regulations governing solid waste collection and disposal within the Town's jurisdiction. Specifically, what are the requirements, obligations, and prohibitions pertaining to the placement of refuse, recyclables, and organic waste for municipal collection services, including permissible container types, set-out times, location restrictions, and compliance standards under applicable Waste Management Bylaws, Public Health Ordinances, and Property Standards regulations, considering the most recently enacted amendments and effective dates.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Garbage Collection Rules in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville has specific rules for putting out garbage for collection, as outlined in By-law 2018-035.

Collection Limits

  • For residential premises, including registered Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs), you may set out a maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags per dwelling unit per collection day. The total maximum number of containers/bags, whether tagged or untagged, shall not exceed six (6) per dwelling unit (Section 5.1, 5.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • For commercial or institutional premises, you may set out a maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags per collection day. The total maximum number of containers/bags, whether tagged or untagged, shall not exceed six (6) (Section 5.2 of By-law 2018-035).
  • For commercial or institutional premises within the Downtown Stouffville Collection Area, you may set out a maximum of six (6) untagged garbage containers/bags per collection day (Section 5.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • For bulk items, a maximum of four (4) items may be set out for collection per property per collection day (Section 5.5 of By-law 2018-035).
  • There is no limit to the quantity of blue box recyclables, source separated organics (SSO), or yard waste that may be set out for collection from a residential property (Section 5.11 of By-law 2018-035).

Excess Garbage and Tags

  • If you have more garbage containers/bags than the untagged limit, you must affix pay-for-service tags to the additional items for them to be collected (Section 5.1, 5.2, 5.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Tags can be purchased from the Town or its designates at the fee set out in the Town's Fees and Charges By-law (Section 8.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • The tag must be clearly visible upon removal of the container's lid or affixed to the bag (Section 8.1, 8.2 of By-law 2018-035).
  • If the Town is required to collect untagged waste, the property owner will be charged an applicable fee (Section 8.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Any refuse in excess of the limits must be disposed of at the owner's expense via a private service provider operating under a Certificate of Approval (Section 5.6 of By-law 2018-035).

Set-Out Times and Placement

  • Approved containers and bundles shall not be placed at the curb or pavement edge before 5:00 p.m. on the day immediately preceding the day designated for collection (Section 4.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Approved receptacles and bundles must be placed at the curb or pavement edge no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection (Section 4.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • All emptied receptacles and uncollected refuse must be removed from the curb or pavement edge before 8:00 p.m. on the day of collection (Section 4.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Containers and bundles should be placed as close as possible to the curb or pavement edge of the road, without obstructing vehicular or pedestrian traffic or street maintenance, and should not be placed on top of snow banks (Section 4.6 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Approved containers must be placed at the edge of the traveled portion of the road, or in a location accessible to municipal collection vehicles as pre-determined and approved by the Town. They shall not be placed on the road for collection (Section 4.9 of By-law 2018-035).

Container Specifications

  • Garbage Containers:
    • Reusable receptacles must be plastic, waterproof, durable, non-absorbent, with a close-fitting cover and two open rigid handles. They shall not exceed 50 cm (20 in) in diameter or 90 cm (36 inches) in height or 125 litres (4.4 cu ft) in capacity. The total weight with contents shall not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.1.1 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Non-reusable receptacles (plastic bags) must be waterproof, designed for containing refuse, and sealed to prevent spillage. Maximum size is 66 cm x 92 cm (26"x36") or 76 litres (20 gallons). The total weight when full shall not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.1.2 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Garbage must be placed out for collection in securely covered containers or bags (Section 6.8 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Blue Box Recyclables:
    • Must be contained in municipally supplied Blue Bins or equivalent open-topped plastic containers with a grip edge, clearly identifiable as containing recyclables. They must be capable of containing all materials without spillage and not exceed 53 cm (21 inches) in height, 40 cm (16 inches) in width, 48 cm (19 inches) in length, or 83 litres (22 gallons) (Section 7.2.1 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Magazines, newspapers, cardboard, boxboard, and other waste paper may be tied securely in bundles or placed in cardboard boxes for overflow, not larger than 90 cm x 90 cm x 20 cm (36" x 36" x 8") (Section 7.2.2 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Plastic or compostable bags are prohibited for use as a receptacle for blue box material (Section 7.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Source Separated Organics (SSO):
    • Must be contained within a certified compostable bag that has been deposited within a green bin supplied by the Municipality. The total weight of the green bin when full shall not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Yard Waste:
    • Must be contained in a returnable plastic, waterproof, durable, non-absorbent open-top container with two open rigid handles and a "Yard Waste" sticker affixed to it. The container's diameter shall not exceed 50 cm (20 in) or a height of 90 cm (36 in). The total weight shall not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs). Blue or green bins are not acceptable yard waste containers (Section 7.5.1 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Alternatively, yard waste can be in a Kraft paper bag designed for yard waste, with a weight not exceeding 22 kg (50 lbs) when full (Section 7.5.2 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Branches, twigs, and cuttings may be set out in securely tied bundles not exceeding 1.2 meters (4 feet) in length, 60 cm (24 inches) in diameter, or 10 cm (4 inches) in diameter per branch, and not weighing more than 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.5.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Any receptacle placed out for collection which is broken or which breaks when lifted will not be collected. Materials set out in cardboard boxes will not be collected (Section 7.6 of By-law 2018-035).

Prohibited Materials and General Restrictions

  • You shall not set out a receptacle for collection that contains liquids, warm ashes, electronics, or hazardous waste (Section 4.8 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Prohibited materials also include, but are not limited to, items listed as "Non-Collectible Waste" in Schedule 'A' of By-law 2018-035, such as:
    • Household Hazardous Waste (e.g., batteries, paints, fuels, corrosive waste, propane tanks, syringes, etc.)
    • Certain bulk items (e.g., carpets loose or over 22kg, bulk items greater than 100 lbs)
    • Certain metal items (e.g., car and car parts, pieces of metal weighing more than 100 lbs)
    • Certain yard waste (e.g., brush larger than 10cm in diameter or bundles over 22kg, earth and sod, grass clippings, tree stumps)
    • Certain plastics (e.g., plastic bags, plastic film and wrap, Styrofoam drinking cups, toys)
    • Construction material, tires and rims, explosives, ammunition, and glass plate/windows.
  • Schedule 'B' of By-law 2018-035 lists items not accepted in Source Separated Organics (SSO), including artificial flowers/plants, ashes, baby wipes, candles, carpet & rugs, cigarette butts, clothing/leather/textiles, plastic wraps & baggies, and Styrofoam.
  • Schedule 'C' of By-law 2018-035 lists "Electronic Waste" as non-collectible items at the curb, such as computers, televisions, printers, and microwaves. These items are accepted for recycling at drop-off locations only.
  • No person shall set out refuse for collection in any manner that may constitute a nuisance, hazard, or threat to public health and safety (Section 6.1 of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall scavenge from, pick over, interfere with, disturb, remove, or scatter any refuse set out for collection (Section 6.6 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Metal appliances must have any door, lid, or cover removed that cannot be easily opened from the inside to prevent a person from being trapped (Section 6.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • If refuse is set out not in accordance with the by-law, the Contractor may refuse to collect it, and it is the responsibility of the person who set it out to comply (Section 6.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • The Town is not responsible for non-approved or broken containers not being collected or returned (Section 6.5 of By-law 2018-035).
  • If garbage, recyclables, yard waste, or SSO is tipped, blown, or knocked over prior to collection, the person who set it out is responsible for cleaning it up. If the Town is required to clean it, a fee will be charged (Section 8.5 of By-law 2018-035).

For comprehensive details, please refer to By-law 2018-035.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Garbage Collection Rules in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Here's what you need to know about garbage collection in Whitchurch-Stouffville, based on By-law 2018-035:

Collection Limits

  • Residential: Max 3 untagged bags/containers. Total max 6 bags/containers (tagged or untagged). This applies to homes and registered Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs).
  • Commercial/Institutional: Max 3 untagged bags/containers. Total max 6 bags/containers (tagged or untagged).
  • Downtown Stouffville (Commercial/Institutional): Max 6 untagged bags/containers.
  • Bulk Items: Max 4 items per property.
  • Recyclables, Organics, Yard Waste: No quantity limits.

Excess Garbage and Tags

  • Use garbage tags for extra bags/containers.
  • Buy tags from the Town.
  • Make sure tags are visible.
  • Fees apply if the Town collects untagged waste.
  • Too much garbage? Hire a private waste service.

Set-Out Times and Placement

  • Don't put garbage out before 5:00 p.m. the day before collection.
  • Garbage must be out by 7:00 a.m. on collection day.
  • Remove empty containers/uncollected garbage by 8:00 p.m. on collection day.
  • Place containers near the curb, without blocking traffic or snow removal.
  • Keep containers off the road.

Container Specifications

  • Garbage Containers:
    • Reusable: Plastic, waterproof, durable, with a lid and handles. Max 50 cm diameter, 90 cm height, 125 litres capacity, 22 kg weight.
    • Non-Reusable (bags): Waterproof, sealed. Max 66 cm x 92 cm or 76 litres, 22 kg weight.
    • Garbage must be in covered containers or bags.
  • Blue Box Recyclables:
    • Use Blue Bins or similar containers. Max 53 cm height, 40 cm width, 48 cm length, 83 litres.
    • Bundle extra paper/cardboard (max 90 cm x 90 cm x 20 cm).
    • No plastic bags in blue bins.
  • Source Separated Organics (SSO):
    • Use certified compostable bags inside a green bin. Max 22 kg weight.
  • Yard Waste:
    • Use a returnable container with "Yard Waste" sticker (max 50 cm diameter, 90 cm height, 22 kg weight). No blue or green bins.
    • Or use Kraft paper yard waste bags (max 22 kg weight).
    • Bundle branches (max 1.2 meters length, 60 cm diameter, 10 cm branch diameter, 22 kg weight).
  • Broken containers won't be collected. Cardboard boxes won't be collected.

Prohibited Materials and General Restrictions

  • Don't put out liquids, hot ashes, electronics, or hazardous waste.
  • Other prohibited materials include:
    • Household Hazardous Waste
    • Certain bulk items
    • Certain metal items
    • Certain yard waste
    • Certain plastics
    • Construction material, tires, explosives, and glass.
  • Don't put unapproved items in organics, like artificial plants, ashes, baby wipes, etc.
  • Electronics are not collected at the curb. Take them to drop-off locations.
  • Don't create a mess or hazard.
  • Don't scavenge from other people's garbage.
  • Remove doors from appliances.
  • If you break the rules, your garbage may not be collected.

original_data.query: What are the rules about putting garbage out for collection?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding regulations governing the placement of refuse and recyclable materials for municipal waste collection services. Specifically, what are the prescribed requirements, permissions, and prohibitions concerning container types, set-out times, collection locations, and acceptable waste composition, as stipulated under the Town's Waste Management Bylaw, Public Health Bylaw, and any applicable Property Standards Bylaws, including amendments and updates enacted within the last five years, to ensure compliance with current waste disposal ordinances?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Garbage Collection Rules in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The rules for putting out garbage for collection in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville are primarily governed by By-law 2018-035, with additional relevant provisions in By-law 2016-068 regarding general property maintenance and waste storage. Here are the key regulations:

Collection Limits for Garbage

  • Residential Premises: A maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags per dwelling unit are permitted for collection on any given day. The total maximum number of containers/bags, including tagged ones, shall not exceed six (6) per dwelling unit (Section 5.1 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Commercial/Institutional Premises: A maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags are allowed per collection day. The total maximum number of containers/bags, including tagged ones, shall not exceed six (6) (Section 5.2 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Downtown Stouffville Collection Area (Commercial/Institutional): A maximum of six (6) untagged garbage containers/bags are permitted per collection day (Section 5.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Registered Accessory Dwelling Units (ADU): A maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags are allowed per collection day. The total maximum number of containers/bags, including tagged ones, shall not exceed six (6) (Section 5.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Bulk Items: A maximum of four (4) bulk items may be set out for collection per property on any collection day (Section 5.5 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Excess Waste: For any refuse exceeding these limits, property owners must dispose of it at their own expense by conveying it to a waste receiving or disposal facility by a private service provider operating under a Certificate of Approval (Section 5.6 of By-law 2018-035).

Garbage Tags for Additional Waste

  • If you have more than the allowed untagged containers/bags, you must affix a special tag (sticker) to each additional container/bag for collection (Sections 5.1, 5.2, 5.4, 8.1, 8.2 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Tags may be purchased from the Town or its designates at the applicable fee set out in the Town's Fees and Charges By-law (Section 8.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • The tag must be clearly visible upon removal of the container's lid or affixed to the bag (Sections 8.1, 8.2 of By-law 2018-035).

Set-Out Times and Placement

  • Approved containers and bundles shall not be placed at the curb or pavement edge before 5:00 p.m. on the day immediately preceding the day designated for collection (Section 4.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • They must be placed at the curb or pavement edge no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection (Section 4.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • All emptied receptacles and uncollected refuse must be removed from the curb or pavement edge before 8:00 p.m. on the day of collection (Section 4.7 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Containers should be placed as close as possible to the curb or pavement edge, without obstructing vehicular or pedestrian traffic or street maintenance, and shall not be placed on top of snow banks (Section 4.6 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Approved containers must be placed at the edge of the traveled portion of the road, or in a location accessible to municipal collection vehicles as pre-determined and approved by the Town. They shall not be placed on the road for collection (Section 4.9 of By-law 2018-035).

Container Specifications for Garbage

  • Garbage must be contained in one of the following approved receptacles (Section 7.1 of By-law 2018-035):
    • Reusable Receptacle (Garbage Can): Must be plastic, waterproof, durable, non-absorbent, with a close-fitting cover and two open rigid handles. It shall not exceed 50 cm (20 in) in diameter or 90 cm (36 inches) in height or 125 litres (4.4 cu ft.) in capacity. The diameter at the top must be larger than the bottom. The total weight with contents shall not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.1.1 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Non-Reusable Receptacle (Garbage Bag): Must be a waterproof plastic bag designed and sold for containing refuse and sealed to prevent spillage. Maximum size is 66 cm x 92 cm (26"x36") or 76 litres (20 gallons). The total weight when full shall not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.1.2 of By-law 2018-035).
  • All garbage must be placed out for collection in securely covered containers or bags (Section 6.8 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Household waste must be stored in rigid, watertight containers, which are maintained in good condition without holes or spillage and with secure lids when stored outdoors. Household waste shall not be stored in the front yard of a residential property where the property has a garage, side yard or designated storage facility. Refuse shall be emptied regularly in accordance with the waste collection schedule (Section 3.2 of By-law 2016-068).

Prohibited Materials and Waste Types

  • You shall not set out a receptacle for collection that contains liquids, warm ashes, electronics, or hazardous waste (Section 4.8 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Prohibited items also include those listed as "Non-Collectible Waste" in Schedule 'A' of By-law 2018-035, such as:
    • Household Hazardous Waste (e.g., acute hazardous waste, aerosol containers, batteries, bio-medical waste, engine oil, paints, propane tanks, radioactive waste, syringes, weed killers) (Schedule A, Section 1 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Certain Bulk items (e.g., carpets loose or greater than 1.5 meters in length & over 22kg (50lbs), household bulk items greater than 100 lbs (45kg)) (Schedule A, Section 2 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Certain Metal items (e.g., car and car parts, pieces of metal weighing more than 100 lbs (45kg) or more than 1.2 m in length, propane tanks, helium tanks, fuel containers and gas cylinders, wire, wire mesh and fencing weighing more than 100 lbs or exceeding 1.2m in length/width) (Schedule A, Section 3 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Certain Yard Waste (e.g., brush larger than 10cm (4") in diameter, earth and sod, grass clippings, tree stumps) (Schedule A, Section 4 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Certain Wood items (e.g., skid, wood) (Schedule A, Section 8 of By-law 2018-035).
    • Additional materials (e.g., ammunition, brick, rock, asphalt, construction material, explosives, fibreglass, glass plate and windows, shingles, tires and rims) (Schedule A, Section 9 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Electronic Waste (listed in Schedule 'C' of By-law 2018-035) is non-collectible at the curb and is accepted for recycling at drop-off locations only. This includes items like computers, televisions, printers, cell phones, and microwaves (Section 1.22, Schedule C of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall deposit any refuse on private or public property without the expressed written authorization of the owner (Section 4.2 of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall place any refuse for collection or permit it to remain on lands where it constitutes a nuisance or hazard, emits foul odors, or attracts vermin or insects (Section 4.3 of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall set out prohibited refuse for collection (Section 4.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall set out for collection or convey refuse in any manner that may constitute a nuisance, hazard or threat to public health and safety (Section 6.1 of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall scavenge from, pick over, interfere with, disturb, remove or scatter any refuse set out for collection (Section 6.6 of By-law 2018-035).
  • No person shall set out any metal appliance without first removing any door, lid or cover that cannot be easily opened from the inside, and taking other precautionary measures to prevent a person from being trapped inside (Section 6.7 of By-law 2018-035).

Consequences of Non-Compliance

  • If refuse is not set out in accordance with the by-law, the contractor may refuse to collect it. It then becomes the responsibility of the person who set it out to comply with the by-law (Section 6.4 of By-law 2018-035).
  • If the Town is required to collect waste that was not tagged as required, or if waste is tipped/blown over and not cleaned up, the owner will be charged an applicable fee as set out in the Town's Fees and Charges By-law (Sections 8.4, 8.5 of By-law 2018-035). Unpaid fees may be added to the property tax roll (Section 8.6 of By-law 2018-035).
  • Any person who contravenes any provision of By-law 2018-035 is guilty of an offence and subject to penalties (Section 11.1 of By-law 2018-035):
    • First conviction: Minimum fine of $350.00, maximum $100,000.00.
    • Second or subsequent conviction for the same offence: Minimum fine of $500.00, maximum $100,000.00.
    • Continuing offence (per day): Minimum fine of $500.00, maximum $10,000.00 per day.
    • Multiple offence (per offence): Minimum fine of $500.00, maximum $10,000.00 per offence.
  • The Town can issue orders to discontinue contraventions or work orders to correct them. If the owner fails to comply, the Town can perform the work and recover costs via property taxes (Sections 10.1, 10.2, 10.3 of By-law 2018-035).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Garbage Collection Rules in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Here's what you need to know about garbage collection in Whitchurch-Stouffville:

Collection Limits for Garbage

  • Residential Premises: You can put out up to three (3) garbage containers/bags without tags. You can put out a maximum of six (6) containers/bags total, including those with tags.
  • Commercial/Institutional Premises: You can put out up to three (3) garbage containers/bags without tags. You can put out a maximum of six (6) containers/bags total, including those with tags.
  • Downtown Stouffville Collection Area (Commercial/Institutional): You can put out up to six (6) garbage containers/bags without tags.
  • Registered Accessory Dwelling Units (ADU): You can put out up to three (3) garbage containers/bags without tags. You can put out a maximum of six (6) containers/bags total, including those with tags.
  • Bulk Items: You can put out a maximum of four (4) bulk items per property.
  • Excess Waste: You must dispose of extra garbage yourself at an approved waste facility.

Garbage Tags for Additional Waste

  • If you have more than the allowed number of untagged containers/bags, you must use garbage tags.
  • You can buy tags from the Town.
  • Make sure the tag is clearly visible.

Set-Out Times and Placement

  • Don't put garbage out before 5:00 p.m. the day before collection.
  • Garbage must be out by 7:00 a.m. on collection day.
  • Remove empty containers and any uncollected garbage by 8:00 p.m. on collection day.
  • Place containers near the curb, but not blocking traffic or on snow banks.
  • Containers must be accessible to collection vehicles and not placed on the road.

Container Specifications for Garbage

  • Garbage must be in:
    • Reusable Garbage Can: Plastic, waterproof, with a lid and handles. Max size: 50 cm diameter, 90 cm height, 125 litres. Max weight: 22 kg.
    • Non-Reusable Garbage Bag: Waterproof plastic bag, sealed. Max size: 66 cm x 92 cm or 76 litres. Max weight: 22 kg.
  • All garbage must be in covered containers or bags.
  • Household waste must be stored in good condition and with secure lids. It should not be stored in the front yard if a garage, side yard, or designated storage facility exists.

Prohibited Materials and Waste Types

  • Do not put out liquids, warm ashes, electronics, or hazardous waste.
  • Other prohibited items include certain bulk items, metal items, yard waste, wood items, and construction materials.
  • Electronic waste must be taken to drop-off locations for recycling.
  • Do not put garbage on private or public property without permission.
  • Garbage should not create a nuisance, hazard, or attract pests.
  • Do not scavenge or disturb garbage set out for collection.
  • Remove doors from appliances before disposal.

Consequences of Non-Compliance

  • If you don't follow the rules, your garbage may not be collected.
  • You may be charged a fee if the Town has to deal with improperly tagged waste or waste that has been tipped over and not cleaned up. Unpaid fees may be added to your property tax.
  • Violating these rules can result in fines.
  • The Town can issue orders to correct violations and recover costs through property taxes if you don't comply.

original_data.query: My contractor finished framing, but we decided to change a window location. Do I need to tell the Town?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding compliance with Town bylaws following completion of structural framing and proposed alteration to fenestration location. Specifically, does the relocation of a window after framing necessitates notification to or approval from the Town, considering applicable zoning ordinances, building codes, permit requirements, and any relevant provisions pertaining to property alterations enacted within the past [Number] years?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Building Permit Revisions

Yes, if you wish to change a window location after your building permit has been issued and framing is complete, you are required to inform the Town.

According to Section 17(1) of By-law 2012-004, if an owner wishes to make any change to the plans, specifications, documents, or other information on the basis of which the permit was issued, the owner must file a new application for a revision to the issued permit. This application should describe the material changes.

Additionally, Section 17(1) of By-law 2012-004 states that a fee, as set out in the most recent corporate "Fees and Charges By-law," will be required for such revisions. Section 17(3) of By-law 2012-004 also notes that any revision made after the initial submission for review will be deemed an incomplete permit, and the Town will not be bound by provincial turnaround times for the application. Plan re-examination fees will also apply.

The Chief Building Official has the discretion to determine the appropriate process for amending the permit documents.
original_data.laymans_answer:

Any revision after the initial submission means the Town is not bound by provincial turnaround times for the application.

The Chief Building Official will determine the process for amending the permit documents.

original_data.query: My contractor finished framing, but we decided to change a window location. Do I need to tell the Town?

Specifically, does the relocation of a window after initial framing necessitates notification to, or approval from, the Town under applicable zoning ordinances, building codes, or permit regulations currently in effect, considering potential impacts on property standards, setback requirements, or previously approved development plans?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Building Permit Revisions for Window Location Changes

Yes, if you have an issued building permit and decide to change a window location after framing has been completed, you generally need to notify the Town and apply for a revision to your permit.

According to By-law 2012-004, Section 17(1), if an owner wishes to make any change to the plans, specifications, documents, or other information on the basis of which a permit was issued, they are required to:

  • File a new application for a revision to the issued permit, describing the material changes.
  • Alternatively, they may be permitted to amend the existing permit documents, as deemed appropriate.
  • A fee, as set out in the most current corporate "Fees and Charges By-law," will be applicable for such revisions.

It is important to note that any revision made to an application after it has been initially submitted for review may be deemed an incomplete permit, and the Town may not be bound by the standard turnaround times for processing (Section 17(3) of By-law 2012-004).

While By-law 2012-004, Section 7(1)(viii) lists "Residential window and door replacement within a single, semi-detached or townhome, provided that the size is not increased" as minor construction not requiring a permit, changing the *location* of a window typically involves structural alterations or changes to egress/fire safety, which would necessitate a permit revision to ensure compliance with the Building Code and other applicable laws.

The Chief Building Official has the final authority to determine the specific plans, specifications, documents, and other information required for any submission, including revisions, to ensure compliance with the Building Code, the Act, and other Applicable Law (Section 8(7) of By-law 2012-004).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Building Permit Revisions for Window Location Changes

Yes, if you have a building permit and want to change a window location after framing, you generally need to notify the Town and apply for a permit revision.

If you want to change any plans after a permit is issued, you must:

  • File a new application for a permit revision describing the changes.
  • Or, you may amend the existing permit documents, if permitted.
  • A fee will apply for revisions.

Any revision after the initial submission may result in processing delays.

While replacing windows without increasing their size doesn't typically require a permit, changing a window's *location* usually does, due to potential structural or safety implications. A permit revision ensures compliance with building codes.

The Chief Building Official determines what information is needed for revisions to ensure compliance.

original_data.query: Can I record a Town Council meeting?
original_data.transformed_query: Formal Inquiry: Regarding the permissibility of audio and video recording of proceedings of the Town Council, what are the current regulations, as of [Current Date], governing such activities? Specifically, do any bylaws pertaining to public access, meeting procedures, privacy, or information management either permit or prohibit the recording, broadcasting, or dissemination of Town Council meetings, considering relevant provisions related to freedom of information and protection of privacy?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Recording Town Council Meetings

Yes, you can record Town Council meetings in Whitchurch-Stouffville, subject to certain conditions outlined in the Town's Procedural By-law.

  • Meetings may be audio and/or visually recorded, broadcasted, and/or live-streamed publicly by the Town, with the exception of proceedings closed to the public.
  • Attendees using their own recording, broadcasting, and/or streaming devices are encouraged to inform the Clerk or ensure other attendees at the meetings are notified through the Chair.

This information is based on Section 4.8 of By-law 2024-033, which is the current Procedural By-law governing Council meetings.

  • If you plan to record, broadcast, or stream a meeting yourself, it's recommended that you inform the Clerk or notify other attendees through the Chair.

original_data.query: are our town parks considered off leash areas for dogs?
original_data.transformed_query: "Inquire as to the current regulations pertaining to the presence and control of canines within municipal parklands and recreational areas of the Town. Specifically, determine if any designated off-leash areas exist pursuant to the Animal Control Bylaw, Property Standards Bylaw, or Parks and Recreation Bylaw, and ascertain any prohibitions or permissions regarding unrestrained dogs, considering potential implications for public health, safety, and waste management ordinances, as currently enacted and amended."
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Leash Regulations in Town Parks

No, town parks in Whitchurch-Stouffville are not considered off-leash areas for dogs. According to By-law 2020-087, which regulates the use of Parks, Trails, Park Buildings, and Open Spaces, no person shall allow a dog to "run at large" in any park.

The term "run at large" is defined in By-law 2019-047 (Animal Services By-Law) as any Domestic Animal found in any place other than the Premises of the Owner and not controlled by a Leash in the hand of the Owner. A "Leash" is defined as a restraining device attached to the collar or harness worn by a Domestic Animal not more than 2 meters in length and of sufficient strength to restrain the Domestic Animal.

Therefore, dogs are required to be on a leash and under the control of their owner when in town parks.
original_data.laymans_answer: No, dogs are not allowed to run off-leash in Whitchurch-Stouffville town parks. Dogs must be controlled by a leash that is no more than 2 meters long.

original_data.query: What businesses am I allowed to perform from my home?
original_data.transformed_query: "Pursuant to current Town bylaws and zoning ordinances, specifically concerning permitted uses within residential zones, what are the permissible home-based businesses, including any applicable restrictions or conditions regarding commercial activities, signage, noise levels, waste disposal, traffic generation, client visitation, employee limitations, and compliance with public health, safety, and animal control regulations, considering all amendments enacted within the last five years?"
original_data.filtered_answer:
Home Occupations

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, home occupations are permitted in various dwelling types and accessory buildings, provided they comply with the provisions of the relevant zone. According to By-law 2013-116, home occupations are allowed in:

  • Single detached dwellings and/or accessory buildings in all Rural and Environmental Zones.
  • Single detached dwellings, semi-detached dwellings, duplex dwellings, townhouse dwellings, street townhouse dwellings, stacked townhouse dwellings, back-to-back townhouse dwellings, and/or accessory buildings in all Traditional Residential Zones and all New Residential Zones.

General conditions for home occupations, as outlined in By-law 2009-098, By-law 2009-099, and By-law 2013-116, include:

  • A maximum of one person who is not a resident of the dwelling unit may be engaged in the home occupation.
  • No more than 25% of the gross floor area of the dwelling unit and/or accessory building may be used for home occupation uses, to a maximum of 90 square metres.
  • The home occupation must be clearly secondary to the use of the dwelling unit and carried out by a resident or residents of the dwelling unit.
  • There shall be no outdoor storage or display or signage associated with the home occupation use.
  • The home occupation shall not involve any changes to the outward appearance of the building, except for modifications required to accommodate barrier-free access.
  • The dwelling unit must be the principal residence, as defined in the Income Tax Act, of the person or persons engaged in the home occupation use.
  • No retail sales are permitted as part of a home occupation use other than the sale of what is produced or repaired on site.
  • The home occupation shall not generate adverse effects such as electrical interference, excessive traffic, parking, noise, or odour.

The following occupations or businesses are generally excluded as home occupations, as per By-law 2013-116:

  • Kennels
  • Animal services
  • Automotive sales and service uses
  • Motor vehicle body repair shop
  • Paint shops
  • Medical offices
  • Restaurants
  • Food preparation services
  • Taxi services
  • Bed and breakfast establishments
  • Distribution centres

Home Industries

Home industry uses are permitted in single detached dwellings in the Rural (RU) Zone, provided they comply with all provisions of that zone. As per By-law 2009-098 and By-law 2009-099, the conditions for home industries include:

  • A maximum of one person who is not a resident of the dwelling unit may be engaged in the home industry use.
  • The home industry use may be located in part of a single detached dwelling unit or in any accessory building or structure, only on lots 5.0 hectares and greater in size.
  • No more than 25% of the gross floor area of the dwelling unit shall be used for any business, including the home industry, and the maximum gross floor area used for the home industry use shall be 140 square metres.
  • There shall be no outdoor storage or display or signage associated with the home industry use.
  • A maximum of one home industry use is permitted on each lot.
  • The home industry shall not involve any changes to the outward appearance of the building, except for modifications required to accommodate barrier-free access.
  • The single detached dwelling unit must be the principal residence, as defined in the Income Tax Act, of the person or persons engaged in the home industry use.
  • No retail sales are permitted as part of a home industry use other than the sale of what is produced or repaired on site.
  • The home industry shall not generate adverse effects such as electrical interference, excessive traffic, parking, noise, or odour.

Examples of permitted home industries include, but are not limited to, carpentry shops, metal working shops, welding shops, electrical shops, small equipment repair shops, or blacksmithing (primarily for the farming community), and gardening. Home industries generally do not include uses such as motor vehicle repair or paint shops or furniture stripping, as stated in By-law 2009-098 and By-law 2009-099.

Specific Exceptions and Permitted Uses

There are specific by-laws that allow certain businesses as home occupations under particular conditions:

  • For the property at 14811 Ninth Line, By-law 1992-026 permits the manufacture and sale of handmade chocolates and associated products as a Home Occupation. Conditions include:
    • Only residents of the building and one other non-resident person are employed.
    • Activity is restricted to the interior of the building.
    • No outdoor storage of goods, material, or equipment.
    • No disturbance to the neighbourhood by dust, noise, smell, smoke, or traffic.
    • No mechanical equipment except for domestic purposes and chocolate manufacturing.
    • Sales limited to articles produced within the building.
    • No more than one business vehicle parked on premises, without advertising.
    • Maximum Gross Floor Area for the Home Occupation is 55 square metres.
  • For the property at 504 Main Street East, Lot 35, Concession 10, By-law 1986-151 allows for a retail craft supply business. Conditions include:
    • The dwelling is occupied as a residence by the user.
    • Not more than one assistant who is not a resident in the dwelling.
    • Not more than 25% of the total floor area is devoted to the business.
    • One off-street parking space is provided for every 9.3 square metres of floor space, suitably screened from adjacent properties.
    • The residential character of the dwelling is not changed.
  • For Mixed-Use Street Townhouses at 11731 Tenth Line, By-law 2020-100 permits the following uses on the ground floor with direct frontage on Tenth Line:
    • Convenience Store
    • Private Home Day Care
    • Home Occupation
    • Office
    • Personal Service Establishment
    • Retail Store
    • Studio

Please note that these are general guidelines, and specific zoning regulations for your property should be confirmed to ensure compliance. You can refer to the cited by-law numbers for full details.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Home Occupations

You can run a business from your home if it meets certain rules. Home occupations are allowed in single-family homes in Rural and Environmental Zones. They are also allowed in most types of homes (single-family, semi-detached, townhouses, etc.) in Traditional and New Residential Zones.

The rules include:

  • Only one non-resident employee is allowed.
  • Business use is limited to 25% of your home's floor area, up to 90 square metres.
  • The business must be secondary to your home's residential use and run by a resident.
  • No outdoor storage, displays, or signs are permitted.
  • The business cannot change the building's outward appearance (except for accessibility modifications).
  • Your home must be your primary residence.
  • Retail sales are limited to what you produce or repair on-site.
  • The business cannot create electrical interference, excessive traffic, parking, noise, or odors.

Some businesses are not allowed as home occupations, including kennels, animal services, auto sales/service, vehicle repair shops, paint shops, medical offices, restaurants, food preparation services, taxi services, bed and breakfasts, and distribution centers.

Home Industries

Home industry uses are allowed only in single-family homes in the Rural (RU) Zone.

The rules include:

  • Only one non-resident employee is allowed.
  • The business can be in your home or an accessory building, but only on lots 5.0 hectares and larger.
  • Business use is limited to 25% of your home's floor area, up to 140 square metres.
  • No outdoor storage, displays, or signs are permitted.
  • Only one home industry is allowed per lot.
  • The business cannot change the building's outward appearance (except for accessibility modifications).
  • Your home must be your primary residence.
  • Retail sales are limited to what you produce or repair on-site.
  • The business cannot create electrical interference, excessive traffic, parking, noise, or odors.

Permitted home industries include carpentry, metal working, welding, electrical, small equipment repair, blacksmithing, and gardening. Motor vehicle repair, paint shops, and furniture stripping are generally not allowed.

Specific Exceptions and Permitted Uses

Some properties have specific permissions:

  • 14811 Ninth Line: You can manufacture and sell handmade chocolates if you only employ residents and one non-resident, the activity is inside, there's no outdoor storage, it doesn't disturb the neighborhood, you only use allowed equipment, sales are limited to what's produced there, you have one unmarked business vehicle, and the business area is no larger than 55 square metres (By-law 1992-026).
  • 504 Main Street East, Lot 35, Concession 10: A retail craft supply business is allowed if you live there, have no more than one non-resident assistant, the business occupies no more than 25% of the floor area, you provide sufficient screened parking, and the home's residential character isn't changed (By-law 1986-151).
  • 11731 Tenth Line (Mixed-Use Street Townhouses): The following businesses are allowed on the ground floor facing Tenth Line: convenience store, private home day care, home occupation, office, personal service establishment, retail store, and studio (By-law 2020-100).

These are general guidelines. Confirm specific zoning regulations for your property.

original_data.query: Can I park my car facing the wrong way on the street?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility of parking a motor vehicle in contravention of the designated direction of travel on a public roadway within the Town's jurisdiction, specifically concerning compliance with current traffic and parking bylaws, including but not limited to regulations pertaining to vehicle orientation, obstruction of traffic flow, and public safety, as governed by municipal codes and any applicable zoning ordinances or recent amendments thereto.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Direction on Streets

No, you cannot park your car facing opposite to the direction in which vehicular traffic is proceeding on that side of the street in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. This is explicitly prohibited under By-law 2008-114, Section 6(a)(xviii), which was amended by By-law 2017-027.

Generally, when parking parallel on a two-way street, vehicles must be parked on the right side of the roadway with the right front and rear wheels parallel to and not more than thirty (30) centimetres from the curb, having regard to the direction in which the vehicle was proceeding. For one-way streets where parking is permitted on the left side, vehicles must be parked with the left front and rear wheels parallel to and not more than thirty (30) centimetres from the curb, having regard to the direction in which the vehicle is proceeding.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking Direction on Streets

No, you cannot park your car facing opposite to the direction of traffic on that side of the street in Whitchurch-Stouffville.

When parking parallel on a two-way street, park on the right side, with your wheels no more than 30 centimetres from the curb, in the direction of traffic. On one-way streets where left-side parking is allowed, park on the left side with your wheels no more than 30 centimetres from the curb, in the direction of traffic.

original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility of operating a temporary commercial enterprise, specifically a lemonade stand, on a municipal sidewalk within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. This inquiry pertains to compliance with applicable bylaws concerning street vending, public thoroughfare obstruction, zoning regulations governing commercial activities in residential areas, and any relevant permits or licenses required for such operation under current and recently enacted municipal codes.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Lemonade Stands and Sidewalk Sales in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Generally, operating a lemonade stand or selling products on a sidewalk in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville requires a license. According to By-law 1995-002 and By-law 1994-161, which regulate Mobile Vendors:

  • No person shall sell, or cause or permit selling at any time, on, over, or upon the street, sidewalk, boulevard, or road allowance of any highway, or otherwise stop, park, place, store, stand, or leave any object, vehicle, or thing on the highway or the sidewalk, the boulevard, road allowance, or any other designated area for the purposes of selling products, unless such person is in possession of a license issued pursuant to these by-laws.

These by-laws define "mobile vendor" broadly to include any person who goes from place to place or to a particular place with goods, wares, or merchandise for sale. A "portable display unit" is also defined as a push cart or other portable display unit used for selling products.

Exceptions to Licensing Requirements

A license to sell products is generally not required in the following situations, as outlined in By-law 1995-002 and By-law 1994-161:

  • If the products are sold by a Registered Charitable Organization or a local Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville Service Club.
  • If the products sold are in conjunction with and part of a community festival of the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville and the vendor has received written permission from the organizers of the festival to sell within the celebration area.
  • If the products sold are in conjunction with and part of a Town sanctioned event anywhere within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville and the vendor has received written permission from the organizers of the event to sell within the designated area (mentioned in By-law 1995-002).
  • If the products are sold by a person who pays business taxes in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville and sells products normally sold in their premises, and the vendor has received permission from the Town to sell within the designated area (mentioned in By-law 1995-002).
  • If the products are sold on lands designated "GC" (General Commercial) pursuant to By-law 89-19.

For specific events like the Strawberry Festival, by-laws such as By-law 2010-093, By-law 2009-093, By-law 2017-060, and By-law 2014-066 indicate that selling goods or services on closed streets requires written permission from the Whitchurch-Stouffville Strawberry Festival Inc.

Therefore, unless your lemonade stand falls under one of the specified exceptions (e.g., a registered charity, service club, or part of a sanctioned community event with permission), you would generally need to obtain a license to operate on a sidewalk.

original_data.filtered_answer:
Regulations for Selling on Sidewalks

Based on the provided by-laws, the ability to open a lemonade stand on a public sidewalk is subject to specific regulations and conditions, and there is an ambiguity within the by-laws regarding general licensing for such locations.

General Prohibition and Licensing Ambiguity

  • According to By-law 1995-002 (and similarly By-law 1994-161), which regulate mobile vendors, no person is permitted to sell products on a street, sidewalk, boulevard, or road allowance of any highway without a license. A "sidewalk" is defined as part of a "highway."

  • However, these same by-laws state that a license for a mobile vendor is issued for a "designated area," and a "designated area" is explicitly defined as an area that is not part of a highway. Since a sidewalk is considered part of a highway, this creates an ambiguity as to whether a license can actually be issued for a public sidewalk location. Therefore, a definitive answer on obtaining a general license for a lemonade stand directly on a public sidewalk cannot be provided based on the current by-laws.

Exemptions Where a License is Not Required

A license to sell products is not required under the following specific circumstances, as outlined in By-law 1995-002 (and similar provisions in By-law 1994-161):

  • If the products are sold by a Registered Charitable Organization or a local Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville Service Club.

  • If the products sold are in conjunction with and part of a community festival of the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, and the vendor has received written permission from the organizers of the festival to sell within the celebration area. For example, during the Strawberry Festival, selling goods on closed streets is prohibited without written permission from the Whitchurch-Stouffville Strawberry Festival Inc. (By-law 2010-093, By-law 2009-093, By-law 2008-082).

  • If the products sold are in conjunction with and part of a Town sanctioned event anywhere within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, and the vendor has received written permission from the organizers of the event to sell within the designated area.

  • If the products are sold by a person who pays business taxes in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville and sells products normally sold in their premises, and the vendor has received permission from the Town to sell within the designated area.

  • If the products are sold on lands designated "GC" (General Commercial) pursuant to By-law 89-19.

Past Temporary Allowances

It is important to note that in the past, temporary allowances for retail sales on highways and vacant lots were made for specific dates and locations. For instance, By-law 1994-069 and By-law 1995-088 permitted retail sales within a specific area of Whitchurch-Stouffville (bounded by Main Street, Burkholder Street, Lloyd/Blake Street, and Baker Street) for a few days in June and July of 1994 and 1995, respectively. These were time-limited exceptions and are not currently in effect.

Sidewalk Cafes for Restaurants

Separately, the Town has provisions for restaurants to operate seasonal sidewalk cafes under specific lease agreements and guidelines, such as those outlined in By-law 1994-104 and agreements authorized by by-laws like By-law 1994-115, By-law 2001-122, By-law 2004-115, and By-law 1996-104. These provisions are specific to established restaurants and are not applicable to a general lemonade stand.

Penalties for Non-Compliance

Any person who contravenes the provisions of By-law 1995-002 (or By-law 1994-161) is guilty of an offence and, upon conviction, is liable to a fine of not more than $5,000.00, exclusive of costs, recoverable under the Provincial Offences Act.

original_data.filtered_answer:
Lemonade Stands on Sidewalks

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, operating a lemonade stand on a sidewalk generally requires a license. According to By-law 1995-002, which regulates mobile vendors:

  • No person is permitted to sell products, including refreshments or foodstuffs, on a street, sidewalk, boulevard, or road allowance of any highway, or to place any object, vehicle, or thing for selling purposes, unless they possess a license issued by the Town.
  • A "mobile vendor" is defined as any person who goes from place to place or to a particular place with goods, wares, or merchandise for sale. A lemonade stand would fall under this definition as it involves selling "refreshments" or "foodstuffs."

When a License is Not Required

There are specific circumstances under By-law 1995-002 where a license to sell products is not required:

  • If the products are sold by a Registered Charitable Organization or a local Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville Service Club.
  • If the products are sold in conjunction with and as part of a community festival of the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, and the vendor has received written permission from the festival organizers to sell within the celebration area.
  • If the products are sold in conjunction with and as part of a Town-sanctioned event anywhere within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, and the vendor has received written permission from the event organizers to sell within the designated area.
  • If the products are sold by a person who pays business taxes in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville and sells products normally sold in their premises, and the vendor has received permission from the Town to sell within the designated area.
  • If the products are sold on lands designated "GC" (General Commercial) pursuant to By-law 89-19.

Applying for a License

If your lemonade stand operation does not fall under one of the exemptions, you would need to apply for a license. The application process typically involves:

  • Determining a proposed location for the designated selling area.
  • Providing a letter from the property owner or property manager permitting the use of their land.
  • Paying a non-refundable application fee (the annual license fee for mobile vendors is $500.00 as per By-law 1995-002).
  • Completing an application form.
  • Obtaining written approval from the York Region Health Department and adhering to their regulations.

Please note that the designated selling area must comply with specific criteria, including not being located on a highway or directly in front of a building entrance/exit, and must be on land zoned as commercial or industrial. There are also setback requirements from other businesses, school grounds, signalized intersections, and highways.

For more detailed information, please refer to By-law 1995-002.

original_data.filtered_answer:
