original_data.query: My neighbour's dog barks constantly when left outside. What can I do?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding potential contravention of municipal bylaws pertaining to animal control and noise regulation. Specifically, investigation into persistent and excessive barking emanating from a domestic animal, potentially constituting a nuisance under relevant provisions. Request determination of applicable regulations, including permissible noise levels, prohibited hours, and owner responsibilities concerning animal behaviour on private property. Seek clarification on enforcement procedures and available remedies for addressing ongoing disturbances, referencing current and recently amended bylaws.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Barking Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville has regulations in place regarding dog barking that disturbs inhabitants or constitutes a public nuisance.

Owner's Responsibility

  • Under By-law 2019-047, Section 3.10, "No Owner shall allow a Dog to make or cause noises, repetitive barking, or howling that is likely to disturb the inhabitants of the Town or that constitutes a public nuisance."
  • Additionally, By-law 2019-092, the general Noise By-law, states in Section 2.1 that "No Person shall make, cause or permit the emission of Noise, which Noise is audible at Point of Reception." This general prohibition would also apply to excessive dog barking.

Enforcement and Penalties

If a dog owner is found to be in contravention of these provisions:

  • For violations of By-law 2019-047, Section 11.1 states that every person who contravenes any provision is guilty of an offence and liable to a fine as provided for in the Provincial Offences Act. Specific fines are outlined in Section 11.3, ranging from a minimum of $300.00 for a first conviction to a maximum of $100,000.00 for a second or subsequent conviction. Non-compliance with an order is a continuing offence.
  • For violations of By-law 2019-092, as amended by By-law 2024-042, Section 7.a states that any person who contravenes any provision shall, upon issuance of a penalty notice, be liable to pay an administrative penalty and any administrative fees in accordance with the Administrative Monetary Penalty System By-law (By-law 2024-039-RE, as referenced in By-law 2024-042). The Provincial Offences Act does not apply to contraventions of designated provisions of this by-law.
  • By-law 2024-077 further amends By-law 2019-092 by adding a rebuttal presumption (Section 7.1) that an owner, whether present or absent, is presumed to have permitted or caused the noise, which can be rebutted by evidence to the contrary.
  • By-law 2020-108 also amends both By-law 2019-047 and By-law 2019-092 to include provisions against providing false information, hindering or obstructing officials, and requiring compliance with any order or notice issued under the by-law.

To address the issue, you may contact the Town's Animal Services or Municipal Law Enforcement to report the ongoing nuisance barking.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Dog Barking Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Whitchurch-Stouffville has rules about dog barking that disturbs people.

Owner's Responsibility

  • Dog owners must not allow their dogs to bark repetitively or howl in a way that disturbs neighbours or creates a nuisance.
  • General noise rules also apply to excessive dog barking.

Enforcement and Penalties

If a dog owner violates these rules:

  • They may be fined if their dog barks excessively. Fines start at $300.00 for the first violation and can increase for further violations.
  • The Town can issue penalties for noise violations.
  • The owner is presumed responsible for the noise, even if they are not present, unless they can prove otherwise.
  • It is against the rules to provide false information or interfere with officials enforcing these rules.

To report ongoing nuisance barking, contact the Town's Animal Services or Municipal Law Enforcement.

original_data.query: What happens if I don't pay my water bill?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and enforcement mechanisms pertaining to non-payment of municipal water utility charges, fees, or rates, as established under relevant Town bylaws and regulations governing water services, public utilities, and debt collection. Specifically, what are the penalties, interest accrual, service disconnection procedures, and potential for property liens or other legal remedies available to the Town for non-compliance with payment obligations within prescribed timelines, according to current and recently amended bylaws?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Consequences of Unpaid Water Bills

Failure to pay your water bill as and when it becomes due and payable is considered a contravention of the Town's by-laws, specifically By-law 2018-055.

  • Addition to Tax Account: If charges for water rates cannot be collected from the owner, these charges, along with any expenses incurred for the repair of private water services, meters, fixtures, and appurtenances connected with the water service or for damage to them, will be added to the property tax account. These charges will then accrue interest as provided in Section 446 of the Municipal Act, 2001, as outlined in By-law 2018-055 (Section 11.10). This is also supported by By-law 1997-141 and By-law 2017-059.
  • Service Disconnection: The Town may turn off your water service without further notice if you fail to comply with the provisions of By-law 2018-055 (Section 18.3).
  • Reconnection Fees: If your water service is turned off due to non-compliance, reconnection will not occur until the applicable reconnection fee, as specified in the Town's Fees and Charges By-law, has been paid (By-law 2018-055, Section 19.1).
  • Penalties: As non-payment is a contravention of By-law 2018-055 (Section 11.11 and 20.6), any person found guilty of an offence under this by-law may be subject to fines. For a first conviction, the fine can range from not less than $100.00 to not more than $50,000.00. For a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence, the fine can range from not less than $400.00 to not more than $100,000.00 (By-law 2018-055, Section 20.3).
  • Overdue Notices: Fees may apply for overdue/arrears notices related to water accounts, as indicated in By-law 2020-107 and By-law 2019-007.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Consequences of Unpaid Water Bills

Not paying your water bill on time violates Town rules.

  • Tax Account Addition: Unpaid water charges will be added to your property tax bill, and interest will accrue.
  • Service Disconnection: The Town may shut off your water service if you don't pay.
  • Reconnection Fees: If your water is shut off, you must pay a reconnection fee to restore service.
  • Penalties: You may be fined for not paying your bill. The first fine can be $100.00 to $50,000.00. Repeat offences can result in fines of $400.00 to $100,000.00.
  • Overdue Notices: You may be charged fees for overdue notices.

  • Lien on Property: When charges are added to the tax roll, they become a lien and charge upon the land, collected in the same manner as municipal taxes. This means the outstanding amount, including interest, has priority lien status and can be recovered as a debt due to the Town from the current or any subsequent owner of the property.

Upon conviction, you may be liable to a fine as provided for in the Provincial Offences Act, R.S.O. 1990, Chapter P.33, as amended. Fines can range from not less than $100.00 and not more than $50,000.00 for a first conviction, with higher penalties for second or subsequent convictions, or for continuing offences (refer to By-law 2018-055, Section 20.3).
  • Overdue Notices: The Town issues overdue/arrears notices for water and tax accounts, for which a fee may be charged, as indicated in By-law 2020-107.

original_data.query: What happens if a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and applicable penalties for unauthorized removal or destruction of a protected tree, specifically a mature tree, contravening municipal tree protection bylaws and zoning ordinances currently in effect. Determine compliance requirements, permit obligations, and prohibitions pertaining to tree removal activities on private and public property. Investigate potential violations related to property rights, environmental protection, and associated fines or remediation orders under relevant municipal codes.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Consequences of Unauthorized Mature Tree Removal by a Developer

If a developer removes a protected Mature Tree without permission in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, particularly within settlement areas covered by an approved Secondary Plan where new development is proposed, several consequences may arise under By-law 2023-060.

Definition of a Mature Tree

According to By-law 2023-060, a Mature Tree is defined as any Private Tree located on Private Property with a Diameter at Standard Height (DSH) of 30 cm or greater, within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville settlement areas in an approved Secondary Plan. Such trees shall not be removed or relocated unless permitted by the Director and/or designate (Section 1).

Prohibition and Conditions for Removal

The removal or cutting of Mature Trees is generally prohibited unless specific approval is granted by the Director and/or designate, typically to accommodate new development or under certain conditions such as the tree posing a hazard, being infested by disease, or being dead or dying (Section 2.4.b).

Enforcement Orders

In cases of contravention, a Municipal Law Enforcement Officer may issue various orders (Section 6):

  • Orders to correct the contravention.
  • Stop work orders.
  • Potential court orders prohibiting continuation or repetition of the offence.
  • Orders for replanting or Silvicultural Treatment.

If an order is not complied with, the Town may cause the required work to be done at the expense of the person or corporation who contravened the by-law, and these expenses can be recovered in the same manner as municipal taxes (Section 6.3).

Penalties and Fines

Violations of By-law 2023-060 are subject to significant penalties (Section 7.1):

  • Upon a first conviction, a fine of not less than $500 and not more than $50,000.
  • Upon a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence, a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $100,000.
  • For a continuing offence, a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 per day or part of a day that the offence continues. The total of these daily fines may exceed $100,000.
  • For a multiple offence, a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 for each offence included in the multiple offence. The total of all fines for each included offence is not limited to $100,000.

It is important to note that for the purpose of multiple offences, the removal or cutting of each Private or Mature Tree is considered a separate offence (Section 7.2).

Replacement and Compensation

In addition to fines, the Director and/or designate is authorized to require compensation for removed Mature Trees, either through planting Replacement Trees or paying Cash-in-lieu Compensation (Section 2.4.d). The replacement ratios are:

  • 3:1 for Mature Trees 30 cm to 49 cm in DSH.
  • 5:1 for Mature Trees 50 cm in DSH.
  • 1 replacement Tree for every 10 cm in DSH of Mature Tree(s) removed.

If planting replacement trees on the property is not feasible, the Owner/Applicant must pay Cash-in-lieu Compensation as determined by the Town's Fees and Charges By-law (Section 2.4.d.ii). Furthermore, a court may order the replanting of any Private Tree(s) removed or the application of Silvicultural Treatment (Section 7.5).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Consequences of Unauthorized Mature Tree Removal by a Developer

If a developer removes a protected Mature Tree without permission in Whitchurch-Stouffville, especially in areas with new development planned, there will be consequences.

Definition of a Mature Tree

A Mature Tree is any tree on private property that is 30 cm or greater in diameter within certain Whitchurch-Stouffville settlement areas. These trees cannot be removed unless the Town approves.

Prohibition and Conditions for Removal

Removing Mature Trees is generally not allowed unless the Town grants permission, such as for new development or if the tree is a hazard, diseased, dead, or dying.

Enforcement Orders

If a Mature Tree is removed without permission, the Town may issue orders to:

  • Correct the issue.
  • Stop work.
  • Obtain court orders to prevent further violations.
  • Replant trees.

If these orders are ignored, the Town may complete the work and bill the responsible party, with costs potentially added to their municipal taxes.

Penalties and Fines

Removing a Mature Tree without permission can result in fines:

  • First time: $500 to $50,000.
  • Second time: $2,000 to $100,000.
  • Ongoing issue: $2,000 to $10,000 per day.
  • Multiple trees removed: $2,000 to $10,000 per tree.

Removing each tree is considered a separate violation.

Replacement and Compensation

The Town may also require replacement of the removed trees:

  • For trees 30 cm to 49 cm in diameter, 3 new trees must be planted for each removed tree.
  • For trees 50 cm or greater in diameter, 5 new trees must be planted for each removed tree.
  • Alternatively, 1 replacement tree must be planted for every 10 cm in diameter of the removed tree(s).

If replanting on the property isn't possible, the Owner/Applicant must pay a fee to the Town. A court may also order replanting.

It is ancillary to an existing principal dwelling and is intended for a senior family member who requires some support but is capable of a degree of independent living. Garden Suites are permitted as a temporary use on a residential lot and must be sited in accordance with the zone provisions established for the lands.

Specific setback requirements for Garden Suites are detailed in by-laws that amend the general zoning regulations for particular properties:

Please note that these specific setback requirements are tied to the addresses mentioned in the respective by-laws, as they are amendments to the general zoning by-law for those particular properties.

original_data.query: wHERE CAN I DISPOSE OF SOD AND SOIL
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding permissible locations and methods for the disposal of sod, topsoil, and other earthen materials within the Town's jurisdiction, pursuant to applicable bylaws and regulations. Specifically, what provisions govern the lawful deposition of such materials, including but not limited to waste management bylaws, zoning ordinances pertaining to land alteration, and environmental protection regulations currently in effect, considering potential impacts on property rights, public health, and watercourse protection?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Disposal of Sod and Soil in Whitchurch-Stouffville

According to By-law 2018-035, "Earth and sod" are classified as "Non-Collectible Waste" (Schedule A, Page 16). This means that the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville does not provide municipal collection services for these materials.

If you have sod or soil to dispose of, By-law 2018-035 (Section 5.6) states that you must arrange for its disposal at your own expense. This involves conveying the material, or having it conveyed, to a waste receiving or disposal facility by a private service provider. This private service provider must operate under a Certificate of Approval issued pursuant to the Environmental Protection Act and comply with all applicable laws.

If your intention is to place or move sod or soil onto a property, this falls under the regulations for Site Alteration. By-law 2024-037 regulates any alteration to the grade of property through the movement, removal, or placing of topsoil or fill (which includes sod and soil). Generally, a Site Alteration Permit is required for such activities (Section 2.1, Section 4.1).

However, By-law 2024-037 (Section 3.2) provides one-time exemptions for placing certain maximum volumes of fill without a permit, depending on the property size:

  • For properties 0.1 hectares or less, a maximum of 10 cubic metres of fill may be placed.
  • For properties 0.1-0.2 hectares, a maximum of 50 cubic metres of fill may be placed.
  • For properties 0.2-0.5 hectares, a maximum of 100 cubic metres of fill may be placed.
  • For properties 0.5 hectares or larger, a maximum of 450 cubic metres of fill may be placed.

Any Site Alteration involving fill that exceeds these maximum volumes is prohibited unless a Site Alteration Permit is issued by the Commissioner.

Furthermore, if you import any fill (including sod and soil) onto any property in a quantity greater than 30 cubic metres, you are required to provide source site chemical testing and lab results to the Town, to the satisfaction of the Commissioner (By-law 2024-037, Section 2.5).

For specific details on private service providers or to inquire about Site Alteration Permits, you would need to contact the Town directly or consult the full text of By-law 2018-035 and By-law 2024-037.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Disposal of Sod and Soil in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The Town does not collect sod and soil. You must arrange for private disposal at your own expense, using a service provider approved under the Environmental Protection Act.

If you plan to move sod or soil onto a property, a Site Alteration Permit is generally required. However, you may be exempt from needing a permit for one-time placements if they are below certain maximum volumes:

  • For properties 0.1 hectares or less, a maximum of 10 cubic metres of fill may be placed.
  • For properties 0.1-0.2 hectares, a maximum of 50 cubic metres of fill may be placed.
  • For properties 0.2-0.5 hectares, a maximum of 100 cubic metres of fill may be placed.
  • For properties 0.5 hectares or larger, a maximum of 450 cubic metres of fill may be placed.

Placements exceeding these amounts are prohibited without a permit.

If you bring more than 30 cubic metres of fill (including sod and soil) onto a property, you must provide chemical testing results from the source site to the Town.

Contact the Town directly for details on service providers or Site Alteration Permits.

original_data.query: wHERE CAN I DISPOSE OF SOD AND SOIL
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding permissible locations and methods for the lawful disposal of sod, topsoil, and other earthen materials within the Town's jurisdiction, pursuant to applicable bylaws and regulations. Specifically, what provisions govern the disposal of such materials under waste management, property standards, zoning, and environmental protection bylaws currently in effect, including any prohibitions, restrictions, or designated disposal sites?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Disposal of Sod and Soil in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Sod and soil are classified as "Non-Collectible Waste" by the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville and are not picked up through regular municipal waste collection services, as outlined in Schedule 'A' of By-law 2018-035.

Disposing of Sod and Soil Off-Site

  • If you need to dispose of sod or soil off your property, you are responsible for arranging its disposal at your own expense.
  • This must be done by conveying the material, or having it conveyed, to a waste receiving or disposal facility.
  • The private service provider used for this purpose must operate under a Certificate of Approval issued pursuant to the Environmental Protection Act and comply with all applicable laws. This is specified in By-law 2018-035, Section 5.6.

Placing Sod and Soil on Your Property (Site Alteration)

If you intend to place sod or soil (defined as "Fill" in By-law 2024-037, Section 1.1(k)) on your property to alter its grade, this is considered a "Site Alteration" and generally requires a Site Alteration Permit issued by the Town, as per By-law 2024-037, Section 2.1.

There are specific exemptions for small volumes of fill based on property size, which are one-time allowances (By-law 2024-037, Section 3.2):

  • For properties 0.1 hectares or less, a maximum of 10 cubic metres of Fill may be placed once without a permit.
  • For properties 0.1-0.2 hectares, a maximum of 50 cubic metres of Fill may be placed once without a permit.
  • For properties 0.2-0.5 hectares, a maximum of 100 cubic metres of Fill may be placed once without a permit.
  • For properties 0.5 hectares or larger, a maximum of 450 cubic metres of Fill may be placed once without a permit.

Any Site Alteration involving Fill that exceeds these maximum volumes is prohibited unless a Site Alteration Permit is issued by the Commissioner (By-law 2024-037, Section 3.2).

Furthermore, any Fill used on a property must meet applicable Site Condition Standards, not contain putrescible materials, and be free of termites and Invasive Species (By-law 2024-037, Section 2.12).

General Prohibitions

It is prohibited to deposit or place any "Waste" on any property within the Town (By-law 2024-037, Section 2.6, and By-law 2016-068, Section 5.1).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Disposal of Sod and Soil in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville does not collect sod and soil through regular waste collection.

Disposing of Sod and Soil Off-Site

  • You must arrange for private disposal of sod and soil at your own expense.
  • You must take it to a waste disposal facility using a private service that is approved under the Environmental Protection Act.

Placing Sod and Soil on Your Property (Site Alteration)

Placing sod or soil (called "Fill") on your property to change its grade usually requires a Site Alteration Permit from the Town.

However, you do not need a permit if you only add a small amount of fill one time:

  • If your property is 0.1 hectares or less, you can add up to 10 cubic metres.
  • If your property is 0.1-0.2 hectares, you can add up to 50 cubic metres.
  • If your property is 0.2-0.5 hectares, you can add up to 100 cubic metres.
  • If your property is 0.5 hectares or larger, you can add up to 450 cubic metres.

If you add more fill than these amounts, you need a Site Alteration Permit.

Any fill you use must meet certain standards, not contain rotting materials, and be free of termites and invasive species.

General Prohibitions

You cannot put any "Waste" on any property in Town.

original_data.query: Does the town have the ability to put stop signs at the request of residents?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire whether the Town possesses the legal authority, pursuant to current traffic bylaws and municipal regulations pertaining to public safety and traffic management, to authorize the installation of traffic control devices, specifically stop signs, at specific locations within the Town's jurisdiction, based solely upon requests or petitions submitted by residents. Determine any applicable procedures, conditions, or limitations governing such authorizations under existing bylaws and relevant statutory provisions, considering the most recently enacted amendments.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Town's Authority to Install Stop Signs

Yes, the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville has the authority to install stop signs. According to the by-laws, the Council of the municipality is authorized to provide for the erection of stop signs at intersections on highways under its jurisdiction.

This authority is granted by legislation such as the Municipal Act, 2001, which allows a municipality to pass by-laws regulating traffic on highways, and the Highway Traffic Act, 1990, which specifically authorizes the Council to prescribe stop signs by by-law. The by-laws indicate that the Council deems it "advisable" to add or amend stop sign locations to regulate traffic and enhance public safety.

For example:

  • By-law 2019-009 states that "section 137 of the Highway Traffic Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. H.8, provides that the Council of a municipality may by by-law provide for the erection of stop signs at intersections on highways under its jurisdiction."
  • By-law 2018-005 notes that "the Highway Traffic Act, 1990 as amended authorizes the Council of a municipality to prescribe stop signs and yield signs by by-law for motor vehicles driven on a highway under its jurisdiction."
  • By-law 2024-071, By-law 2024-104, and By-law 2022-049 all reference Section 11 (3) of the Municipal Act, 2001, which authorizes a municipality to pass by-laws prohibiting or regulating parking and traffic on highways.

The provided by-laws do not specify whether stop signs are installed directly at the request of residents. The decision-making process for deeming it "advisable" to add stop signs is within the purview of the Council, as indicated in the by-laws such as By-law 2018-092, By-law 2016-106, By-law 2012-087, and By-law 2009-125.

Yes, the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville can install stop signs. The Town Council can authorize stop signs at intersections on roads under its jurisdiction to regulate traffic and improve safety.

It's unclear whether stop signs are installed directly at a resident's request. The Council decides when it's "advisable" to add stop signs.

original_data.query: I am a resident of Stouffville. I am a landlord. I need to add additional car spaces for my tenant to park my car. What are the bylaws around this?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding permissible alterations to residential property located within the Town of Stouffville for the purpose of increasing off-street parking capacity. Request for clarification on applicable zoning bylaw regulations, including but not limited to minimum parking space requirements, dimensional standards, and permitted uses ancillary to residential tenancies. Seeks guidance on compliance with current and recently amended bylaws governing property standards and any associated permitting processes for construction or modification of parking areas. Landlord status disclosed.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Regulations for Additional Car Spaces

As a landlord in Whitchurch-Stouffville, if you are looking to add additional car parking spaces for your tenant, the regulations depend on whether the tenant's unit is considered an "Additional Residential Unit" (ARU) or if you are simply adding general parking capacity to a single-detached dwelling.

Parking for Additional Residential Units (ARUs)

Effective June 19, 2024, By-law 2024-078 amended the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-law to replace the definition of "Second Suite" with "Additional Residential Units" (ARUs). For each ARU, one (1) parking space is required in addition to the parking requirements for the principal dwelling unit (Single Detached Dwelling, Semi-Detached Dwelling, or Townhouse Dwelling Unit). This required parking space for an ARU is permitted in a tandem parking space configuration and must be located on private property, complying with all other applicable provisions of the By-law.

General Residential Parking Space Dimensions and Location

According to By-law 2023-111, the following general provisions apply to parking in Residential and New Residential Zones:

  • Within a front, rear, or exterior side yard, motor vehicle parking is only permitted on a driveway or a parking pad. This area must have a minimum unobstructed dimension of 2.75 meters in width and 5.5 meters in length.
  • Parking is permitted within a garage, provided it has a minimum unobstructed dimension of 2.75 meters in width and 6 meters in length. Specific allowances are made for stair encroachments within the garage:
    • If stairs encroach up to 0.6 meters and are located within 1 meter from the end of the parking space, a 2.75 meter width and 6 meter length is still permitted.
    • If stairs intrude beyond 0.6 meters or are located more than 1 meter away from the end of the parking space, a 3.25 meter width and 6 meter length is required.
    • For a double vehicle garage, a dimension of 5.6 meters in width and 6 meters in length is permitted, with up to 0.6 meters of encroachment by stairs located within 1 meter of the end of the parking space.
  • Subject to provisions for circular driveways, only one driveway or one parking pad is permitted per lot.
  • No parking is permitted on any Residential Walkway or hardscaped outdoor amenity space.

Driveway Widths and Setbacks

The maximum driveway width within your property boundary is regulated by By-law 2016-143. In all Residential and New Residential Zones, the maximum driveway width shall be the greater of:

  • The garage door width plus 2 meters, provided that:
    • For lots with a lot frontage less than 11 meters, a minimum of 20% soft landscaped area must be provided in the front or exterior side yard where the driveway is located.
    • For lots with a lot frontage 11 meters or greater, a minimum of 35% soft landscaped area must be provided in the front or exterior side yard where the driveway is located.
  • 6 meters, provided that a minimum of 35% soft landscaped area is provided in the front or exterior side yard where the driveway is located.
  • In the case of a lot with a three-bay garage, 9 meters, provided that a minimum of 35% soft landscaped area is provided in the front or exterior side yard where the driveway is located.

Driveway and parking pad setbacks are also specified in By-law 2016-143 (which amends By-law 2010-001-ZO):

  • For Traditional Residential and New Residential Zones (excluding RPS, RV, RM1, RM2, and RN5 Zones):
    • If accessed from the front lot line, driveways or parking pads shall be located no closer to the interior side lot line than the minimum interior side yard setback requirement for the main building, and no closer to the exterior side lot line than the minimum exterior side yard setback requirement for the main building.
    • If accessed from the exterior side lot line, driveways or parking pads shall be at least 6 meters in depth and located no closer than 1.2 meters from the rear lot line, and no closer to the front lot line than the minimum front yard setback requirement for the main building.
  • For RPS, RV, RM1, RM2, RN5, and all Zones set out in Section 4:
    • If accessed from the front lot line, driveways or parking pads shall be located no closer than 1.5 meters from the interior side lot line, and no closer to the exterior side lot line than the minimum exterior side yard setback requirement for the main building.
    • If accessed from the exterior side lot line, driveways or parking pads shall be at least 6 meters in depth and located no closer than 1.2 meters from the rear lot line, and no closer to a front lot line than the minimum front yard setback requirement for the main building.

Please note that these are general provisions. Specific zoning for your property may have additional conditions or exceptions. For precise details regarding your specific property, it is recommended to consult the full text of the relevant by-laws or contact the Town's planning department.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking Regulations for Additional Car Spaces

If you are a landlord looking to add parking spaces for your tenant, the rules depend on whether the unit is an "Additional Residential Unit" (ARU) or if you are adding parking to a single-detached house.

Parking for Additional Residential Units (ARUs)

For each ARU, one parking space is required in addition to the parking needed for the main house. This parking space can be a tandem parking space and must be on your property.

General Residential Parking Space Dimensions and Location

The following rules apply to parking in residential zones:

  • In a front, rear, or side yard, parking is only allowed on a driveway or parking pad that is at least 2.75 meters wide and 5.5 meters long.
  • Parking is allowed in a garage that is at least 2.75 meters wide and 6 meters long. Stairways can affect this:
    • If stairs take up less than 0.6 meters and are near the end of the parking space, the garage can still be 2.75 meters wide and 6 meters long.
    • If stairs take up more than 0.6 meters or are further from the end of the parking space, the garage must be 3.25 meters wide and 6 meters long.
    • For a double garage, it can be 5.6 meters wide and 6 meters long if stairs take up less than 0.6 meters and are near the end of the parking space.
  • Generally, only one driveway or parking pad is allowed per property.
  • Parking is not allowed on walkways or outdoor amenity spaces.

Driveway Widths and Setbacks

The maximum driveway width on your property is regulated. The maximum width is the greater of:

  • The garage door width plus 2 meters, but you must have enough soft landscaped area in your front or side yard (20% if your lot is less than 11 meters wide, 35% if it is 11 meters or greater).
  • 6 meters, if you have at least 35% soft landscaped area in your front or side yard.
  • 9 meters for a three-bay garage, if you have at least 35% soft landscaped area in your front or side yard.

Driveway and parking pad setbacks also apply:

  • For most residential zones:
    • If the driveway is accessed from the front, it must be set back from the side property lines as far as your house is required to be.
    • If the driveway is accessed from the side, it must be at least 6 meters deep, set back 1.2 meters from the rear property line, and set back from the front property line as far as your house is required to be.
  • For specific zones (RPS, RV, RM1, RM2, RN5, and zones in Section 4):
    • If the driveway is accessed from the front, it must be set back 1.5 meters from the side property lines and set back from the side property lines as far as your house is required to be.
    • If the driveway is accessed from the side, it must be at least 6 meters deep, set back 1.2 meters from the rear property line, and set back from the front property line as far as your house is required to be.

These are general rules, and your property's specific zoning might have other rules. Contact the Town's planning department for details specific to your property.

Parking Requirements for Additional Residential Units (ARUs)

  • Number of Parking Spaces: One (1) parking space is required for each Additional Residential Unit (ARU). This is in addition to the parking spaces required for the principal dwelling unit (your main house). This requirement is outlined in By-law 2024-078, which amends the Comprehensive Zoning By-law 2010-001-ZO.
  • Tandem Parking: A parking space required for an ARU is permitted in a tandem parking space configuration.
  • Location of Parking: The parking space for the ARU must be located on private property and comply with all other applicable provisions of the by-law.

  • Minimum Parking Space Dimensions:

    For parking pads or driveways, a minimum unobstructed dimension of 2.75 meters in width and 5.5 meters in length is required. This is specified in By-law 2023-111.

    If the parking is within a garage, the following unobstructed dimensions apply, as per By-law 2023-111:

    • 2.75 meters in width and 6 meters in length.
    • If stairs intrude up to 0.6 meters within 1 meter from the end of the parking space, the dimensions remain 2.75 meters in width and 6 meters in length.
    • If stairs intrude beyond 0.6 meters or are located more than 1 meter from the end of the parking space, the dimensions must be 3.25 meters in width and 6 meters in length.
    • For a double vehicle garage, the dimensions are 5.6 meters in width and 6 meters in length, with up to 0.6 meters of encroachment by stairs located within 1 meter of the end of the parking space.

Please note that By-law 2024-078 specifically replaced the previous "Second Suites" regulations, including their parking requirements, with the new "Additional Residential Units" framework. Therefore, the information provided above from By-law 2024-078 and By-law 2023-111 is the most current and applicable.

original_data.query: GENERATOR NOISE AFTER 11PM
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding permissible sound levels emanating from generators after 23:00 hours. Specifically, what municipal bylaws, including noise control bylaws, zoning regulations, and public nuisance ordinances, govern the operation of generators and the emission of noise therefrom on private or public property after 11:00 PM? Requesting clarification on any applicable exemptions, permits, or restrictions pertaining to generator noise during nighttime hours, with emphasis on currently enforced regulations and recent amendments.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Generator Noise Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the operation of generators is regulated under the Noise By-law. According to By-law 2024-042, which amends By-law 2019-092, a "generator" is explicitly defined as "Construction Equipment."

Therefore, the restrictions for "Construction Equipment" as outlined in By-law 2019-092 apply to generators. The restricted time periods for the operation of any Construction Equipment are:

  • Monday to Friday: 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m.
  • Saturday: 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m.
  • Sundays and Holidays: All day

For construction or the operation of Construction Equipment conducted by any individual other than the homeowner, the Saturday restricted period is from 7:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m., as specified in By-law 2022-080 (which amends By-law 2019-092).

Based on these regulations, the operation of a generator is generally prohibited after 7:00 p.m. on weekdays and Saturdays, and all day on Sundays and Holidays. This means that generator noise after 11:00 p.m. is not permitted.

Additionally, By-law 2019-092 includes a general prohibition stating that no person shall make, cause, or permit the emission of noise that is audible at a Point of Reception and is of such a volume or nature that it is likely to disturb any person in the Town.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Generator Noise Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In Whitchurch-Stouffville, generators are considered "Construction Equipment" and are subject to noise restrictions.

You cannot operate a generator during these times:

  • Monday to Friday: 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m.
  • Saturday: 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. (or 8:00 a.m. if the construction is not being done by the homeowner)
  • Sundays and Holidays: All day

This means you generally cannot use a generator after 7:00 p.m. on weekdays and Saturdays, or at all on Sundays and Holidays. Generator noise is not permitted after 11:00 p.m.

Additionally, you cannot make noise that is loud enough to disturb others in town.

original_data.query: GENERATOR at home and NOISE AFTER 11PM. Are there exceptions?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding permissible operation of residential generators, specifically concerning noise emissions exceeding established decibel limits during nighttime hours (23:00-07:00). Request clarification on any applicable exemptions, variances, or special permissions pertaining to noise control bylaws, zoning regulations, and public nuisance ordinances, considering temporal precedence of amendments and recent enactments affecting generator operation and noise pollution standards within residential zones.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Noise Regulations for Generators at Home

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the operation of a generator at home is subject to noise regulations outlined in By-law 2019-092, as amended by By-law 2022-080, By-law 2024-042, and By-law 2024-077.

General Prohibition and Restricted Times

  • No person shall make, cause, or permit the emission of noise that is audible at a Point of Reception.
  • The operation of any combustion engine or pneumatic device without an effective exhaust or intake muffling device in constant operation is considered a noise likely to disturb.
  • Specifically, the operation of any gas, battery, or electric powered tool for domestic purposes, which would include a generator, is restricted during the following times:
    • 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Monday to Saturday
    • 9:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. on Sundays and Holidays
    Therefore, operating a generator after 11:00 p.m. is generally prohibited under these regulations.

Exceptions to Noise Regulations

There are general exemptions and a process for applying for temporary noise permits:

General Exemptions (as per By-law 2019-092):

This by-law does not apply to sound emitted or caused or permitted in connection with:

  • Measures undertaken in an emergency for the immediate health, safety, or welfare of persons and animals.
  • Measures undertaken in an emergency for the preservation or restoration of property.
  • The operation of emergency vehicles.
  • Measures undertaken where the Town, its servants, employees, contractors, or agents are carrying out Town operations or operating, maintaining, or installing municipally-owned infrastructure, facilities, or the like.
  • Non-emergency construction, reconstruction, or repair of any regional, provincial, or federal public works, including highways, provided the Town is given advanced written notice of the hours to be worked if outside the permitted construction hours.
  • The use of implements of husbandry in the operation of agricultural or farm activity related to food crop seeding, chemical spraying, harvesting, or livestock operations carried on by a farmer.
Exemptions by Application (Temporary Noise Permit):

For situations not covered by general exemptions, a person may apply for a Temporary Noise Permit:

  • Applications for exemptions not exceeding 90 days in length can be made to the Manager of By-Law or their designate.
  • Applications for exemptions over 90 days in length must be made to Council.
  • The application must be in writing and include:
    • The name and address of the applicant.
    • The name and information of a contact person (if different from the applicant).
    • The location of the event or activity.
    • A description of the source of noise.
    • The specific provision(s) from which the exemption is sought.
    • The times of day, period, and duration for which the exemption is sought.
    • The reasons why the exemption should be granted.
    • A statement of the steps planned or being taken to minimize the noise.
    • Written confirmation that all property owners within a 500-meter radius of the noise source have been notified, along with a copy of the public notice.
    • A non-refundable application fee as set out in the Town's current Fees and Charges By-law.
  • The Manager of By-Law or Council will consider factors such as negative effects on neighboring properties or the Town, benefits to the Town or neighbors, and any previous violations by the applicant.
  • Conditions may be imposed on any granted Temporary Noise Permit.
  • Breaching any terms or conditions of an exemption or Temporary Noise Permit will render it null and void.

Owner Responsibility for Noise

Please note that By-law 2024-077 amends By-law 2019-092 to include a rebuttal presumption: an owner, whether present or absent from the property where noise is being emitted, shall be presumed to have permitted or caused the noise, which presumption may be rebutted by evidence to the contrary on a balance of probabilities.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Noise Regulations for Generators at Home

Whitchurch-Stouffville has noise regulations that apply to home generators.

General Prohibition and Restricted Times

  • You can't make noise that others can hear.
  • Generators must have a working muffler.
  • You can't use gas, battery, or electric tools (including generators) at these times:
    • 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. Monday to Saturday
    • 9:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. on Sundays and Holidays
    Operating a generator after 11:00 p.m. is generally not allowed.

Exceptions to Noise Regulations

There are some exceptions and a way to apply for a temporary permit:

General Exemptions:

The noise by-law doesn't apply to:

  • Emergencies for health, safety, or welfare.
  • Emergencies for protecting property.
  • Emergency vehicles.
  • Town operations.
  • Construction on public works (with notice to the Town for work outside normal hours).
  • Farm activities.
Exemptions by Application (Temporary Noise Permit):

You can apply for a Temporary Noise Permit for situations not covered above:

  • Apply to the Manager of By-Law for permits up to 90 days.
  • Apply to Council for permits longer than 90 days.
  • Your application must be in writing and include:
    • Your name and address.
    • Contact information.
    • Location of the noise.
    • Description of the noise.
    • Which rule you need an exception from.
    • Dates and times of the exception.
    • Reasons for the exception.
    • Steps to reduce noise.
    • Proof that neighbors within 500 meters were notified.
    • A non-refundable fee.
  • The Manager of By-Law or Council will consider the impact on neighbors and the Town, benefits, and past violations.
  • Permits may have conditions.
  • Breaking the permit rules makes it invalid.

Owner Responsibility for Noise

The owner is responsible for noise coming from their property, even if they aren't there, unless they can prove otherwise.

original_data.filtered_answer:
Public Nuisance By-law and Harassment/Intimidation

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville has By-law 2003-071, which prohibits and abates public nuisances on public land or in public buildings within the Town.

Under By-law 2003-071, "Nuisance" is defined to include "the harassment or the intimidation of another person or persons on public lands or in public facilities."

Therefore, if someone harasses or intimidates you on public lands or in public facilities within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, they may be in contravention of By-law 2003-071.

Penalties for Contravention

Every person who contravenes any provision of By-law 2003-071 is guilty of an offence and, upon conviction, is liable to a fine as provided for in the Provincial Offences Act, R.S.O. 1990, Chapter P.33, as amended.

original_data.query: can i park an extra car on my property
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility of parking an additional motor vehicle on a residential property within the Town, specifically concerning compliance with current zoning bylaws, parking regulations, and any applicable restrictions pertaining to vehicle storage, property maintenance standards, or limitations on the number of vehicles permitted per dwelling unit as defined under relevant municipal codes and recently amended ordinances.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking an Extra Car on Your Property

You may park an extra car on your property in Whitchurch-Stouffville, provided you adhere to the Town's by-laws regarding parking location, driveway, and garage specifications. Here are the general guidelines:

General Parking Location

  • Motor vehicle parking on your property is generally permitted only on a driveway or a parking pad, or within a garage.
  • Parking is not permitted in an "unauthorized area," which includes your Front Yard, Exterior Side Yard, or Side Yard, unless specifically allowed by the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-Law.
  • You are also prohibited from parking on any Residential Walkway or hardscaped outdoor amenity space. A Residential Walkway is defined as a hard surface path leading from the front or exterior wall of a dwelling unit to a driveway, curb, lot line, or sidewalk, and it cannot be used for motor vehicle parking.

These regulations are outlined in By-law 2017-027 and By-law 2023-111.

Driveway and Parking Pad Regulations

If you are parking on a driveway or parking pad, the following requirements apply:

  • The parking space must have a minimum unobstructed dimension of 2.75 meters in width and 5.5 meters in length.
  • Generally, only one driveway or one parking pad is permitted per lot, though provisions exist for circular driveways.
  • For corner lots, a second driveway may be permitted to access a garage or accessory building, provided the accessory building is a minimum of 6.0 meters from the street line and the second driveway receives approval from the authority having jurisdiction for the road.
  • Maximum driveway widths within the property boundary are regulated. For instance, the maximum width can be the greater of the garage door width plus 2 meters (with specific soft landscaped area requirements based on lot frontage), 6 meters (with 35% soft landscaped area), or 9 meters for a three-bay garage (with 35% soft landscaped area).
  • Driveways and parking pads must also comply with specific setback requirements from interior, exterior, front, and rear lot lines.

Details on these regulations can be found in By-law 2023-111, By-law 2016-143, and By-law 2013-110.

Garage Parking

Parking is permitted within a garage, subject to specific minimum dimensions:

  • An unobstructed dimension of 2.75 meters in width and 6 meters in length is required.
  • If stairs encroach into the garage, specific dimensions apply: 2.75 meters in width and 6 meters in length with up to 0.6 meters of encroachment by stairs located within 1 meter from the end of the parking space, or 3.25 meters in width and 6 meters in length if stairs intrude beyond 0.6 meters or are located more than 1 meter away from the end of the parking space.
  • For a double vehicle garage, a dimension of 5.6 meters in width and 6 meters in length is required, with similar provisions for stair encroachment.

These details are specified in By-law 2023-111.

Parking for Additional Residential Units (ARUs)

If the "extra car" is associated with an Additional Residential Unit (ARU) on your property, one parking space is required for each ARU. This is in addition to the parking requirements for the principal dwelling unit. This parking space can be in a tandem configuration and must be located on private property, complying with all other applicable by-law provisions. This is outlined in By-law 2024-078.

Specific Vehicle Restrictions

Please note that buses with a net weight exceeding 4,000 kilograms are generally not permitted to be parked or stored on lots in Residential or Rural Residential Zones where the minimum lot area permitted is 0.8 hectares or less. This is stated in By-law 1987-163.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking an Extra Car on Your Property

You can park an extra car on your property in Whitchurch-Stouffville if you follow the Town's rules about where you park, your driveway, and your garage. Here's what you need to know:

General Parking Location

  • You can only park on a driveway, a parking pad, or in a garage.
  • Parking is not allowed in your Front Yard, Exterior Side Yard, or Side Yard, unless the Town specifically allows it.
  • You cannot park on any Residential Walkway, which is a path from your house to the street.

These rules are in By-law 2017-027 and By-law 2023-111.

Driveway and Parking Pad Regulations

If you park on a driveway or parking pad:

  • The parking space must be at least 2.75 meters wide and 5.5 meters long.
  • Usually, you can only have one driveway or parking pad, but there are exceptions for circular driveways.
  • If you have a corner lot, you might be able to have a second driveway if it leads to a garage or shed that is at least 6.0 meters from the street and the Town approves it.
  • There are rules about how wide your driveway can be, depending on your lot size and garage.
  • Driveways and parking pads must be set back a certain distance from your property lines.

Garage Parking

You can park in your garage if it meets these size requirements:

  • It must be at least 2.75 meters wide and 6 meters long.
  • If stairs stick out into the garage, different size rules apply.
  • For a double garage, it must be 5.6 meters wide and 6 meters long, with similar rules for stairs.

Parking for Additional Residential Units (ARUs)

If the extra car is for an Additional Residential Unit (ARU) on your property, you need one parking space for each ARU, in addition to the parking for your main house. This space can be one behind the other (tandem) and must be on your property. This is in By-law 2024-078.

Specific Vehicle Restrictions

Buses heavier than 4,000 kilograms are generally not allowed on smaller lots in Residential or Rural Residential Zones. This is stated in By-law 1987-163.

original_data.query: My neighbour's tree is branching into my property over the common fence. What are my options?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding potential encroachment of vegetation, specifically tree branches, extending from an adjacent property across a shared property boundary and onto the inquirer's property. Requesting clarification on applicable municipal bylaws pertaining to property line disputes, vegetation maintenance obligations, nuisance abatement procedures, and potential remedies for violations, including but not limited to, tree trimming rights and responsibilities under current zoning ordinances, property standards bylaws, and any relevant public tree protection bylaws enacted within the last five years.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Options Regarding Your Neighbour's Tree Branching Over Your Property

If your neighbour's tree is branching into your property over a common fence, the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville by-laws provide some guidance, particularly if the tree is causing damage or is in an unsafe condition.

Attempting to Reach an Agreement

It is generally encouraged to first attempt to reach an agreement with your neighbour. While By-law 2007-118, the Division Fence By-law, specifically addresses agreements for the construction or maintenance of division fences, the principle of mutual agreement can be applied to other shared property matters.

Tree Causing Damage to a Division Fence

If the tree is causing damage to the division fence between your properties, By-law 2007-118 states the following:

  • Section 3.7 of By-law 2007-118 specifies that if a tree causes damage to a division fence, whether by accident, carelessness, negligence, deliberate intent, or otherwise, the owner of the land on which the tree stood shall, at their sole expense, forthwith remove the tree and repair the fence.

General Property Maintenance for Hazardous Limbs

Property owners have a general responsibility to maintain their vegetation to prevent unsafe conditions or damage to property. By-law 2016-068, which pertains to litter, yard waste, and property maintenance, includes provisions for vegetation:

  • Section 2.4(e) of By-law 2016-068 requires that "a tree or other plant, or limb or branch of it, that is dead, diseased, decayed or damaged shall be removed from the land or otherwise pruned to remove the dead, diseased, decayed or damaged portions of the tree or plant, so as to prevent an unsafe condition or damage to any property." This applies to trees on any property.

Overhanging Branches Not Causing Damage or Unsafe Conditions

The provided by-laws define "pruning" and "good arboricultural practice" in the context of municipal trees or trees affected by development applications (By-law 2020-086 and By-law 2023-060). However, these by-laws do not explicitly detail specific options or rights for a property owner regarding overhanging branches from a neighbour's tree that are not causing damage to a fence or presenting an unsafe condition as described in the by-laws.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Options Regarding Your Neighbour's Tree Branching Over Your Property

If your neighbour's tree branches over your property line and a shared fence, here’s what you should know:

Attempting to Reach an Agreement

Try talking to your neighbour first to find a solution that works for both of you.

Tree Causing Damage to a Division Fence

If the tree is damaging the fence between your properties, the owner of the land where the tree is located is responsible for removing the tree and repairing the fence at their own cost.

General Property Maintenance for Hazardous Limbs

Property owners must maintain their trees to prevent unsafe conditions or damage to other properties. Dead, diseased, decayed, or damaged tree parts must be removed or pruned to prevent hazards or property damage.

Overhanging Branches Not Causing Damage or Unsafe Conditions

The Town's rules define pruning in specific situations, but there are no explicit rules about branches that overhang your property without causing damage or posing an immediate safety risk.

original_data.query: My neighbour's tree is branching into my property over the common fence. Can I cut those branches?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding permissible actions concerning encroaching vegetation: Pursuant to current municipal bylaws, including but not limited to property standards, zoning regulations, and tree protection bylaws, what are the rights and obligations of an owner of land with respect to branches of a neighbour's tree extending onto their property across a shared boundary or fence line? Specifically, is the property owner permitted to prune or remove said encroaching branches, and are there any applicable restrictions or requirements regarding notification, species protection, or disposal of resulting vegetative waste under current Town regulations?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Tree Branches Overhanging Property

The by-laws provided do not contain specific information regarding a property owner's right to cut branches from a neighbor's tree that are overhanging their property. The available by-laws primarily address the protection and maintenance of trees on municipal lands or on private property in the context of new development applications, as well as general property maintenance standards for the tree's owner.

For instance, By-law 2023-060, the Private Tree Preservation and Protection By-law related to Development Applications, outlines regulations for Mature and Heritage Trees on private property within specific Secondary Plan Areas when new development is proposed. It defines "Pruning" as the appropriate removal of not more than one-third of the live branches or limbs of a tree in accordance with Good Arboricultural Practice. However, this by-law focuses on the owner's responsibility in the context of development and does not grant a general right to an adjoining property owner to prune a neighbor's tree.

By-law 2020-086 pertains to the planting, injury, and removal of trees on highways and other public lands (Municipal Trees), and therefore does not apply to trees on private property between neighbors.

By-law 2016-068, respecting litter, yard waste, and property maintenance, states that an owner of property shall ensure that "a tree or other plant, or limb or branch of it, that is dead, diseased, decayed or damaged shall be removed from the land or otherwise pruned to remove the dead, diseased, decayed or damaged portions of the tree or plant, so as to prevent an unsafe condition or damage to any property." This clause places the responsibility for maintenance on the owner of the property where the tree is located.

Since the provided by-laws do not explicitly address the right of a property owner to cut overhanging branches from a neighbor's tree, we cannot provide a definitive answer based solely on this information.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Tree Branches Overhanging Property

The Town's by-laws don't specifically say whether you can cut branches from a neighbor's tree that hang over your property. The by-laws mainly focus on protecting trees on Town land or managing trees on private property when someone is planning new construction.

For example, By-law 2023-060 discusses pruning trees during development, but it doesn't give you the right to prune your neighbor's tree.

Another by-law covers trees on public lands, not trees on private property between neighbors.

However, property owners must maintain their trees so that dead, diseased, or damaged parts don't create unsafe conditions or damage property.

Because the by-laws don't directly address your right to cut overhanging branches, we can't give you a definite answer based only on this information.

original_data.query: can neighbours feed wildlife like birds and squirrels
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility, under current and recently enacted Town bylaws, of providing food or sustenance to wildlife, including but not limited to avian species and squirrels, by residents on private property. Determine if such activity constitutes a violation of animal control bylaws, waste management regulations, public health ordinances, or zoning provisions pertaining to nuisance or property maintenance standards. Ascertain any applicable restrictions, prohibitions, or obligations regarding wildlife feeding.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Feeding Wildlife in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the intentional feeding of wildlife is generally prohibited. According to Section 7.1 of By-law 2019-047 (Animal Services), no person shall intentionally feed a Wild Animal or leave food or attractants outdoors in a manner that attracts or is accessible by a Wild Animal, feral, or stray Domestic Animal on private or public property.

However, there is a specific exception for feeding song birds. Section 7.2 of By-law 2019-047 states that the general prohibition does not apply to the feeding of song birds on a property, provided the following conditions are met:

  • Seed must be placed in a bird feeding device that is sufficiently above grade to not attract or be accessible by Wild Animals.
  • Bird feeding practices must not attract large flocks of homing birds, such as wild, feral, or domestic Pigeons.
  • Any spillage of seed upon the ground must be removed by the property owner or resident immediately and disposed of in a manner that does not attract Wild Animals, feral, or stray Domestic Animals.

Therefore, while feeding song birds is permitted under these strict conditions, feeding other wild animals like squirrels, or leaving out food that could attract them, is not allowed.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Feeding Wildlife in Whitchurch-Stouffville

You generally can't intentionally feed wild animals or leave food outside that attracts them on any property.

However, you *can* feed songbirds if you follow these rules:

  • Use bird feeders that are high enough off the ground to keep other animals away.
  • Don't attract large flocks of birds like pigeons.
  • Clean up any spilled birdseed immediately.

Feeding other wild animals, like squirrels, or leaving food out that could attract them is not allowed.

original_data.query: என் வீட்டு மேல விழுகிற மரத்தை நான் கட் பண்ணலாமா கூடாதா?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding permissible tree removal on private property: Does the Town's current bylaws, specifically those pertaining to property maintenance, tree protection (including but not limited to tree preservation bylaws and zoning regulations concerning vegetation), and emergency tree removal provisions, permit or prohibit a property owner from removing a tree situated such that it poses an imminent hazard or has fallen onto their dwelling? This inquiry seeks clarification on obligations and permissions under relevant and recently enacted municipal codes.
original_data.filtered_answer:
மரம் அகற்றுதல் - அவசரநிலை

பொதுவாக, விட்சர்ச்-ஸ்டூஃப்வில்லில் உள்ள தனிப்பட்ட நிலங்களில் மரங்களை வெட்டுவதற்கு அல்லது சேதப்படுத்துவதற்கு அனுமதி தேவைப்படுகிறது. இருப்பினும், உங்கள் வீட்டின் மீது ஒரு மரம் விழுந்து, அது உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலாக இருந்தால், அதை அகற்ற உங்களுக்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை.

  • By-law 2006-001 இன் பிரிவு 2.2(b)(i) இன் படி, உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலை முடிவுக்குக் கொண்டுவரத் தேவையான 'அவசர வேலை'க்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை. உங்கள் வீட்டின் மீது ஒரு மரம் விழுந்தால், அது இந்த வரையறைக்குள் வரும்.
  • மேலும், By-law 2006-001 இன் பிரிவு 2.2(b)(iii) இறந்த மரங்கள் அல்லது இறந்த கிளைகளை அகற்றுவதற்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை என்றும் குறிப்பிடுகிறது.
  • By-law 2016-068 (சொத்து பராமரிப்பு) இன் பிரிவு 2.4(e) இன் படி, உங்கள் சொத்தில் உள்ள ஒரு மரம் அல்லது அதன் கிளைகள் இறந்த, நோய்வாய்ப்பட்ட, சிதைந்த அல்லது சேதமடைந்த நிலையில் இருந்தால், அது பாதுகாப்பற்ற நிலையை அல்லது சொத்துக்கு சேதத்தை ஏற்படுத்தாமல் தடுக்க அகற்றப்பட வேண்டும்.
  • By-law 2023-060 இன் பிரிவு 4.1(c)(i) இன் படி, 'அவசர வேலை'யின் விளைவாக ஒரு தனிப்பட்ட மரம் அல்லது முதிர்ந்த மரத்தை அகற்றுவதற்கு விலக்கு அளிக்கப்படுகிறது. 'அவசர வேலை' என்பது உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலை முடிவுக்குக் கொண்டுவரத் தேவையான வேலை என வரையறுக்கப்படுகிறது.

எனவே, உங்கள் வீட்டின் மீது மரம் விழுந்து, அது உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலாக இருந்தால், அதை அகற்ற உங்களுக்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை.

அவசரநிலை இல்லை என்றால், 20 சென்டிமீட்டருக்கும் அதிகமான மர விட்டம் அல்லது 40 சென்டிமீட்டருக்கும் அதிகமான அடி விட்டம் கொண்ட மரங்களை அகற்றுவதற்கு பொதுவாக By-law 2006-001 இன் படி அனுமதி தேவைப்படும் என்பதை நினைவில் கொள்ளவும்.
original_data.laymans_answer:
உங்கள் வீட்டின் மீது ஒரு மரம் விழுந்து, அது உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலாக இருந்தால், அதை அகற்ற உங்களுக்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை.

  • உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலை முடிவுக்குக் கொண்டுவரத் தேவையான அவசர வேலைக்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை.
  • இறந்த மரங்கள் அல்லது இறந்த கிளைகளை அகற்றுவதற்கு அனுமதி தேவையில்லை.
  • உங்கள் சொத்தில் உள்ள ஒரு மரம் அல்லது அதன் கிளைகள் இறந்த, நோய்வாய்ப்பட்ட, சிதைந்த அல்லது சேதமடைந்த நிலையில் இருந்தால், அது பாதுகாப்பற்ற நிலையை அல்லது சொத்துக்கு சேதத்தை ஏற்படுத்தாமல் தடுக்க அகற்றப்பட வேண்டும்.
  • உயிர் அல்லது சொத்துக்கு உடனடி அச்சுறுத்தலை முடிவுக்குக் கொண்டுவரத் தேவையான வேலையின் விளைவாக ஒரு மரம் அகற்றப்பட்டால், அனுமதி தேவையில்லை.

அவசரநிலை இல்லை என்றால், 20 சென்டிமீட்டருக்கும் அதிகமான மர விட்டம் அல்லது 40 சென்டிமீட்டருக்கும் அதிகமான அடி விட்டம் கொண்ட மரங்களை அகற்றுவதற்கு பொதுவாக அனுமதி தேவைப்படும் என்பதை நினைவில் கொள்ளவும்.

original_data.query: Lái xe 50/40 thì có bị phạt không?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquiry regarding potential contravention of municipal traffic regulations pertaining to vehicular speed limits. Specifically, does operating a motor vehicle at a speed of 50 kilometers per hour in a designated zone with a posted speed limit of 40 kilometers per hour constitute a violation subject to fines or other penalties under current Town bylaws governing traffic control and public safety, as amended to date?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Tốc độ giới hạn và Vi phạm

Theo By-law 2008-147, Mục 14(a), không ai được phép lái xe trên đường phố hoặc bất kỳ nơi nào khác với tốc độ lớn hơn mức hợp lý và thận trọng trong điều kiện hiện có, hoặc với tốc độ có khả năng gây nguy hiểm cho bất kỳ người nào hoặc sự an toàn của bất kỳ tài sản nào. Trừ khi có biển báo khác, tốc độ giới hạn cho các phương tiện lưu thông trên các đường phố trong Thị trấn Whitchurch-Stouffville không được vượt quá 40 km/h.

Do đó, nếu bạn lái xe với tốc độ 50 km/h trong khu vực có tốc độ giới hạn là 40 km/h (dù có biển báo hoặc là tốc độ mặc định), bạn sẽ bị coi là vi phạm quy định này.

Quy định về Hình phạt

Mục 17(a) của By-law 2008-147 quy định rằng bất kỳ người nào vi phạm bất kỳ điều khoản nào của By-law này, khi bị kết án, sẽ bị coi là phạm tội và phải chịu phạt tiền theo quy định của Đạo luật Vi phạm Tỉnh (Provincial Offences Act), không bao gồm chi phí.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Giới hạn tốc độ và Vi phạm

Không ai được phép lái xe với tốc độ lớn hơn mức hợp lý trong điều kiện hiện tại hoặc với tốc độ có thể gây nguy hiểm. Trừ khi có biển báo khác, tốc độ giới hạn trên các đường phố ở Whitchurch-Stouffville là không quá 40 km/h.

Nếu bạn lái xe với tốc độ 50 km/h trong khu vực giới hạn 40 km/h, bạn sẽ bị coi là vi phạm.

Hình phạt

Bất kỳ ai vi phạm quy định sẽ bị phạt tiền theo quy định của pháp luật.

original_data.query: Can I park a school bus in the library's parking lot?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility of parking a commercial vehicle, specifically a school bus, within the designated parking area of the municipal library, as governed by applicable Town bylaws. This inquiry pertains to current regulations concerning vehicle parking restrictions, zoning ordinances, and potential prohibitions related to vehicle type, size, or commercial use on municipal property. Determine compliance requirements and any associated penalties under relevant bylaws currently in effect.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking a School Bus in the Library's Parking Lot

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, a school bus is classified as a "Commercial Motor Vehicle" under By-law 2008-114, as amended by By-law 2020-137 and By-law 2024-040.

Regarding parking on private or municipal property, By-law 2008-114 (Section 18, as updated by By-law 2024-040) states that no person shall park or leave a motor vehicle on municipal property without the consent of The Corporation of the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville or a local board thereof. A library parking lot would typically fall under municipal property.

While the by-laws specify that Commercial Motor Vehicles are generally prohibited from parking on highways within residential zones (with exceptions for active loading/unloading of passengers), they do not provide a general exemption for school buses to park in municipal parking lots, such as a library's, without consent. Therefore, consent from the Town or the relevant local board operating the library would be required for a school bus to park in the library's parking lot.

It is also important to note that By-law 2002-085 (Schedule VIII) designates the east side of the Pool/Library Complex at 30 Burkholder Street as a Fire Route, where parking is prohibited at all times. This specific area must be kept clear.

For specific inquiries about parking at the library, it is advisable to contact the library administration directly to confirm their parking policies and obtain any necessary consent.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking a School Bus in the Library's Parking Lot

A school bus is considered a Commercial Motor Vehicle in Whitchurch-Stouffville.

You can't park any vehicle on Town property, including a library parking lot, without the Town's permission. So, you'll need permission to park a school bus there.

While there are rules about where Commercial Motor Vehicles can park in residential areas, these rules don't automatically allow school buses to park in municipal lots like the library's. You still need permission.

Also, the east side of the Pool/Library Complex at 30 Burkholder Street is a designated Fire Route, where parking is never allowed.

To be sure about parking at the library, contact the library directly to ask about their parking rules and get permission.

original_data.query: Are there any bylaws regarding e-scooters or e-bikes?
original_data.transformed_query: "Inquire as to the existence and current applicability of any municipal bylaws, regulations, or ordinances pertaining to the operation, use, and parking of electric scooters (e-scooters) and electric bicycles (e-bikes) within the Town's jurisdictional boundaries. This includes, but is not limited to, bylaws concerning traffic safety, pedestrian rights-of-way, permitted vehicle types on public and private property, licensing requirements, and any relevant amendments or repeals enacted within the past five years. Search should encompass transportation, parks and recreation, and public safety domains."
original_data.filtered_answer:
Bylaws Regarding E-Scooters and E-Bikes

Based on the provided by-laws for the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, specific regulations for e-scooters are not explicitly mentioned.

For e-bikes, which are referred to as "motor assisted bicycles" in the by-laws, the following information is available:

  • Operation on Sidewalks:

    According to By-law 2008-147, which regulates traffic in the Town, a "motor assisted bicycle" is included in the definition of a "motor vehicle." Section 3(d)(i) of By-law 2008-147 states that "No person shall drive a motor vehicle upon a sidewalk or footpath on a highway except for the purpose of directly crossing the sidewalk or footpath." Therefore, motor assisted bicycles (e-bikes) are generally prohibited from being driven on sidewalks or footpaths, except when directly crossing them.

    Additionally, By-law 2008-147 defines "bicycle" as including a tricycle and unicycle but explicitly states it "does not include a motor assisted bicycle." Section 5(a) of By-law 2008-147 prohibits riding a "bicycle" upon a sidewalk on any highway. While this specific prohibition does not apply to motor assisted bicycles, the broader "motor vehicle" prohibition mentioned above would apply.

  • Operation in Parks:

    By-law 2020-087, which regulates the use of Parks, Trails, Park Buildings, and Open Spaces, defines "motor assisted bicycle" and includes it within the definition of a "motor vehicle." Section 4.1(q) of By-law 2020-087 states that "No person shall ride or drive any motor vehicle in a park except upon the roadway therein designated for public vehicular use within a park." Section 4.1(r) further states "No person shall park any motor vehicle in a park except within a designated parking space." This means that motor assisted bicycles (e-bikes) are generally restricted to designated roadways and parking spaces within parks.

    Furthermore, By-law 2020-087 also prohibits the riding or driving of "motorized recreational vehicles" (which are defined separately and include items like go-carts, trail bikes, and all-terrain vehicles) and "motorized snow vehicles" within any park, as per Section 4.1(s).

For parking regulations, By-law 2024-040 amends By-law 2008-114-PR and updates definitions, including "Motor Vehicle" which encompasses "motor assisted bicycle." This by-law primarily establishes an administrative monetary penalty system for parking violations.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Bylaws Regarding E-Scooters and E-Bikes

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's by-laws do not specifically mention regulations for e-scooters.

For e-bikes (referred to as "motor assisted bicycles" in the by-laws), here's what you need to know:

  • Sidewalk Use:

    E-bikes are generally not allowed on sidewalks, except to directly cross them. By-law 2008-147 prohibits driving a motor vehicle, which includes e-bikes, on sidewalks.

  • Park Use:

    E-bikes are restricted to designated roadways and parking spaces within Town parks. By-law 2020-087 prohibits operating motor vehicles, including e-bikes, in parks except on designated roadways.

By-law 2024-040 establishes fines for parking violations related to motor vehicles, including e-bikes.

original_data.query: Can I install a swimming pool in my side yard?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility of installing a private swimming pool within a side yard setback area, contingent upon current zoning regulations and applicable bylaws pertaining to property line restrictions, fence requirements, water discharge protocols, public health standards, and safety codes, as currently enacted and enforced by the Town. Determine compliance obligations regarding permits, inspections, and ongoing maintenance responsibilities related to said pool installation.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Swimming Pool Installation in Side Yards

Yes, you can generally install a swimming pool in your side yard in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, subject to specific regulations.

General Zoning Regulations

  • According to By-law 2020-058, a swimming pool or hot tub is permitted in the actual or required rear yard, exterior side yard, or interior side yard of any lot.
  • The edge of the water of the swimming pool must not be located any closer to any lot line or street line than 1.2 meters.
  • By-law 1974-031 also permits swimming pools in the side yard, stating that no part of the pool shall be located closer to any lot line or street line than the minimum distance required for the principal building on that lot.
  • Please note that specific properties may have unique zoning exceptions. For example, By-law 1989-065 specifies a minimum southerly Side Yard of 9 meters for a swimming pool on a particular piece of land (Lot 32, Concession 6).

Enclosure and Permit Requirements

In addition to zoning setbacks, all swimming pools must comply with the Town's Fence & Pool Enclosure By-law:

  • Before excavating for or constructing a swimming pool, or constructing an enclosure around it, you must submit plans to the Chief Building Official, pay a permit fee, and obtain a permit. This is outlined in By-law 2013-168.
  • A temporary enclosure is required if water is added to the pool during construction, and it must be maintained until the permanent enclosure is erected and approved, as per By-law 2013-168.
  • Every swimming pool must be completely surrounded by an enclosure that is at least 1.5 meters high, measured on the outside. This enclosure must not have any climbing aids and any gaps within or below it cannot exceed 100 mm.
  • No part of the enclosure shall be located within 1.2 meters of the edge of the water contained in the swimming pool, as stated in By-law 2013-168.
  • Gates forming part of the enclosure must be of equivalent construction and height, self-closing, lockable, and self-latching. The opening device must be located at the top of the gate and designed so it cannot be readily opened from the outside by small children.
  • The installation of a swimming pool or its enclosure must not alter the existing drainage pattern of the lot in a negative way, unless approved by the Chief Building Official. The owner is responsible for ensuring the new drainage pattern does not affect neighboring lands.

For specific details regarding your property, it is recommended to consult the full text of the relevant by-laws or contact the Town's planning and building departments.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Swimming Pool Installation in Side Yards

Yes, you can generally install a swimming pool in your side yard in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, subject to specific regulations.

General Zoning Regulations

  • Swimming pools are permitted in rear, exterior side, or interior side yards.
  • The water's edge must be at least 1.2 meters from any lot line or street line.
  • Specific properties may have unique zoning exceptions. For example, By-law 1989-065 specifies a minimum southerly Side Yard of 9 meters for a swimming pool on a particular piece of land (Lot 32, Concession 6).

Enclosure and Permit Requirements

All swimming pools must comply with the Town's Fence & Pool Enclosure By-law:

  • You must submit plans, pay a permit fee, and obtain a permit before starting construction.
  • If water is added during construction, a temporary enclosure is required until the permanent enclosure is approved.
  • The pool must be completely surrounded by an enclosure at least 1.5 meters high, with no climbing aids and gaps no larger than 100 mm.
  • No part of the enclosure can be within 1.2 meters of the water's edge.
  • Gates must be self-closing, lockable, self-latching, and have a child-resistant opening device at the top.
  • Pool installation must not negatively alter the lot's drainage unless approved. You are responsible for ensuring drainage doesn't affect neighboring properties.

For specific details regarding your property, it is recommended to contact the Town's planning and building departments.
