original_data.query: `Can my neighbor extend their downspout and run it onto my property?`
original_data.transformed_query: "Inquiry regarding permissible discharge of stormwater runoff from an adjacent property's downspout onto the subject property. Specifically, does the Town's current Zoning Bylaw, Drainage Bylaw, or Property Standards Bylaw permit or prohibit the extension of a downspout such that it directs stormwater onto a neighboring property, potentially creating a nuisance, impacting drainage patterns, or violating property line regulations? Requesting clarification on applicable obligations, permissions, and prohibitions under relevant municipal regulations, including recent amendments."
original_data.filtered_answer:
Storm Water Drainage Regulations

No, your neighbor is generally not permitted to extend their downspout and run it onto your property. The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville has specific by-laws regulating storm water drainage to ensure it is contained within the property from which it originates.

According to By-law 2016-068, Section 9, titled "Drainage":

  • Subsection 9.2 states that "Every owner of property shall ensure that all storm water run-off from downspouts and impervious surfaces on the property is contained within the limits of the property until absorbed by the soil or drained to a swale, watercourse or storm sewer."
  • Subsection 9.4 further clarifies that "Every owner of property shall ensure that such property is not filled, graded, re-graded or altered in any way that would change existing surface drainage patterns or create additional storm water run-off onto any adjacent property."
  • Subsection 9.5 (b) explicitly states that "all roof drainage or storm water... from the property is: not discharged onto walkways, boulevards, stairs, or neighbouring lands."

Additionally, By-law 2018-056, Section 14, titled "Storm Water Drainage," reinforces these requirements:

  • Subsection 14.1 states that a discharger "shall discharge storm water... at grade away from any building or structure on that discharger's property in such manner that the storm water will not accumulate at or near the building or structure and will not adversely affect adjacent properties or create hazardous conditions."
  • Subsection 14.3 specifies that "Water from roofs of buildings shall be conveyed through eavestrough and pipe systems to discharge a minimum of 0.6 metres (2 feet) from the foundation wall of that building, from which point it shall drain by flowing across the surface of the ground and down pipes and may not be directed toward or across hard-paved or concrete surfaces."

These provisions collectively ensure that property owners are responsible for managing storm water runoff, including from downspouts, entirely within their own property boundaries to prevent adverse effects on neighboring lands.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Storm Water Drainage Regulations

Generally, your neighbor is not permitted to extend their downspout and direct water onto your property. The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville requires property owners to manage storm water drainage within their own property.

Property owners must ensure storm water from downspouts and other surfaces remains within their property until it's absorbed or drained to an appropriate outlet.

Properties cannot be altered in ways that change existing drainage patterns or create additional runoff onto neighboring properties.

Storm water from roofs must be managed to avoid discharging onto walkways, boulevards, stairs, or neighboring lands.

Storm water must be discharged away from buildings in a manner that doesn't negatively affect adjacent properties or create hazardous conditions. Water from roofs should be directed away from the building's foundation and allowed to drain across the ground, not onto paved surfaces.

These rules ensure that property owners manage storm water runoff within their boundaries to prevent issues on neighboring properties.

original_data.query: Are you allowed to pave your entire backyard with stones?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility, under current and recently enacted Town bylaws, specifically zoning ordinances, property standards regulations, and environmental protection provisions, of installing impermeable surfaces, such as paving stones or similar materials, across the entirety of a residential rear yard. Determine any restrictions, obligations, or prohibitions regarding maximum lot coverage, stormwater management, drainage requirements, or potential impacts on adjacent properties or public health related to such installations.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Site Alteration and Property Maintenance Regulations

Paving your entire backyard with stones in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville is subject to regulations concerning site alteration and property maintenance. This type of activity is generally considered a "Site Alteration" under Town by-laws.

Site Alteration Permit Requirements

  • According to By-law 2024-037, Section 2.1, no person shall undertake, cause, or permit any Site Alteration of any property within the Town without the owner first receiving a Site Alteration Permit. "Site Alteration" is defined in Section 1.1(jj) as any alteration to the existing grade of a property through the movement, removal, placing, or relocation of any "Fill".

  • "Fill" (Section 1.1(k) of By-law 2024-037) includes materials such as soil, sand, clay, rock, and stone. Therefore, placing stones to pave your backyard would fall under the definition of "Placing of Fill" and would constitute a Site Alteration.

  • While By-law 2024-037 does provide some exemptions for minor volumes of fill without a permit (Section 3.2), paving an entire backyard would likely exceed these allowances. For example, on a property 0.1 hectares or less, a maximum of 10 cubic metres of fill is permitted once without a permit. For larger properties, the maximum volume increases, but paving an entire backyard would typically involve a significant amount of material.

Drainage and Environmental Considerations

  • Any site alteration, including extensive paving, must comply with drainage regulations. By-law 2016-068, Section 9.1, requires property owners to ensure their property is graded and maintained to prevent water ponding, unsafe conditions, or harm to the environment. It also states that catchbasins and swales must be installed and maintained to facilitate drainage and not impede the natural flow of stormwater.

  • By-law 2016-068, Section 9.2, mandates that all stormwater runoff from downspouts and impervious surfaces (like a paved backyard) must be contained within the property limits until absorbed by the soil or drained to a swale, watercourse, or storm sewer.

  • Furthermore, By-law 2016-068, Section 9.4, prohibits altering existing surface drainage patterns or creating additional stormwater runoff onto any adjacent property. Paving an entire backyard could significantly impact these drainage patterns.

  • By-law 2024-037, Section 2.11, also explicitly states that no person shall alter, fill, or block any drainage on any property without prior written approval from the Commissioner.

  • By-law 2016-068, Section 2.4(d), also requires that a yard be cultivated or protected by ground cover which prevents the erosion of the soil. While stones can prevent erosion, the overall impact on vegetation and natural ground cover for an entire backyard would need to be considered in the context of the by-law's intent for property maintenance.

Given these regulations, it is highly probable that paving your entire backyard with stones would require a Site Alteration Permit and would need to adhere to strict drainage and environmental standards. It is recommended to contact the Town's Engineering and Public Works Department for specific guidance and to determine if your proposed project requires a permit and to ensure compliance with all applicable by-laws.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Site Alteration and Property Maintenance Regulations

Paving your entire backyard with stones in Whitchurch-Stouffville is regulated under site alteration and property maintenance rules. This is generally considered a "Site Alteration".

Site Alteration Permit Requirements

  • You generally need a Site Alteration Permit before altering the grade of your property by moving or placing materials. Paving your backyard with stones is considered "Placing of Fill" and is a Site Alteration.

  • While By-law 2024-037 allows some exceptions for small amounts of fill without a permit, paving an entire backyard will likely require one.

Drainage and Environmental Considerations

  • Any paving must follow drainage rules. You must ensure your property is graded to prevent water ponding and environmental harm.

  • Stormwater runoff from paved areas must stay within your property until absorbed or drained to a proper outlet.

  • You cannot change existing drainage patterns or create extra runoff onto neighboring properties.

  • You cannot alter or block any drainage on your property without written approval.

  • Your yard must be maintained to prevent soil erosion. The impact of stones on vegetation and ground cover will be considered.

Paving your entire backyard with stones likely requires a Site Alteration Permit and must meet drainage and environmental standards. Contact the Town's Engineering and Public Works Department for specific guidance and to ensure you comply with all rules.

original_data.query: How high am I able to build a fence in my backyard?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding permissible fence height regulations applicable to residential properties, specifically within rear yard setbacks, pursuant to current zoning bylaws and property standards codes. Request clarification on maximum fence height limitations, including any variations based on fence material, location relative to property lines, and potential impact on sightlines or neighbouring properties. Seek confirmation of compliance obligations under relevant Town of [Town Name] bylaws, including but not limited to zoning, property maintenance, and animal control regulations, as currently enacted.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Fence Height Regulations in Residential Rear Yards

For properties located in a residential zone in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the maximum height for a fence in your rear yard is generally 2.2 metres above the grade. This is outlined in Section 4.1 of By-law 2013-168.

The height of a fence is measured from the grade directly below a given portion of the fence to its top, excluding the posts (Section 1.18 of By-law 2013-168).

Specific Exceptions for Rear Yard Fences

There are a few specific exceptions to this general height limit for fences in a rear yard:

  • Fences on Retaining Walls: If a fence is acting as a guard on top of a retaining wall, its highest point shall not be more than 1.8 metres above the retaining wall (Section 11.1 of By-law 2013-168).
  • Tennis Court Fencing: Chain link fencing for a tennis court located in a rear yard may be constructed up to a height of 3.6 metres above grade (Section 11.2 of By-law 2013-168).

Please ensure that any fence you plan to build complies with these regulations and other general provisions of By-law 2013-168, such as material restrictions and structural soundness requirements.
original_data.laymans_answer:

Specific Exceptions for Rear Yard Fences

There are some exceptions to the general height limit:

  • Fences on Retaining Walls: If your fence is on top of a retaining wall, the highest point of the fence cannot be more than 1.8 metres above the wall.
  • Tennis Court Fencing: If you have a tennis court in your backyard, the chain link fence can be up to 3.6 metres high.

Make sure your fence follows these rules, as well as any rules about materials and structural soundness.

original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking on Your Driveway in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Regarding parking on your driveway, the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's parking regulations address parking on private property and in "unauthorized areas."

  • According to By-law 2008-114, Section 18(a)(i), and as reiterated in its amendments, "No person shall park or leave a motor vehicle on private property without the consent of the owner or occupant of such property." This implies that if you are the owner or occupant of the property, you have consent to park on your own driveway.

  • However, By-law 2008-114, Section 6(b), and By-law 2017-027, Section 3, state that "No person shall park a motor vehicle in an unauthorized area." An "unauthorized area" is defined in By-law 2008-114, Section 1(ee), and By-law 2017-027, Section 1, as "a Front Yard, Exterior Side Yard, or Side Yard except as otherwise permitted under the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-Law."

Since a driveway is typically located within a Front Yard, whether parking on it is permitted depends on the specific provisions of the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-Law. The provided by-laws do not contain the full details of the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-Law.

Therefore, based solely on the information available in these by-laws, a definitive answer regarding parking on the bottom half of your driveway cannot be provided without consulting the Town's Comprehensive Zoning By-Law, which may specify what is "otherwise permitted" within a Front Yard.

original_data.query: Are there laws around security cameras and fortification?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the existence, scope, and applicability of municipal bylaws regulating the installation, operation, and maintenance of security surveillance systems, including but not limited to closed-circuit television (CCTV), on private and public property. Further, investigate regulations pertaining to property fortification, encompassing structural modifications intended to enhance security. original_data.filtered_answer:
Regulations on Security Measures and Property Standards

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville by-laws address certain security measures, particularly concerning fences and the maintenance of vacant properties. However, there is no explicit mention of regulations specifically for "security cameras" or "fortification" as a general concept in the provided by-laws.

Fences and Enclosures

Regarding specific types of fences that could be considered security measures, By-law 2013-168 (Fence and Pool Enclosure Regulation) outlines the following:

  • Barbed Wire or Razor Wire: This by-law prohibits the use of barbed wire or razor wire in fences, with one exception. It is permitted only on land within an Employment Heavy zone, as defined by the zoning by-law, and must be located at least 1.8 metres (approximately 5.9 feet) above grade (Section 2.2).
  • Electrified Fences: Fences that include or are connected to any device designed to conduct electric current are generally prohibited. The only exception is for fences erected for the containment of animals in connection with agricultural uses within rural areas (Section 2.3).

Vacant Buildings and Security

For vacant buildings, By-law 2018-049 (Property Standards) includes provisions related to security:

  • Securing Vacant Buildings: If a building is vacant, its owner must protect it in accordance with the Town's current Boarding Up of Vacant Buildings By-law (Section 23.1).
  • Utility Disconnection/Security: If a building remains vacant for more than 90 days, the owner must ensure all utilities serving the building are properly disconnected or otherwise secured to prevent accidental or malicious damage, unless such utilities are necessary for the building's safety or security (Section 23.2).
  • Heritage Properties: For vacant heritage properties, if unauthorized entry occurs repeatedly, the owner may be required to provide "improved security of closures" as determined by the Chief Building Official or an Officer (Section 24.4e).

If you are considering specific security installations, it is advisable to consult with the Town's Building Department or Municipal Law Enforcement for guidance on current regulations and permit requirements.

original_data.query: How long I can park my car on streets during daytime
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissible duration for vehicle parking on municipal roadways during daylight hours, specifically concerning compliance with parking bylaws and traffic regulations currently in effect. Request clarification on any restrictions, prohibitions, or time limitations applicable to daytime street parking, considering relevant sections pertaining to vehicle operation, public safety, and obstruction of roadways within the Town's jurisdiction.
original_data.filtered_answer:
General Daytime Parking Regulations

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, generally, no person shall park any vehicle on any highway for a period longer than three (3) hours. This regulation is outlined in Section 6(a)(v) of By-law 2008-114, which governs and controls the parking of vehicles in the Town.

Exceptions to the Three-Hour Parking Limit

There are specific exceptions to this three-hour parking limit, which are detailed in Schedule III (Three (3) Hour Parking Exceptions) of By-law 2008-114, as amended by subsequent by-laws:

  • For certain locations, parking is permitted for longer periods or at any time. For example, By-law 2024-095 amends Schedule III to allow "Anytime" parking in specific sections of:
    • Brown Lane (South side, between #5 and #35; East side, between #32 and #58)
    • Betula Gate (West side, between #6 and #22 Brown Lane flankage)
    • Delbert Circle (East side, between #23 and #101 flankage, and between #6 and #22 Brown Lane flankage)
    • Fernglen Crescent (West side, between #93 and #113)
  • By-law 2018-038 specifically states that on Main Street, between Albert Street intersection and Park Drive intersection, Park Drive intersection and a point 46 metres east, and Cemetery Lane intersection and Tenth Line, parking is permitted for a maximum of 3 hours from Monday to Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. (with extended hours on Thursday & Friday until 10:00 p.m. for some sections).
  • Other exceptions primarily apply to specific locations during nighttime hours (e.g., 4 p.m. to 9 a.m. or 9 p.m. to 2 a.m.), as noted in By-law 2009-007, By-law 2021-100, and By-law 2022-123, for areas such as Church Street (south of Main Street, 24-hour parking permitted), Dougherty Crescent, Miltrose Crescent, James Ratcliff Avenue, Brill Court, and Delbert Circle.

Unless a specific by-law provides an exception for a particular street or area, the general three-hour maximum parking limit applies during daytime hours on streets in Whitchurch-Stouffville.
original_data.laymans_answer:
In Whitchurch-Stouffville, you can generally park on streets for a maximum of three hours during the day.

However, there are exceptions:

    • Brown Lane (South side, between #5 and #35; East side, between #32 and #58)
    • Betula Gate (West side, between #6 and #22 Brown Lane flankage)

  • Other exceptions apply to specific locations during nighttime hours.

Unless there's a specific exception for a street, the three-hour parking limit applies during the day.

original_data.query: What happens if a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and enforcement mechanisms applicable to unauthorized removal or destruction of a protected tree, specifically a mature tree, contravening municipal tree protection bylaws, zoning ordinances, or heritage conservation regulations currently in effect. Determine applicable penalties, restoration requirements, and remediation obligations arising from non-compliance, including potential impacts on property rights, environmental protection, and public nuisance abatement.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Unauthorized Removal of Protected Mature Trees

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the removal or cutting of a Mature Tree on private property without express authorization through the review and approval of Planning Act applications is prohibited, as outlined in By-law 2023-060, Section 2.4.c. Heritage Trees are strictly prohibited from being removed or relocated at all times (Section 2.4.a).

Enforcement Actions

If a contravention of By-law 2023-060 occurs, the Town may take several enforcement actions (Section 6):

  • Orders to Correct: The Town may issue an Order requiring the person who contravened the by-law, or who caused or permitted the contravention, or the owner/occupier of the land, to do work to correct the contravention (Section 6.2).
  • Town Action at Offender's Expense: If an Order is not complied with, a Municipal Law Enforcement Officer may cause the work to correct the contravention to be done at the expense of the person(s) or corporation responsible. This includes any administrative or additional fees as required under the Town's Fees and Charges By-law (Section 6.3).
  • Stop Work Orders: A Municipal Law Enforcement Officer may issue an Order describing a contravention, specifying the timeframe for its remedy, and establishing other conditions to mitigate adverse impacts (Section 6.5.a).
  • Permit Suspension/Revocation: Permits may be suspended or revoked for any violation of the by-law or the conditions of a Permit (Section 6.5.b).
  • Court Orders: Upon conviction, the Ontario Court of Justice or any court of competent jurisdiction may make an Order prohibiting the continuation or repetition of the offence (Section 7.3.b). The court may also order the convicted person to replant trees in a specified location and within a specified period, or apply Silvicultural Treatment to re-establish the trees (Section 7.5.b).

Penalties and Fines

Any person found guilty of an offence under By-law 2023-060 is subject to significant penalties (Section 7.1):

  • First Conviction: A fine of not less than $500 and not more than $50,000.
  • Second or Subsequent Conviction: A fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $100,000 for the same offence.
  • Continuing Offence: A fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 per day or part of a day that the offence continues. The total of daily fines may exceed $100,000.
  • Multiple Offence: For each offence included in a multiple offence, a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000. The total of all fines for each included offence is not limited to $100,000. For clarity, the removal/cutting of each Private or Mature Tree is considered a separate offence (Section 7.2).

Additionally, municipal fees for administration and enforcement activities will be charged according to the Town's current Fees and Charges By-law (Section 7.4).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Unauthorized Removal of Protected Mature Trees

In Whitchurch-Stouffville, you need permission to remove or cut down a mature tree on private property. It is never permitted to remove or relocate Heritage Trees.

Enforcement Actions

If this rule is broken, the Town may take action:

  • The Town may order the responsible party to fix the problem.
  • If the order isn't followed, the Town may do the work and bill the responsible party.
  • The Town may issue a Stop Work Order.
  • Permits may be suspended or revoked.
  • The courts may issue orders to stop the violation from continuing. The court may also order tree replanting or treatment.

Penalties and Fines

Anyone found guilty of illegally removing a protected tree faces significant penalties:

  • First Offence: A fine between $500 and $50,000.
  • Repeat Offence: A fine between $2,000 and $100,000 for the same offence.
  • Ongoing Offence: A fine between $2,000 and $10,000 per day the offence continues, potentially exceeding $100,000 in total.
  • Multiple Offences: A fine between $2,000 and $10,000 for each separate tree removed or cut.

The Town will also charge fees for administration and enforcement.

original_data.query: What happens if a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and applicable penalties for unauthorized removal or destruction of a protected tree, specifically a mature tree, contravening municipal tree protection bylaws or zoning ordinances currently in effect. Determine compliance requirements, permit obligations, and prohibitions pertaining to tree removal on private or public property. Investigate potential violations related to property rights, environmental protection, and associated remediation requirements under relevant Town bylaws.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Consequences of Unauthorized Removal of a Protected Mature Tree by a Developer

If a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, particularly within Secondary Plan Areas where new development is proposed, it constitutes a contravention of the Town's by-laws. This is specifically addressed in By-law 2023-060, which protects Private, Mature, and Heritage Trees on private property.

Prohibition and Conditions for Removal

  • Under By-law 2023-060, the removal or cutting of a Heritage Tree on private property is strictly prohibited at all times (Section 2.4.a).

  • For Mature Trees (defined as having a Diameter at Standard Height (DSH) of 30 cm or greater), removal or relocation is generally not permitted unless expressly authorized by the Town's Director and/or designate through the review and approval of Planning Act applications (Section 2.4.c).

  • Permitted circumstances for removal of a Mature Tree, subject to approval, include accommodating new development, posing a hazard to life or property, being a public nuisance, being infested by disease or insects, being structurally compromised, being dead or dying, or being planted too close to another tree (Section 2.4.b).

Enforcement and Penalties

Any person, including a corporation (such as a developer), who contravenes any provision of By-law 2023-060 is deemed guilty of an offence (Section 6.1). The Town may take several enforcement actions and impose significant penalties:

Enforcement Orders

  • The Town may issue an Order requiring the person who contravened the by-law, or caused or permitted the contravention, to do work to correct it (Section 6.2).

  • This can include stop work orders, orders prohibiting continuation or repetition of the offence, and orders for replanting or Silvicultural Treatment (Sections 6.5.a, 7.3.ii).

  • If an Order is not complied with, the Town may cause the required work to be done at the expense of the person or corporation, and these expenses can be recovered (Section 6.3).

Fines

Fines for violating By-law 2023-060 can be substantial:

  • Upon a first conviction, a fine of not less than $500 and not more than $50,000 (Section 7.1.a).

  • Upon a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence, a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $100,000 (Section 7.1.b).

  • For a continuing offence (where the contravention of an Order persists), a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 per day or part of a day that the offence continues. The total of these daily fines may exceed $100,000 (Section 7.1.c).

  • For a multiple offence (two or more acts or omissions each constituting a separate offence), a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 for each offence included. The total of all fines for each included offence is not limited to $100,000 (Section 7.1.d).

  • It is explicitly stated that when multiple Private or Mature Trees are removed or cut, the removal or cutting of each tree is a separate offence (Section 7.2).

Compensation and Replanting

In addition to fines, the Director is authorized to require compensation for removed Mature Trees, either through:

  • Planting Replacement Trees on the same private property at specific ratios (e.g., 3:1 for 30-49cm DSH trees, 5:1 for 50cm+ DSH trees, or 1 replacement tree for every 10 cm in DSH removed) (Section 2.4.d.i).

  • Paying Cash-in-lieu Compensation if planting replacement trees is not feasible on the property. This cash-in-lieu would be used for planting additional trees or maintenance on municipal lands (Section 2.4.d.ii).

  • The court may also order the convicted person to replant any Private Tree(s) removed in a specified location and within a specified period, and/or apply any necessary Silvicultural Treatment to re-establish the tree(s) (Section 7.5.ii).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Consequences of Unauthorized Removal of a Protected Mature Tree by a Developer

If a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission in Whitchurch-Stouffville, it violates the Town's rules. This is addressed in By-law 2023-060, which protects trees on private property.

Prohibition and Conditions for Removal

  • Removing or cutting down a Heritage Tree on private property is always prohibited.

  • For Mature Trees (30 cm diameter or greater), removal is generally not allowed unless the Town's Director approves it through a Planning Act application.

  • Mature Trees may be removed if approved to allow for new development, if they are a hazard, a nuisance, diseased, structurally unsound, dying, or too close to other trees.

Enforcement and Penalties

Any person or corporation (like a developer) who violates By-law 2023-060 is guilty of an offence. The Town may take action and impose penalties:

Enforcement Orders

  • The Town may issue an Order requiring the person who violated the rules to fix the problem.

  • This can include stop work orders, orders to stop the violation, and orders to replant trees.

  • If an Order isn't followed, the Town may do the work and charge the person or corporation for the expenses.

Fines

Fines for violating By-law 2023-060 can be significant:

  • A first conviction carries a fine between $500 and $50,000.

  • A second or later conviction for the same offence carries a fine between $2,000 and $100,000.

  • For a continuing offence (violating an Order), a fine between $2,000 and $10,000 per day can be applied. The total of these daily fines may exceed $100,000.

  • For a multiple offence (two or more separate offences), a fine between $2,000 and $10,000 for each offence can be applied. The total of all fines is not limited to $100,000.

  • Removing or cutting down multiple Private or Mature Trees means that removing or cutting down each tree is a separate offence.

Compensation and Replanting

Besides fines, the Director can require compensation for removed Mature Trees, through:

  • Planting Replacement Trees on the same property (e.g., 3 replacement trees for each tree removed, or 1 replacement tree for every 10 cm in diameter removed).

  • Paying Cash-in-lieu Compensation if planting replacement trees isn't possible. This money would be used for planting or maintaining trees on Town land.

  • The court may also order the convicted person to replant any removed trees and/or provide care to help them grow.

original_data.query: What happens if a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and applicable penalties for unauthorized removal or destruction of a protected tree, specifically a mature tree, contravening municipal tree protection bylaws currently in effect. This includes investigation of potential violations concerning zoning ordinances, property standards, environmental protection regulations, and any applicable permit requirements or prohibitions related to tree removal without prior authorization. Determine compliance obligations and enforcement mechanisms, including remediation requirements and associated fines.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Unauthorized Removal of Protected Mature Trees by Developers

If a developer removes a protected mature tree without permission in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, particularly within Secondary Plan Areas where new development is proposed, several consequences may arise under By-law 2023-060.

Prohibition and Presumption of Contravention

  • The removal or cutting of Mature Trees on private property within approved Secondary Plan areas is generally prohibited unless permitted by the Town's Director and/or designate under specific circumstances (e.g., to accommodate new development, if the tree is a hazard, diseased, dead or dying, or for other good reasons deemed necessary by the Director).
  • If the removal, cutting, or injuring of Private or Mature Trees has taken place within a 60-month period prior to the submission of a Planning Act application, the owner is presumed to have contravened the by-law, unless evidence to the contrary is provided.

Enforcement Orders

A Municipal Law Enforcement Officer may issue various orders, including:

  • Orders to correct the contravention.
  • Stop work orders.
  • Orders establishing conditions to mitigate adverse impacts.
  • Orders for replanting or Silvicultural Treatment (care and maintenance of the tree and its habitat).
  • The Town may also suspend or revoke a permit for any violation of the by-law or its conditions.

Penalties and Fines

Any person, including a corporation, found guilty of an offence under By-law 2023-060 is subject to significant penalties:

  • Upon a first conviction, a fine of not less than $500 and not more than $50,000.
  • Upon a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence, a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $100,000.
  • For a continuing offence (where an order is not complied with), a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 for each day or part of a day that the offence continues. The total of these daily fines may exceed $100,000.
  • For a multiple offence (two or more acts or omissions each constituting an offence), a fine of not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 for each offence included. The total of all fines for each included offence is not limited to $100,000.
  • It is important to note that the removal or cutting of each Private or Mature Tree is considered a separate offence.

Cost Recovery and Court Orders

  • If an owner fails to comply with an order, the Town may cause the required work to be done at the owner's expense. These expenses, including any administrative or additional fees, can be recovered from the person(s) or corporation and may be added to the property's tax roll.
  • In addition to fines, the Ontario Court of Justice or any court of competent jurisdiction may issue an order prohibiting the continuation or repetition of the offence. The court may also require the convicted person to correct the contravention, which can include ordering the planting or replanting of removed trees in a specified location and timeframe, and the application of necessary Silvicultural Treatment to re-establish the trees.

original_data.query: How long I can park my car on streets during daytime

original_data.filtered_answer:
General Parking Duration

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, unless otherwise specified by signage or specific by-laws, you are generally prohibited from parking any vehicle on any highway for a period longer than three (3) hours. This general regulation is outlined in by-laws such as 2009-007 and 2021-100, which amend the main parking by-law 2008-114-PR.

Specific Daytime Parking Regulations

  • Main Street: On Main Street, in areas between the Albert Street intersection and Park Drive intersection, Park Drive intersection and a point 46 metres east, and Cemetery Lane intersection and Tenth Line, parking is permitted for a maximum of 3 hours from Monday to Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. This is specified in 2018-038. Additionally, 2020-137 indicates a 3-hour maximum for Main Street between Albert Street and Park Drive from 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.
  • Residential Neighbourhoods: In residential neighbourhoods, parking is generally limited to a maximum of 3 hours from 2:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m., as per 2020-137.

Locations with "Anytime" Parking Exceptions

Certain specific locations have exceptions to the general three-hour parking limit, allowing for parking at any time. These include:

  • Park Drive North: On the west side, from the Main Street Intersection to a point 121 feet (37 metres) northerly, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 1988-139.
  • Brown Lane:
    • South side, between #5 and #35 Brown Lane: Anytime parking permitted.
    • East side, between #32 (flankage) and #58 Brown Lane: Anytime parking permitted.
    These exceptions are noted in 2024-095.
  • Betula Gate: On the west side, between #6 and #22 Brown Lane (flankage), Anytime parking is permitted, as per 2024-095.
  • Delbert Circle: On the east side, between #23 and #101 (flankage), Anytime parking is permitted, as per 2024-095.
  • Fernglen Crescent: On the west side, between #93 and #113 Fernglen Crescent, Anytime parking is permitted, as per 2024-095.
  • Lakeshore Road: On both sides, between the intersection of Ninth Line and the intersection of Highway 48, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-079.
  • Byers Pond Way: On the east side, between #29 Byers Pond Way and #53 Byers Pond Way, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-079.
  • Churchill Drive East: On both sides, from the intersection of Ninth Line to the end of the road, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-079.
  • Mill Street: On the east side, from Main Street to the North End, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-137.
  • Frederick Street: On the south side, from 35 metres East of Mill Street to Church Street, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-137.
  • George Street: On the south/east side, from Mill Street to Church Street, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-137.
  • James Ratcliff Avenue: On the east/south/north side, from 9 meters North of Isabella Garden Lane to #141 James Ratcliff Avenue, parking is permitted Anytime, as per 2020-137.
  • Dougherty Crescent:
    • South/West side, from 40 metres east of Jamesway Crescent to #122 Dougherty Crescent: Anytime parking permitted.
    • South/West side, from the East end of Dougherty Crescent Parkette to #84 Dougherty Crescent: Anytime parking permitted.
    These exceptions are noted in 2020-137.
  • Jamesway Crescent: On the south/west side, from #46 Jamesway Crescent to #74 Jamesway Crescent, Anytime parking is permitted, as per 2020-137.
  • Win Timbers Crescent: On the north/west side, from James McCullough Road to #55 Win Timbers Crescent, Anytime parking is permitted, as per 2020-137.

Seasonal or Time-Specific Restrictions

Please be aware that some areas have specific "No Parking" or "No Stopping" restrictions during certain hours or seasons, which would override general parking durations. For example:

  • On Dougherty Crescent (East side, parallel to Ninth Line), Miltrose Crescent (East side, parallel to the GO Transit corridor), James Ratcliff Avenue (South side, adjacent to stormwater management block/valley view corridor), and Brill Court (cul-de-sac), there is no parking from December 1 to March 31, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. (2009-007, 2021-100).
  • On Clark Street (West Side, 45m South of Main Street Intersection of Clarke Street and Sunset Boulevard), there is no parking Monday - Friday 8:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m. (2015-001).
  • On Gladys Clarkson Boulevard (East Side, from Hoover Park Drive Fernglen Crescent), there is no stopping September 1st to June 30th, Monday-Friday 8:30 a.m. - 9:30 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. (2017-003).
  • On Hoover Park Drive (North and South Sides, from Yakefarm Blvd. to 135M West) and Yakefarm Blvd (East Side, from Hoover Park Drive to Fairlee Circle), there is no parking Monday - Friday 8:00 a.m. - 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. (2015-089).
  • On Daws Hare Crescent, Harriet Crescent, and Robertdale Court (all both sides, from intersection of Northway Ave. to intersection of Northway Ave. or end of road), there is no parking Monday to Friday 9:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. (2020-079).
  • On Greenwood Road (Both sides, between Alderwood Street and Forsyth Farm Drive), there is no stopping Monday to Friday 7:30 a.m. to 9:15 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. (2022-026).

For specific locations, it is always advisable to check local signage.

original_data.query: What's the fine if I cut down a Mature Tree without getting Town approval first?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the applicable penalty or fine, as stipulated within current and recently enacted municipal bylaws, for the unauthorized removal, destruction, or damage of a Mature Tree, as defined by relevant zoning ordinances and tree protection bylaws, specifically without prior issuance of required permits or approvals from the Town. This inquiry pertains to compliance with regulations governing property rights, environmental protection, and potential violations related to tree cutting prohibitions.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Fines for Cutting Down a Mature Tree Without Town Approval

The fine for cutting down a Mature Tree without Town approval in Whitchurch-Stouffville depends on the specific circumstances, as different by-laws may apply. Please refer to the details below:

Under By-law 2023-060: Private Tree Preservation and Protection By-law related to Development Applications

This by-law applies to the protection of Private, Mature, and Heritage Trees on private property within settlement areas covered by an approved Secondary Plan, specifically when new development requiring a Planning Act application (Site Plan, Subdivision, Consent) is proposed. A "Mature Tree" is defined as any Private Tree with a Diameter at Standard Height (DSH) of 30 cm or greater.

  • For a first conviction, the fine ranges from $500 to $50,000.
  • For a second or subsequent conviction for the same offence, the fine ranges from $2,000 to $100,000.
  • For a continuing offence (where the contravention continues each day), the fine is not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 per day. The total of these daily fines may exceed $100,000.
  • For a multiple offence (where the removal/cutting of each Private or Mature Tree is considered a separate offence), the fine is not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 for each offence. The total of all fines for each included offence is not limited to $100,000.

Under By-law 2006-001: Tree Permit By-law

This by-law applies to privately owned lands within the Town that are not already governed by the Regional Municipality of York's Forest Conservation By-law. It requires a permit to injure or destroy any tree with a tree diameter greater than 20 centimetres or a base diameter greater than 40 centimetres.

  • For an individual (Person):
    • On a first conviction, the fine is not more than $10,000 or $1,000 per tree, whichever is greater.
    • On any subsequent conviction, the fine is not more than $25,000 or $2,500 per tree, whichever is greater.
  • For a corporation:
    • On a first conviction, the fine is not more than $50,000 or $5,000 per tree, whichever is greater.
    • On any subsequent conviction, the fine is not more than $100,000 or $10,000 per tree, whichever is greater.

Please note that the specific by-law and penalty applicable will depend on the location of the tree and whether the removal is associated with a development application.

  • Second offence: $2,000 to $100,000.
  • If the offence continues daily: $2,000 to $10,000 per day (total fines can exceed $100,000).
  • If you cut down multiple trees: $2,000 to $10,000 per tree (total fines not limited to $100,000).

original_data.query: When does the Town collect yard waste like leaves and branches?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the scheduled collection of organic waste, specifically leaf and branch material, within the Town's municipal boundaries. Pursuant to applicable waste management bylaws, property maintenance regulations, and public health ordinances, what are the designated dates, frequency, and procedures for curbside collection of yard waste? This request seeks clarification on resident obligations and Town responsibilities concerning vegetative debris disposal, referencing current and recently amended bylaws.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Yard Waste Collection

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville collects yard waste, such as leaves and branches, once every other week. The specific collection dates are determined by the Town.

Yard Waste Container Requirements

According to By-law 2018-035 and By-law 2004-096, yard waste must be set out for collection in one of the following approved receptacles:

  • Paper bags: These must be Kraft paper bags designed for yard waste, and the total weight when full must not exceed 22 kg (50 pounds).
  • Reusable, non-absorbent open-top containers: These plastic containers must have two open rigid handles and a "Yard Waste" sticker affixed to them. The container's diameter should not exceed 50 cm (20 inches) or a height of 90 cm (36 inches). The diameter at the top must be larger than the bottom. The total weight of any full receptacle, including its contents, must not exceed 22 kg (50 pounds). Please note that blue or green bins are not considered acceptable yard waste containers and will not be collected for yard waste.
  • Securely tied bundles: Branches, twigs, and cuttings can be bundled. These bundles must not exceed 1.2 meters (4 feet) in length, 60 cm (24 inches) in diameter, or 10 cm (4 inches) in diameter per branch. The total weight of a bundle must not exceed 22 kg (50 pounds).

There is no limit to the quantity of yard waste that may be set out for collection from a residential property, as stated in By-law 2018-035.
original_data.laymans_answer:

The Town collects yard waste, like leaves and branches, every other week. Contact the Town for specific collection dates.

Yard Waste Container Requirements

Yard waste must be placed in approved containers:

  • Paper bags: Use Kraft paper bags for yard waste, weighing no more than 22 kg (50 pounds) when full.
  • Reusable containers: Use open-top plastic containers with two rigid handles and a "Yard Waste" sticker. Containers must be no larger than 50 cm (20 inches) in diameter and 90 cm (36 inches) in height, with a wider top than bottom, and weigh no more than 22 kg (50 pounds) full. Blue or green bins are not acceptable.
  • Bundles: Tie branches, twigs, and cuttings into bundles no longer than 1.2 meters (4 feet) in length and 60 cm (24 inches) in diameter, with individual branches no thicker than 10 cm (4 inches). Bundles must weigh no more than 22 kg (50 pounds).

There is no limit to the amount of yard waste you can put out for collection.

original_data.query: Can I park my car facing the wrong way on the street?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility of parking a motor vehicle in contravention of the designated direction of travel on a public roadway within the Town's jurisdiction, pursuant to applicable Traffic and Parking Bylaws, specifically concerning regulations governing vehicle orientation, directionality, and obstruction of traffic flow. Determine if any exemptions or conditional permissions exist under current or recently amended bylaws, considering potential impacts on public safety, accessibility, and emergency vehicle access.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Direction on Highways

No person shall park any vehicle on any highway with the front of the vehicle facing opposite to the direction in which vehicular traffic is proceeding on that side of the street. This regulation is outlined in By-law 2008-114, as amended by By-law 2017-027.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking Direction on Highways

You cannot park your car on any street facing against the normal direction of traffic flow on that side of the street.

original_data.query: How close to a fire hydrant can I legally park?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissible proximity for vehicle parking relative to a fire hydrant, pursuant to Town bylaws governing traffic, parking regulations, and public safety. Specifically, what is the minimum allowable distance, measured in meters or feet, a vehicle may be parked from a fire hydrant on Town roadways or public property, considering current and recently amended bylaws pertaining to obstruction of emergency services access and fire code compliance?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Near a Fire Hydrant

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, you are not permitted to park a vehicle within three (3) metres of a point on the curb or edge of the roadway nearest to any fire hydrant. This regulation is outlined in Section 6(a)(ii) of By-law 2008-114-PR.

Penalty for Violation

If you park in contravention of this rule, an administrative penalty will be issued. As per Schedule A, Item 8 of By-law 2024-039-RE (the Administrative Monetary Penalty System By-law), the set penalty for parking within 3 metres of a fire hydrant is $100.00 for a first, second, or third offence.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking Near a Fire Hydrant

You are not permitted to park a vehicle within three (3) metres of a fire hydrant.

Penalty for Violation

If you park too close to a fire hydrant, the penalty is $100.00.

original_data.query: How high am I able to build a fence in my backyard? Provide the answer in feet.
original_data.transformed_query: Pursuant to the Town's Zoning Bylaw and any applicable Fencing Bylaws currently in force, what is the maximum permissible height, measured in feet, for a fence erected on residential property within the rear yard setback area? This inquiry pertains to compliance with regulations governing property line fencing, potential obstructions, and any relevant provisions concerning sight triangles or public safety considerations, as amended to the present date.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Fence Height in Residential Rear Yards

For a fence located in your rear yard in a residential area, the maximum height permitted is 2.2 metres, which is approximately 7.2 feet. This regulation is outlined in Section 4.1 of By-law 2013-168, the Town's Fence and Pool Enclosure Regulation.

Please note the following general provisions from By-law 2013-168 regarding fences:

  • Fences must be maintained in a structurally sound and safe condition and in good repair (Section 2.5).
  • Certain materials are prohibited, such as sheet metal or corrugated metal panel members, and materials not usually intended for permanent fencing (Section 2.1).
  • Barbed wire or razor wire is generally prohibited, except in Employment Heavy zones where it must be at least 1.8 metres (approximately 5.9 feet) above grade (Section 2.2).
  • Electrified fences are prohibited, except for agricultural uses in rural areas for animal containment (Section 2.3).
  • Fences must not obstruct the vision of drivers or detract from the visibility of traffic signs (Section 2.4).

Specific exceptions apply for fences acting as a guard on a retaining wall (maximum 1.8 metres above the wall) and tennis court fencing in a rear yard (maximum 3.6 metres).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Fence Height in Residential Rear Yards

In residential areas, your backyard fence can be a maximum of 7.2 feet high.

Please note the following:

  • Fences must be structurally sound and in good repair.
  • Certain materials like sheet metal or corrugated metal are prohibited.
  • Barbed wire or razor wire is generally not allowed, except in some industrial zones where it must be at least 5.9 feet above the ground.
  • Electrified fences are prohibited, except on farms for livestock.
  • Fences cannot block drivers' views or traffic signs.

There are exceptions for fences that act as a guard on a retaining wall (maximum height of 5.9 feet above the wall) and for tennis court fencing in a rear yard (maximum height of approximately 11.8 feet).

original_data.query: What are the rules about putting garbage out for collection?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding regulations governing the placement of refuse and recyclable materials for municipal waste collection services. Specifically, what are the provisions concerning permissible set-out times, approved container types, location restrictions on public and private property, prohibitions against scavenging, and compliance requirements under the Waste Management Bylaw and related Public Health and Property Standards bylaws, as amended and currently in force.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Garbage Collection Rules in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville has specific rules for putting out garbage and other waste for collection, as outlined in By-law 2018-035.

Collection Limits

  • For residential premises, including registered Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs), you may set out a maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags per dwelling unit. The total number of containers/bags, whether tagged or untagged, must not exceed six (6) per dwelling unit (Section 5.1, 5.4).
  • For commercial or institutional premises, a maximum of three (3) untagged garbage containers/bags are permitted per collection day. The total number of containers/bags, tagged or untagged, must not exceed six (6) (Section 5.2).
  • Commercial or institutional premises within the Downtown Stouffville Collection Area may set out a maximum of six (6) untagged garbage containers/bags per collection day (Section 5.3).
  • For bulk items, a maximum of four (4) may be set out per collection day (Section 5.5).
  • There is no limit on the quantity of blue box recyclables, source separated organics (green bin), or yard waste that may be set out for collection from a residential property (Section 5.11).
  • Additional garbage containers/bags beyond the untagged limit will not be collected unless pay-for-service tags have been affixed to them (Section 5.1, 5.2, 5.4). These tags can be purchased from the Town or its designates (Section 8.3).
  • If you have refuse in excess of these limits, you must dispose of it at your own expense via a private service provider operating under a Certificate of Approval (Section 5.6).

Set-Out and Removal Times

  • Approved containers and bundles must be placed at the curb or pavement edge no earlier than 5:00 p.m. on the day immediately preceding the collection day (Section 4.7).
  • They must be placed out no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection (Section 4.7).
  • All emptied receptacles and uncollected refuse must be removed from the curb or pavement edge before 8:00 p.m. on the day of collection (Section 4.7).
  • Containers should be placed as close as possible to the curb or pavement edge, without obstructing vehicular or pedestrian traffic or street maintenance, and should not be placed on top of snow banks (Section 4.6).

Container Specifications

  • Garbage Containers: Must be rigid plastic with two open rigid handles, a capacity of no more than 125 litres, and a total weight with contents not exceeding 22 kg (50 lbs). Plastic film garbage bags are also permitted, with a capacity of no more than 125 litres and a total weight with contents not exceeding 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 1.24, 7.1). Garbage must be placed in securely covered containers or bags (Section 6.8).
  • Blue Bins (Recycling): Must be open-topped plastic containers, clearly identifiable for recyclables, capable of containing all materials without spillage. They should not exceed 53 cm (21 inches) in height, 40 cm (16 inches) in width, 48 cm (19 inches) in length, or 83 litres (22 gallons) (Section 1.5, 7.2.1). Magazines, newspapers, cardboard, boxboard, and other waste paper may also be securely tied in bundles or placed in cardboard boxes for overflow, not larger than 90 cm x 90 cm x 20 cm (36" x 36" x 8") (Section 7.2.2). Plastic or compostable bags are prohibited for blue box material (Section 7.7).
  • Green Bins (Source Separated Organics): Must be clearly identifiable as containing Source Separated Organics and must contain certified compostable bags. They should not exceed 69 cm (27 inches) in height, 40 cm (16 inches) in width, 46 cm (18 inches) in length, or 45 litres (12 gallons). The total weight when full must not exceed 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 1.25, 7.3).
  • Yard Waste: Must be contained in a returnable plastic container with a "Yard Waste" sticker (max 50 cm diameter, 90 cm height, 22 kg) or a Kraft paper bag (max 22 kg). Branches, twigs, and cuttings may be set out in securely tied bundles not exceeding 1.2 meters (4 feet) in length, 60 cm (24 inches) in diameter, or 10 cm (4 inches) in diameter per branch, and weighing no more than 22 kg (50 lbs) (Section 7.5). Blue or green bins are not considered acceptable yard waste containers and will not be collected (Section 7.5.1).
  • Any receptacle that is broken or breaks when lifted will not be collected (Section 7.6).

Prohibited Materials and Special Items

  • Do not set out receptacles containing liquids, warm ashes, electronics, or hazardous waste (Section 4.8).
  • A detailed list of waste material classifications, including non-collectible waste and hazardous waste, is provided in Schedule 'A' of By-law 2018-035. Examples of non-collectible waste include acute hazardous waste, batteries, car parts, construction material, earth and sod, grass clippings, propane tanks, tree stumps, and tires.
  • Electronic Waste (e.g., computers, televisions, cell phones) is non-collectible through regular curbside pickup and is accepted at drop-off locations only (Schedule C).
  • For Special Waste (e.g., furniture, large metal items), you must call the contractor in advance to arrange for collection (Section 7.4.1).
  • When setting out metal appliances, you must first remove any door, lid, or cover that cannot be easily opened from the inside, and take other precautionary measures to prevent a person from being trapped inside (Section 6.7).

Non-Compliance and Penalties

  • If refuse is not set out in accordance with By-law 2018-035, the contractor may refuse to collect it. It is then the responsibility of the person who set it out to comply with the by-law (Section 6.4).
  • If garbage, recyclables, or organics are tipped, blown, or knocked over prior to collection, the person who set them out is responsible for cleaning up the material. If the Town is required to clean it up, applicable fees will be charged (Section 8.5).
  • Unpaid fees for Town services related to waste collection may be added to the property's tax roll (Section 8.6).
  • Contravention of any provision of By-law 2018-035, including an order issued under it, is an offence. Penalties include a minimum fine of $350 for a first conviction, $500 for a second or subsequent conviction, and up to $10,000 per day for continuing or multiple offences, with a maximum fine of $100,000 (Section 11.5).
  • The Town may issue orders to discontinue contraventions or work orders to correct them. If an owner fails to comply, the Town may perform the work and recover costs by adding them to the property taxes (Section 10.1, 10.2, 10.3).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Garbage Collection Rules in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Whitchurch-Stouffville has rules for garbage collection.

Collection Limits

  • Residential: Max 3 untagged bags/containers. Total (tagged or untagged) max 6.
  • Commercial/Institutional: Max 3 untagged bags/containers. Total (tagged or untagged) max 6.
  • Downtown Stouffville (Commercial/Institutional): Max 6 untagged bags/containers.
  • Bulk items: Max 4.
  • Recyclables, organics, yard waste: No limit.
  • Extra garbage requires special tags, available from the Town.
  • Dispose of excess refuse using a private service.

Set-Out and Removal Times

  • Earliest set out: 5:00 p.m. the day before collection.
  • Latest set out: 7:00 a.m. on collection day.
  • Remove emptied containers by 8:00 p.m. on collection day.
  • Place containers near the curb without blocking traffic; do not place on snow banks.

Container Specifications

  • Garbage Containers: Rigid plastic with handles, max 125 litres, max 22 kg (50 lbs), or plastic bags, max 125 litres, max 22 kg (50 lbs). Garbage must be in covered containers or bags.
  • Blue Bins (Recycling): Open-topped, identified for recyclables, no spillage, and within size limits. Bundled paper/cardboard is allowed for overflow. No plastic or compostable bags.
  • Green Bins (Organics): Identified for organics, certified compostable bags only, and within size limits. Max 22 kg (50 lbs).
  • Yard Waste: Returnable plastic container with "Yard Waste" sticker (size/weight limits) or Kraft paper bag (weight limit). Bundled branches (size/weight limits). No blue or green bins.
  • Broken containers will not be collected.

Prohibited Materials and Special Items

  • No liquids, warm ashes, electronics, or hazardous waste.
  • Electronic waste must be taken to drop-off locations.
  • For Special Waste (furniture, metal), call in advance for collection.
  • Remove doors from appliances.

Non-Compliance and Penalties

  • Unacceptable refuse may be refused. The resident is responsible for compliance.
  • Residents are responsible for cleaning up spilled refuse. The Town will charge fees for cleanup.
  • Unpaid fees may be added to property taxes.
  • Violations may result in fines.
  • The Town may issue orders and recover costs for non-compliance.

original_data.query: what is the overnight parking requirements
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulations governing overnight parking within the Town's jurisdictional boundaries. Specifically, what are the applicable prohibitions, permissions, and restrictions pertaining to the parking of vehicles on municipal roadways, public property, and private property between the hours of [Specify Start Time] and [Specify End Time]? Reference relevant sections of the Traffic Bylaw, Zoning Bylaw, and any other applicable municipal regulations concerning vehicle storage, obstruction of roadways, and public safety, considering the most recently enacted amendments.
original_data.filtered_answer:
General Overnight Parking Regulations

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, the following general parking regulations apply:

  • No person shall park any vehicle on any highway for a period longer than three (3) hours, unless specifically exempted in Schedule III (Three (3) Hour Parking Exceptions) of By-law 2008-114, as amended.
  • During the winter months, from December 1st of each year to March 31st of the following year, no person shall park any vehicle on any highway under the jurisdiction of the Town at any time during the hours of 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. (By-law 2008-114, Section 17(a)).
  • No person shall park or leave a motor vehicle on private property without the consent of the owner or occupant of such property (By-law 2008-114, Section 18(a)(i)).

Exceptions to Winter Overnight Parking Prohibition (2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m., December 1st to March 31st)

The winter overnight parking prohibition does not apply to the following specific locations:

  • The portion of Church Street south of Main Street (By-law 2008-114, Section 17(b)).
  • The following locations, where Section 17 (On Street Parking - Winter Months) of By-law 2008-114-PR does not apply (By-law 2024-001):
    • Dougherty Crescent:
      • East side, between #80 and #126 Dougherty Crescent (Anytime)
      • North side, between Weldon Road and #73 Dougherty Crescent (Anytime)
      • South side, between Weldon Road and #127 Dougherty Crescent (Anytime)
    • Firbank Lane:
      • North side, between #3 and #23 Firbank Lane (Anytime)
      • West side, between #26 and #100 Firbank Lane (Anytime)
    • Hoppington Avenue: West & South sides, between Mantle Avenue and Firbank Lane (Anytime)
    • Jamesway Crescent: East & North sides, between Weldon Road and Dougherty Crescent (Anytime)
  • The following locations, where parking is permitted daily from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m., thereby covering the overnight winter parking period (By-law 2021-100, Schedule A):
    • Brill Court: Along the cul-de-sac
    • Dougherty Crescent: East side, parallel to the Ninth Line
    • James Ratcliff Avenue: South/West side, adjacent to the stormwater management block
    • Miltrose Crescent: East side, parallel to the GO Transit Corridor

Please note that while some areas like "Residential Neighbourhoods" and "Main Street (Albert Street to Park Drive)" are listed as exceptions to the three-hour parking rule, their permitted parking times (Daily 9 p.m. to 2 a.m. and Daily 6 p.m. to 2 a.m. respectively) do not extend through the entire 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. winter overnight prohibition period. Therefore, the winter overnight parking ban still applies to these areas.

  • From December 1st to March 31st, you can't park on any Town highway between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.

original_data.query: Can I put up one of those big inflatable tube guys outside my store for our anniversary sale?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility of deploying an inflatable advertising device, specifically a dynamically moving, air-filled tube figure, on commercial property within the Town, for the purpose of promoting an anniversary sale. This inquiry pertains to compliance with applicable zoning bylaws, sign regulations, temporary structure provisions, and any relevant sections concerning visual clutter, public safety, and nuisance abatement, as currently enacted and recently amended. Determine any permit requirements, restrictions on size, location, duration, and operational characteristics governing such devices.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Inflatable Sign Regulations for Your Business

Yes, you may be able to put up an inflatable sign for your anniversary sale, but it is subject to specific regulations and requires a permit from the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. The rules for inflatable signs are primarily outlined in By-law 2016-165, which regulates portable, mobile, banner, feather banner, inflatable, and temporary signs.

Permitted Locations and Permit Requirements

  • Inflatable signs are permitted on properties located in commercial, employment, or institutional zones.
  • A valid sign permit must be obtained from the Town before erecting the sign.

Key Restrictions and Conditions

If your property is located within a commercial, employment, or institutional zone, the following restrictions apply to inflatable signs:

  • Permit Duration: A permit for an inflatable sign will be issued for a period not exceeding 30 days.
  • Frequency: No more than two (2) permits may be issued for the same owner, tenant, or occupant at the same location in any calendar year.
  • Multiple Occupancy: If your premises are occupied by more than one owner or tenant, only one (1) permit will be issued for the same period of time for the entire premises.
  • Placement:
    • Power cords and/or supporting devices for inflatable signs shall not be placed on or over parking areas or pedestrian areas.
    • Inflatable signs shall not be placed on a parking space, aisle, or pedestrian areas.
  • Removal: Upon the expiry of a permit for an inflatable sign, the inflatable sign must be immediately removed.

Downtown Stouffville Special Sign District

Please note that inflatable signs are not permitted in the Special Sign District known as "Downtown Stouffville," as indicated in Schedule "A" of By-law 2016-165 and By-law 2016-012. If your store is located within this district, you would not be able to use an inflatable sign.

Application Requirements for a Sign Permit

To apply for an inflatable sign permit, you will need to provide the following to the Clerk or designate, as per Section 11 of By-law 2016-165:

  • One completed copy of the permit application form as prescribed by the Clerk or designate.
  • A diagram showing the street lines and boundaries of your property, and the proposed location of the inflatable sign in relation to other signs and structures on the property. The Clerk or designate may require this diagram and information to be certified by a registered Ontario Land Surveyor.
  • A letter of consent from the owner of the property or the property manager/agent authorizing you to erect the inflatable sign(s) in compliance with municipal by-laws.

All municipal fees for administration and enforcement activities related to this by-law are subject to the rates and fees set out in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's current Fees and Charges By-law, and application fees are due upon submission of an application.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Inflatable Sign Regulations for Your Business

You may be able to put up an inflatable sign for your anniversary sale, but it is subject to regulations and requires a permit from the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. By-law 2016-165 regulates inflatable signs.

Permitted Locations and Permit Requirements

  • Inflatable signs are permitted on properties in commercial, employment, or institutional zones.
  • You must get a sign permit from the Town before putting up the sign.

Key Restrictions and Conditions

If your property is in a commercial, employment, or institutional zone, these restrictions apply:

  • Permit Duration: A permit for an inflatable sign lasts for up to 30 days.
  • Frequency: You can only get two (2) permits per year for the same location.
  • Multiple Occupancy: If more than one business occupies the premises, only one (1) permit will be issued for the entire premises at a time.
  • Placement:
    • Power cords and supports cannot be placed on parking or pedestrian areas.
    • Inflatable signs cannot be placed in parking spaces, aisles, or pedestrian areas.
  • Removal: The inflatable sign must be removed immediately after the permit expires.

Downtown Stouffville Special Sign District

Inflatable signs are not permitted in the "Downtown Stouffville" area. If your store is in this area, you cannot use an inflatable sign.

Application Requirements for a Sign Permit

To apply for a permit, you need to provide:

  • A completed permit application form.
  • A diagram showing your property lines and the sign's location relative to other signs and structures.
  • A letter of consent from the property owner or manager.

Application fees are due when you submit your application.

original_data.query: Can i ride roller blades in the sidewalks
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility, under current and recently enacted municipal bylaws of the Town, of operating or using roller blades, in-line skates, or similar wheeled recreational devices on public sidewalks or pedestrian walkways. Specifically, does any bylaw pertaining to traffic, pedestrian safety, public thoroughfares, parks and recreation, or nuisance prohibit or regulate such activity? Request clarification regarding any applicable restrictions, obligations, or permissions governing the use of such devices on municipal property.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Rollerblading on Sidewalks in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Based on the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's by-laws, you may ride rollerblades on sidewalks. The By-law 2008-147, which regulates traffic, specifies restrictions for roller skates and similar devices on roadways, but not on sidewalks.

  • Section 4(c) of By-law 2008-147 states that no person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon a roadway except for the purpose of crossing the roadway. When crossing a roadway, such a person has the rights and is subject to the obligations of a pedestrian. This implies that rollerblading on sidewalks is generally permitted, as the restriction is specifically for the roadway.
  • However, it is important to note that By-law 1998-146, which amends regulations for parks, prohibits rollerskating, rollerblading, or skateboarding in public parks unless specific areas are designated for such purposes.

Any contravention of these by-laws may result in a fine as provided for pursuant to the Provincial Offences Act.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Rollerblading on Sidewalks in Whitchurch-Stouffville

Yes, you can rollerblade on sidewalks in Whitchurch-Stouffville.

  • You cannot rollerblade on roads, except to cross them as a pedestrian.
  • Rollerblading is not allowed in public parks unless there are designated areas.

Breaking these rules may result in a fine.

original_data.query: airsoft
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility, regulation, and potential prohibition of airsoft activities, including the discharge of airsoft projectiles, within the Town's jurisdictional boundaries. This inquiry encompasses relevant bylaws pertaining to public safety, noise control, firearms regulations (if applicable), parks and recreation area usage, zoning ordinances governing permissible land use, and any temporal restrictions or amendments to said bylaws currently in effect or recently enacted.

Regulation of Airsoft Devices in Whitchurch-Stouffville

While "airsoft" is not explicitly mentioned in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville's by-laws, devices such as airsoft guns, which discharge projectiles, may fall under the definition of "Firearm" or "weapon" as regulated by existing by-laws.

Discharge of Firearms and Bows

By-law 2019-119, titled "BEING A BY-LAW to regulate the discharge of Firearms within the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville," defines a "Firearm" as "a barrelled weapon from which any shot, bullet or other projectile can be discharged that is capable of causing bodily injury or death to a Person, and includes any frame or receiver of such a barrelled weapon and anything that can be adapted for use as a firearm, and includes shotguns, rifles, air guns, spring guns or any class thereof." Given this definition, airsoft guns would likely be considered firearms under this by-law.

The by-law generally prohibits the discharge of any Firearm or Bow within the Town, with specific exceptions. These exceptions include:

  • A Peace Officer, Conservation Officer, or Deputy Conservation Officer in the course of their duties.
  • A landowner or tenant, or an Agent with prior written permission, for the Protection of Property from nuisance wildlife, under specific conditions regarding the location (outside or within "Defined Areas" with minimum land size and zoning requirements) and ensuring no bullet or shot passes over the boundary of the lands.
  • A landowner or occupier of land, or a licensed hunter or Trapper with prior written permission, for hunting or trapping purposes, specifically for the protection of crops or agriculture, on lands within the Defined Areas used for agriculture, provided the owner has a valid Farm Business Registration number and no bullet or shot passes over the boundary.
  • The owner or occupier of land, or a licensed hunter or Trapper with prior written permission, on lands within the Town and outside the Defined Areas, provided the parcel of land is no less than 25 acres in size, for hunting, trapping, or target shooting, and no shot or bullet passes over the boundary.
  • The owner or occupier of land or a licensed hunter with prior written permission, on lands outside the Defined Area or within the Defined Areas (if the parcel is no less than 10 acres), for the purpose of hunting or target shooting with a Bow, provided no bolt or arrow passes over the boundary.
  • A Person firing blank ammunition which does not discharge a projectile for lawful use in motion pictures, television, stage productions, historical plays, or for starting/controlling sporting events.

Additionally, By-law 2019-119 prohibits the discharge of a Firearm or Bow within 200 metres of the periphery of any Educational Property used for educational purposes, with an exception for properties used for instruction in the proper use of Firearms or Bows.

Weapons in Parks

By-law 2020-087, the Parks By-law, defines "weapon" as "anything used, designed to be used or intended for use in causing death or injury to any person or animal, or anything used, designed to be used or intended for use for the purpose of threatening or intimidating any person and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, includes any firearm." This by-law explicitly states that "No person shall... carry a weapon in a park." Therefore, carrying an airsoft gun in a Town park would be prohibited under this by-law.

For any specific inquiries regarding the application of these by-laws to a particular situation or property, it is recommended to consult the full text of By-law 2019-119 and By-law 2020-087.

Discharge of Firearms

By-law 2019-119 prohibits the discharge of any Firearm or Bow within certain "Defined Areas" of the Town. There are specific exceptions to this prohibition:

  • Peace Officers, Conservation Officers, or Deputy Conservation Officers: When discharging in the course of their duties.

  • Landowners, Tenants, or Agents: Discharge of a Firearm is permitted on lands outside the Defined Areas. Within the Defined Areas, discharge is permitted for the Protection of Property from nuisance wildlife, provided the parcel of land is a minimum of 10 acres in size and within a zone of Section 4 of the Town's Zoning By-law, and no bullet or shot passes over the boundary of the lands.

  • Landowners, Occupiers, Licensed Hunters, or Trappers: Discharge of a Firearm for hunting or trapping is permitted for the protection of crops or agriculture on lands within the Defined Areas, provided the land is used for agriculture, the owner/occupier has a valid Farm Business Registration number, and no bullet or shot passes over the boundary.

  • Landowners, Occupiers, Licensed Hunters, or Trappers: Discharge of a Firearm for hunting, trapping, or target shooting is permitted on lands within the Town and outside the Defined Areas, provided the parcel is no less than 25 acres in size and no shot or bullet passes over the boundary.

  • Landowners, Occupiers, or Licensed Hunters: Discharge of a Bow for hunting or target shooting is permitted on lands outside the Defined Area or within the Defined Areas, provided the parcel is no less than 10 acres in size and no bolt or arrow passes over the boundary.

Additionally, no person authorized to discharge a Firearm or Bow under these exceptions shall discharge it within 200 metres of the periphery of any Educational Property used for educational purposes, unless the property is used for instruction in the proper use of Firearms or Bows.

Carrying Weapons in Parks

By-law 2020-087, which regulates the use of Parks, Trails, Park Buildings, and Open Spaces, prohibits carrying a "weapon" in a park. A "weapon" is defined broadly to include "anything used, designed to be used or intended for use in causing death or injury to any person or animal, or anything used, designed to be used or intended for use for the purpose of threatening or intimidating any person and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, includes any firearm." Therefore, if an airsoft device is considered a "firearm" or "weapon" under these definitions, its possession in parks would be prohibited.

Exemptions and Penalties

Council may grant exemptions from the provisions of By-law 2019-119 by resolution, which may include specific terms and conditions. Contraventions of By-law 2019-119 are subject to penalties, including fines ranging from $250.00 to $100,000.00, as outlined in Section 7 of the by-law.
