original_data.filtered_answer:
General Parking Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

The general parking regulations in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, which apply to most streets unless otherwise specified by signage or specific by-laws, are as follows:

  • General Parking Limit: Unless otherwise indicated by signs or specific by-law exceptions, you are generally prohibited from parking a vehicle on any highway for a period longer than three (3) hours. This regulation is outlined in Section 6(a)(v) of By-law 2008-114.
  • Residential Neighbourhood Exception: In residential neighbourhoods, there is an exception to the three-hour parking rule. Parking is permitted for longer than three hours daily from 9:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m., unless otherwise posted. This exception is detailed in Schedule III of By-law 2008-114, as amended by By-law 2021-100. This means that from 2:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m., the three-hour parking limit generally applies in residential areas.
  • Winter Parking Restrictions: Annually, from December 1st to March 31st, parking is prohibited on any highway under the Town's jurisdiction between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. This restriction is stated in Section 17(a) of By-law 2008-114. Please note that there are specific exceptions to this winter parking rule for certain streets, as noted in Section 17(c) of By-law 2008-114 and further amended by By-law 2024-001.

It is important to always check for any posted signs on your specific street, as these signs may indicate additional or different parking restrictions that supersede the general rules.
original_data.laymans_answer:

original_data.query: What happens if I don't pay my water bill?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the regulatory consequences and enforcement mechanisms pertaining to the non-payment of municipal water utility charges, fees, and rates. Specifically, what are the penalties, fines, or service discontinuations authorized under relevant bylaws, including those related to public health, property standards, and utility service provision, for failure to remit payment for water services within prescribed timeframes, according to the currently enacted bylaws and regulations?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Consequences of Unpaid Water Bills in Whitchurch-Stouffville

If you do not pay your water bill in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, several actions may be taken, as outlined in the Town's by-laws, primarily By-law 2018-055 and By-law 2020-107.

  • Contravention of By-law: Failure to pay water rates when due is considered a contravention of By-law 2018-055, specifically Section 11.11 and Section 20.6.
  • Overdue Notices and Fees: Overdue/Arrears Notices for Water & Tax Accounts may be issued, incurring a fee of $6.00, as per By-law 2020-107.
  • Addition to Tax Account and Interest: All charges for water supplied, or expenses incurred related to water services, if not collected from the owner, may be added to the property tax account and will accrue interest. This is detailed in Section 11.10 and Section 11.22 of By-law 2018-055. These charges become a lien on the property.
  • Water Service Disconnection: The Town may turn off your water service without prior notice if you fail to comply with the provisions of By-law 2018-055, including non-payment of bills. The Town is not liable for any damages resulting from the water being turned off (Section 18.3 of By-law 2018-055).
  • Reconnection Fees: If your water service is disconnected due to non-payment, it will not be reconnected until all outstanding amounts, including a reconnection fee, are paid to the Town (Section 19.1 of By-law 2018-055).
  • Penalties: As non-payment is a contravention of the by-law, you may be subject to penalties. By-law 2018-055 outlines general penalties for contraventions, which can include fines upon conviction (Section 20.3 of By-law 2018-055).
original_data.laymans_answer:
Here's what could happen if you don't pay your water bill in Whitchurch-Stouffville:
  • You'll be considered in violation of Town rules.
  • You may receive overdue notices, which include a $6.00 fee.
  • Unpaid water charges can be added to your property tax bill, and interest will accrue. This becomes a lien on your property.
  • The Town may shut off your water service without warning and isn't responsible for any resulting damage.
  • To reconnect your water after a shut-off, you must pay all outstanding charges plus a reconnection fee.
  • You may face penalties, including fines.

original_data.query: am i allowed to set off fireworks in my backyard
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility of discharging or igniting consumer fireworks on private residential property within the Town's municipal boundaries. This inquiry pertains to compliance with all applicable bylaws, including but not limited to noise control, fire safety regulations, zoning ordinances governing permissible land use, animal control bylaws regarding disturbance, and any temporary or seasonal prohibitions currently in effect regarding the sale, possession, or discharge of fireworks.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Fireworks Discharge in Whitchurch-Stouffville

No, you are not allowed to set off fireworks in your backyard in the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville. By-law 2025-024, which came into force on April 16, 2025, explicitly prohibits the discharge of 'Family Fireworks' (also known as consumer fireworks) anywhere in the Town.

Specifically, By-law 2025-024 states:

  • Section 3.1: "No Person shall Discharge Family Fireworks in the Town."
  • Section 1.5.b: Defines "Family Fireworks" as "low hazard fireworks that are generally used for recreation and are classified as Type F.1 explosives under the Act. They are also known as consumer fireworks."

This by-law also prohibits the sale of any fireworks in the Town year-round (Section 2.1 of By-law 2025-024).

Professional 'Display Fireworks' and 'Pyrotechnic Special Effects Fireworks' may only be discharged with a permit issued by the Town's Fire Chief or an Assistant to the Fire Marshal, subject to strict conditions outlined in By-law 2025-024.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Fireworks Discharge in Whitchurch-Stouffville

No, you are not allowed to set off fireworks in your backyard in Whitchurch-Stouffville. By-law 2025-024 prohibits discharging 'Family Fireworks' anywhere in Town.

'Family Fireworks' are defined as low-hazard fireworks used for recreation.

It is also prohibited to sell fireworks in Whitchurch-Stouffville year-round.

Professional fireworks displays may only occur with a permit from the Town's Fire Chief, and are subject to specific conditions.

Fireworks Regulation in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, personal fireworks, also known as 'Family Fireworks' or 'consumer fireworks', are regulated under By-law 2025-024.

  • Sale Prohibition: By-law 2025-024 completely prohibits the sale or offering for sale of any kind or description of fireworks in the Town on any day during the year (Clause 2.1).
  • Discharge Prohibition: The discharge (setting off) of Family Fireworks is prohibited in the Town (Clause 3.1).
  • Definition: 'Family Fireworks' are defined as low hazard fireworks generally used for recreation and classified as Type F.1 explosives under the Explosives Act (Clause 1.5.b).

This means that both the sale and the setting off of personal fireworks are prohibited in Whitchurch-Stouffville.

original_data.query: I like feeding birds in my backyard. Is that allowed?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility, under current and recently enacted Town bylaws, of providing food or sustenance to avian wildlife on private residential property. This inquiry pertains to potential contraventions of bylaws related to animal control, nuisance wildlife management, property standards, waste disposal, public health regulations concerning vectors and disease transmission, and zoning ordinances impacting permissible land uses and potential attractants for wildlife. Determine any applicable obligations, permissions, or prohibitions.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Feeding Birds in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, By-law 2019-047-RE generally prohibits intentionally feeding wild animals or leaving food outdoors in a way that attracts or is accessible to wild, feral, or stray domestic animals on private or public property. However, there is a specific exception for feeding songbirds in your backyard, provided certain conditions are met:

  • The bird seed must be placed in a bird feeding device that is high enough off the ground to prevent wild animals from accessing it.
  • Your bird feeding practices must not attract large flocks of homing birds, such as wild, feral, or domestic pigeons.
  • Any spilled seed on the ground must be promptly removed and disposed of in a manner that does not attract wild animals, feral, or stray domestic animals.

As long as these requirements are followed, feeding songbirds in your backyard is permitted.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Feeding Birds in Whitchurch-Stouffville

You generally can't intentionally feed wild animals or leave food outside where it attracts animals on public or private property. However, you *can* feed songbirds in your backyard if you:

  • Use a bird feeder that's high enough to keep wild animals away.
  • Don't attract large flocks of birds like pigeons.
  • Clean up spilled seed right away so it doesn't attract animals.

If you follow these rules, feeding songbirds in your backyard is permitted.

original_data.query: Can my dog be off leash?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding the permissibility of allowing a canine animal to be unrestrained by a leash within the Town's municipal boundaries. Specifically, what are the current regulations, as of [Current Date], pertaining to off-leash canines, including designated areas, prohibited zones, temporal restrictions, owner responsibilities under Animal Control Bylaws, potential violations, and relevant sections of the Public Health Act, Zoning Bylaws, and Waste Management regulations concerning animal defecation and public nuisance?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Dog Leash Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, dogs are generally required to be on a leash when they are not on their owner's property. This is regulated by the Town's by-laws concerning animal services and parks.

  • Running at Large Prohibited: According to By-law 2019-047, Section 3.3, "No Owner of a Domestic Animal shall allow a Domestic Animal to Run at Large within the limits of the Town, unless prior consent is given by the owner of the property in which the Domestic Animal is found to be Running at Large."
  • Definition of Running at Large: By-law 2019-047, Section 1.34, defines "Run at Large" or "Running at Large" as "any Domestic Animal found in any place other than the Premises of the Owner and not controlled by a Leash in the hand of the Owner." This means that if your dog is off your property and not on a leash held by you, it is considered to be running at large. By-law 2001-082-LI, Section 16, also reinforces this by stating that a dog is deemed to be running at large when found in any place other than the owner's premises and not under the control of any person.
  • Responsibility of Owners: If a domestic animal is found running at large, the owner is presumed to have caused or permitted it, unless they can prove they took all reasonable precautions to prevent it (By-law 2019-047, Section 3.4).
  • Parks and Public Spaces: Specifically for parks, trails, park buildings, and open spaces, By-law 2020-087, Section 8.1(a), states that no person as owner or person having control of any dog shall "Allow it to run at large." Additionally, By-law 2019-047, Section 8.1(b), prohibits dogs (excluding guide or therapy dogs) from entering certain areas like beaches, ponds, swimming areas, playgrounds, or sports fields, or any other area posted to prohibit them.
  • Trespassing: Owners are also prohibited from allowing their domestic animals to trespass on private property, whether leashed or unleashed (By-law 2019-047, Section 3.11).
  • Exceptions: Exceptions to these rules include Police Work Dogs or working dogs employed under contract to the Town, when they are actively engaged in the performance of their trained duty (By-law 2019-047, Section 3.5).

Therefore, to comply with Town by-laws, your dog must be on a leash and under your control when it is off your private property in Whitchurch-Stouffville.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Dog Leash Regulations in Whitchurch-Stouffville

In Whitchurch-Stouffville, your dog must be on a leash when off your property.

  • Running at Large Prohibited: Dogs cannot run at large unless the property owner gives consent.
  • Definition of Running at Large: A dog is "running at large" if it's off your property and not on a leash held by you.
  • Responsibility of Owners: If your dog is running at large, it's assumed you allowed it, unless you prove you took precautions.
  • Parks and Public Spaces: Dogs must be leashed in parks, trails, park buildings, and open spaces. Dogs (except guide or therapy dogs) are not allowed on beaches, ponds, swimming areas, playgrounds, sports fields, or areas where prohibited.
  • Trespassing: Dogs are not allowed on private property, even on a leash.
  • Exceptions: Police work dogs or working dogs under contract to the Town are exempt when working.

To comply with Town regulations, keep your dog on a leash and under control when off your property in Whitchurch-Stouffville.

original_data.query: How many hours can I park on the street?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding permissible duration of vehicle parking on municipal roadways. Request clarification on any applicable time limitations, restrictions, or prohibitions governing on-street parking as stipulated under relevant Traffic and Parking Bylaws, including but not limited to regulations pertaining to overnight parking, designated parking zones, and temporary parking restrictions. Seek current regulations, considering amendments enacted within the past [X] years, impacting allowable continuous parking duration on Town roadways.
original_data.filtered_answer:
General Parking Regulations

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, generally, no person shall park any vehicle on any highway for a period longer than three (3) hours. This general regulation is outlined in by-laws such as By-law 2009-007 and By-law 2021-100, which amend the main parking by-law By-law 2008-114-PR.

Exceptions to the Three-Hour Rule

There are various exceptions to the three-hour parking rule, which are typically detailed in Schedule III (Three (3) Hour Parking Exceptions) of By-law 2008-114-PR, as amended by subsequent by-laws. These exceptions vary by specific location and permitted times. Examples include:

  • On a portion of Church Street located south of Main Street, 24-hour parking is permitted (By-law 2009-007).
  • On Main Street, parking is generally restricted to 3 hours, with specific permitted times depending on the section. For instance, some sections allow 3-hour parking Monday to Saturday from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., with extended hours on Thursday and Friday evenings (By-law 2018-038). Other sections may have 3-hour parking permitted from 2:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. (By-law 2020-137) or from 6:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m. (By-law 2021-100).
  • In Residential Neighbourhoods, 3-hour parking exceptions may apply during specific hours, such as 2:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. (By-law 2020-137) or 9:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m. (By-law 2021-100), unless otherwise posted.
  • Specific streets and areas have unique permitted parking times as exceptions to the 3-hour rule, often allowing parking daily from 4:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. or at any time. These locations include, but are not limited to:
    • Dougherty Crescent (East side parallel to Ninth Line, and specific sections between house numbers) (By-law 2009-007, By-law 2021-100, By-law 2024-001)
    • Miltrose Crescent (East side parallel to the GO Transit corridor) (By-law 2009-007, By-law 2021-100)
    • James Ratcliff Avenue (South side adjacent to stormwater management block/valley view corridor) (By-law 2009-007, By-law 2021-100)
    • Brill Court (cul-de-sac) (By-law 2009-007, By-law 2021-100)
    • Delbert Circle (East side parallel to the GO Transit Corridor) (By-law 2022-123)
    • Specific sections of Brown Lane, Betula Gate, Fernglen Crescent, Firbank Lane, Hoppington Avenue, and Jamesway Crescent may permit parking at any time (By-law 2024-095, By-law 2024-001).
    • On Park Drive North, a specific section on the west side from Main Street Intersection to a point 121 feet northerly allows parking anytime (By-law 1988-139).

No Parking Zones

It is important to note that many streets and sections of streets have specific "No Parking" or "No Stopping" restrictions, which prohibit parking at all times or during certain hours. These restrictions are detailed in Schedule II (No Parking) and Schedule IV (No Stopping) of By-law 2008-114-PR, as amended. Examples include:

  • Millard Street has a "No Stopping" zone Monday to Friday from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. within 30 meters of school boundaries (By-law 2003-097).
  • Clark Street (West Side) and Gladys Clarkson Boulevard (East Side) have no parking restrictions during specific hours on weekdays (By-law 2015-001).
  • Hoover Park Drive and Yakefarm Blvd have no parking restrictions Monday to Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. (By-law 2015-089).
  • Various sections of Mill Street, Frederick Street, George Street, James Ratcliff Avenue, Dougherty Crescent, and Win Timbers Crescent have "Anytime" no parking restrictions (By-law 2020-137).
  • Newer no-parking zones have been added on streets like Byers Pond Way, Churchill Drive East, Daws Hare Crescent, Harriet Crescent, Lakeshore Road, and Robertdale Court, some with specific time restrictions (By-law 2020-079, By-law 2023-070).
  • Parking is prohibited on all roads within a road closure for the full duration of the closure (By-law 2023-070).

Winter Parking Restrictions

Please be aware that there are general on-street parking restrictions during winter months (referred to as Section 17, On Street Parking - Winter Months). However, certain locations may be exempt from these winter restrictions, as noted in By-law 2024-001.

For precise parking regulations at a specific location, it is always recommended to check local signage and the most current version of the Town's parking by-laws.

General Parking Duration

Exceptions to the Three-Hour Parking Limit

    • North side, between Weldon Road and #73 Dougherty Crescent, parking is permitted Anytime (By-law 2024-001).

  • Fernglen Crescent: West side, between #93 and #113 Fernglen Crescent, parking is permitted Anytime (By-law 2024-095).

    • West side, between #26 and #100 Firbank Lane, parking is permitted Anytime (By-law 2024-001).

Winter Parking Restrictions

To facilitate snow removal, parking is generally prohibited on any highway under the Town's jurisdiction between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. from December 1st of each year to March 31st of the following year. This is stated in Section 17(a) of By-law 2008-114.

Exceptions to these winter parking restrictions include:

  • The following locations, which are also exempt from the three-hour parking rule and permit "Anytime" parking:
    • Dougherty Crescent (East, between Weldon Road and #80 and #126 Dougherty Crescent) (By-law 2024-001).
    • Dougherty Crescent (North, between Weldon Road and #73 Dougherty Crescent) (By-law 2024-001).
    • Dougherty Crescent (South, between Weldon Road and #127 Dougherty Crescent) (By-law 2024-001).
    • Firbank Lane (North, between #3 and #23 Firbank Lane) (By-law 2024-001).
    • Firbank Lane (West, between #26 and #100 Firbank Lane) (By-law 2024-001).
    • Hoppington Avenue (West & South, between Mantle Avenue and Firbank Lane) (By-law 2024-001).
    • Jamesway Crescent (East & North, between Weldon Road and Dougherty Crescent) (By-law 2024-001).

Please note that specific signage on streets may indicate additional or different parking regulations. Always observe posted signs.
original_data.laymans_answer:
General Parking Duration

You can park on any street in Whitchurch-Stouffville for up to three hours.

Exceptions to the Three-Hour Parking Limit

Some streets allow parking for longer than three hours, or at any time:

  • Betula Gate: West side, between #6 and #22 Brown Lane (flankage): Anytime.
  • Brill Court: Along the cul-de-sac: Daily 4 p.m. to 9 a.m.
  • Brown Lane:
    • South side, between #5 and #35 Brown Lane: Anytime.
    • East side, between #32 (flankage) and #58 Brown Lane: Anytime.
  • Delbert Circle:
    • East side, parallel to the GO Transit Corridor: Daily 4 p.m. to 9 a.m.
    • East side, between #23 and #101 (flankage): Anytime.
  • Dougherty Crescent:
    • East side, parallel to the Ninth Line: Daily 4 p.m. to 9 a.m.
    • East side, between #80 and #126 Dougherty Crescent: Anytime.
    • North side, between Weldon Road and #73 Dougherty Crescent: Anytime.
    • South side, between Weldon Road and #127 Dougherty Crescent: Anytime.
  • Fernglen Crescent: West side, between #93 and #113 Fernglen Crescent: Anytime.
  • Firbank Lane:
    • North side, between #3 and #23 Firbank Lane: Anytime.
    • West side, between #26 and #100 Firbank Lane: Anytime.
  • Hoppington Avenue: West & South, between Mantle Avenue and Firbank Lane: Anytime.
  • James Ratcliff Avenue: South/West, adjacent to the stormwater management block: Daily 4 p.m. to 9 a.m.
  • Jamesway Crescent: East & North, between Weldon Road and Dougherty Crescent: Anytime.
  • Main Street: Both sides, Albert Street to Park Drive: Daily 6 p.m. to 2 a.m.
  • Miltrose Crescent: East side, parallel to the GO Transit Corridor: Daily 4 p.m. to 9 a.m.
  • Residential Neighbourhoods: Both sides, unless otherwise posted: Daily 9 p.m. to 2 a.m.

Winter Parking Restrictions

From December 1st to March 31st, parking is not allowed on any street between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. to allow for snow removal.

Exceptions to these winter parking restrictions include:

  • The portion of Church Street south of Main Street.
  • The following locations, which also allow "Anytime" parking:
    • Dougherty Crescent (East, between Weldon Road and #80 and #126 Dougherty Crescent).
    • Dougherty Crescent (North, between Weldon Road and #73 Dougherty Crescent).
    • Dougherty Crescent (South, between Weldon Road and #127 Dougherty Crescent).
    • Firbank Lane (North, between #3 and #23 Firbank Lane).
    • Firbank Lane (West, between #26 and #100 Firbank Lane).
    • Hoppington Avenue (West & South, between Mantle Avenue and Firbank Lane).
    • Jamesway Crescent (East & North, between Weldon Road and Dougherty Crescent).

Always check posted signs, as they may have different rules.

original_data.query: Bylaws around open fire pit in the backyard
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire regarding current bylaws pertaining to open-air burning, recreational fires, and outdoor fireplaces on private residential property within Town limits. Specifically, what regulations govern permissible locations, dimensions, required permits, safety precautions, allowable fuel types, temporal restrictions (including seasonal bans), and potential impacts on neighbouring properties concerning smoke, noise, and odour, with reference to relevant sections of the Fire Prevention Bylaw, Zoning Bylaw, and Public Nuisance Bylaw, as amended to date.
original_data.filtered_answer:
Bylaws for Open Fire Pits in Backyards

In the Town of Whitchurch-Stouffville, open fire pits in backyards are generally considered "Recreational Fires" and do not require a permit, provided they comply with specific conditions outlined in By-law 2016-056. Recreational Fires are defined as the burning of clean wood products for cooking, heating, enjoyment, religious ceremony, or similar purposes.

The following conditions must be met for recreational fires:

  • The fire must not exceed 0.75 meters (approximately 2.5 feet) in diameter or 0.75 meters in height and must be contained to prevent the spread of fire.
  • Only clean wood products may be burned. Prohibited materials include petroleum products, plastics, rubber, painted lumber, domestic, industrial, agricultural waste, or any other material that will cause excessive smoke or noxious fumes.
  • A competent person must supervise the recreational fire at all times until it is completely extinguished.
  • Adequate means to extinguish the fire must be present and in close proximity.
  • A minimum distance of 3 meters (approximately 10 feet) to combustible materials must be maintained at all times.
  • Recreational fires are not permitted when the wind speed exceeds 20 kph, when the wind direction is changing frequently, or when there is decreased visibility on any highway in the vicinity.
  • Recreational fires are prohibited when an Open Air Burning Ban has been declared by the Fire Chief.
  • Recreational fires are prohibited during construction within any subdivision or on any construction site within the Town.
  • If using outdoor fireplaces, they must be equipped with screens on the flue and fuel loading area. Their use must comply with the manufacturer's guidelines. If no manufacturer's guidelines exist, a minimum 3-meter clearance must be maintained between the fireplace and combustible objects, and it must be installed on a non-combustible surface.
  • Recreational fires that emit excessive amounts of smoke or sparks or create a nuisance are not permitted and must be extinguished.
  • The Fire Chief may at any time require that a recreational fire be extinguished.
  • The resident or occupant of the land must ensure that Officers have full access to the land at all times during the recreational fire.

Please note that these regulations are specific to recreational fires. Larger open-air burning activities typically require a permit from the Fire Chief, as outlined in By-law 2016-056.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Backyard Fire Pit Rules

You can have a fire pit in your backyard for cooking, heating, or enjoyment, as long as you follow these rules:

  • The fire must be no bigger than 2.5 feet wide and 2.5 feet high, and contained.
  • Burn only clean wood. Do not burn things like plastic or rubber.
  • Someone must watch the fire until it's completely out.
  • Have a way to put the fire out nearby.
  • Keep the fire at least 10 feet away from anything that can burn.
  • Don't have a fire if the wind is over 20 kph, the wind direction keeps changing, or visibility is poor.
  • Don't have a fire if the Fire Chief has announced a burning ban. As of today, June 30, 2025, there is no burning ban in effect.
  • Fires are not allowed during construction in subdivisions or construction sites.
  • Outdoor fireplaces must have screens. Follow the manufacturer's instructions. If there are no instructions, keep it 10 feet from anything that can burn and put it on a surface that won't burn.
  • Don't let the fire make too much smoke or sparks, or create a nuisance.
  • The Fire Chief can tell you to put out the fire at any time.
  • Allow Officers access to your property at all times during the fire.

These rules are for recreational fires. Larger fires may need a permit from the Fire Chief.

original_data.query: Can I park my car facing the wrong way on the street?
original_data.transformed_query: Inquire as to the permissibility, under current Town municipal bylaws and regulations pertaining to vehicular traffic and parking, of positioning a motor vehicle on a public roadway or right-of-way with the vehicle's orientation contravening the designated direction of travel for that lane or side of the street. Specifically, does any provision within the Traffic and Parking Bylaw, or any related bylaw concerning public safety or obstruction of roadways, prohibit parking against the flow of traffic?
original_data.filtered_answer:
Parking Direction on Highways

No person shall park any vehicle on any highway with the front of the vehicle facing opposite to the direction in which vehicular traffic is proceeding on that side of the street. This regulation is outlined in By-law 2008-114, Section 6(a)(xviii), as amended by By-law 2017-027, Section 2.
original_data.laymans_answer:
Parking Direction on Highways

No, you cannot park your vehicle on any street with the front of the vehicle facing against the normal direction of traffic on that side of the street.
